context_snippets: ALS. Informs addressee of his wife's illness and instructs him to inform Dr. Variot that he will hold a promised clinic soon.

creator: Latane, John Holladay, 1869-1932. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no99089612
title: John Holladay Latane letter, 1914, Feb. 12 : Baltimore, to Dr. Jacobs.
context_snippets: ALS. Latane responds to Jacobs' inquiries regarding a 1797 letter by Benjamin Rush on slavery. In his opinion, "the framers of the Constitution seem to have regarded slavery as a dying institution, but the invention of the cotton-gin in 1793 gave it a new lease on life."

creator: Earle, Pliny, 1809-1892. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n95067768
title: Pliny Earle papers, 1806-1897.
context_snippets: Business and professional correspondence of Pliny Earle, Sr., (1762-1832), inventor and cotton textiles manufacturer, and of Pliny, (1809-1892), physician and alienist, including a few personal letters to Miss Earle. Correspondence addressed to Earle, Sr., touches on politics, patent rights and carding machines. Correspondence addressed to Earle relates to mental illness and the institutional care of the mentally ill. He received letters from physicians, institutional administrators, and philanthropists, including a number of letters of introduction. Items, mostly ALS and 10 addressed envelopes, are arranged in roughly chronological order.

creator: Lewis, Dio, 1823-1886. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n88620594

context_snippets: ALS. Writes to "my dear Holbrook" of his intention to start a school of physical education and to write a book and to Mr. Woolson, inviting both Woolson and his wife to join him that summer.

creator: Nott, Josiah C. (Josiah Clark), 1804-1873. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50065142
title: Josiah Clark Nott letters and note, 1839, 1855 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection contains two letters and one note, written by physician Josiah Clark Nott from Mobile, Alabama, where he first practiced medicine. The letter from 1839 speaks of payment for services and difficulty of finances; the 1855 letter comments favorably on a work by Arthur de Gobineau on the theory of racial differences, published in French in the U.S. in 1855, which upheld the superiority of the "Aryan race" and thus promoted slavery as a just and moral system. Nott mentions in the 1855 letter that he had hired a "young friend" to help with the translation of Gobineau's work, which was published in 1856 in a much shortened and edited form. The undated note asks about the suitability of evening attire.

creator: Rolleston, Humphry Davy, Sir, 1862-1944. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84803401
title: Sir Humphry Davy Rolleston papers, 1882-1943.
context_snippets: ALS from many notable members of the British medical establishment, including William Bateson, John Bland-Sutton, Byrom Bramwell, Yandell Henderson, Thomas Jeeves Horder, Arthur F. Hurst, Robert Hutchison, James Mackenzie, Arthur Salusbury Macnalty, Norman Moore, Berkeley Moynihan, Charles Samuel Myers, George Newman, D'Arcy Power, Charles Scott Sherrington, and Grafton Elliott Smith. Foreign correspondents include Pierre Marie and Karl Sudhoff. Most letters are of a casual social nature, though reference is often made to Rolleston's lectures and publications. A complete list of correspondents is available.

creator: Rush, Benjamin, 1746-1813, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50000649 creator.
title: Benjamin and Julia Stockton Rush papers, 1766-1845 and undated.
context_snippets: Papers include letters, writings, financial records, a few legal documents and one educational record. Benjamin Rush's personal and professional outgoing letters, with some incoming letters, cover a wide variety of topics, but focus primarily on medical concerns, particularly the 1793 and other yellow fever epidemics in Philadelphia, as well as mental illness and its treatment, and the medical department of the Continental Army, among other topics. There are a few letters from others to Julia Stockton Rush that seek to continue ties with her and the Rush family or offer condolences following Benjamin's death. Collection also contains a medical case book and a fragment of an essay or lecture written by Benjamin Rush, along with his travel diary for a trip to meet with the Board of Trustees for Dickinson College in 178[4]; other writings include Julia Rush's devotional journal and exercise book. The financial records include a few medical statements and receipts, but primarily contain two account books, one maintained by Benjamin Rush, the other by Rush with his wife. These account books provide a complete picture of the family finances from the period when Rush set up his medical practice almost to Julia's death. Legal documents include a sworn statement and a land patent, and there is an educational record for one of Rush's students.

creator: Salmon, Frederick, 1796-1868. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2015189593
title: Frederick Salmon papers, 1864-1867.
context_snippets: ALS. Salmon writes to a Miss Acton, a former patient, referring to his health and to the election of assistant surgeons at St. Mark's Hospital.

creator: Sandwith, Humphry, 1822-1881. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no94036878
title: Humphry Sandwith papers, 1864 and undated.
context_snippets: ANS. Sandwith writes to his publisher regarding the date of publication of his new book and to a Miss Pike regarding the dates of his departure from and return to England.

creator: Sayer, John Lathrop, 1819-1884. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2017050914
title: John Lathrop Sayer papers, 1833-1872.
context_snippets: Papers consist of three types of material: correspondence, loose manuscript leaves, and ms. notebooks. Correspondence consists of letters written by Sayer, his wife, Sarah A. Sayer, and the Superintendent at the Asylum, John Gray, during Sayer's stay at the Asylum. Loose manuscripts consist of miscellaneous notes, a poem, Sayer's teacher certification, and the school lists of both Sayer and his wife, then Sarah Ann Bennet. Notebooks: "Sketches of life" (a journal, tp., 23 pp., 1842-1859); "A book intended for writings" (notebook of essays and poems, tp., 23 pp., 1837); and an algebra notebook (tp., 85 pp., 1833) with notes on town bonds at the end (3 pp., 1872).

creator: Sayer, John Lathrop, 1819-1884. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2017050914

creator: Shattuck, Frederick Cheever, 1847-1929. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2011166882
title: Frederick Cheever Shattuck papers, 1822-1928.
context_snippets: ALS and TLS to Shattuck regarding Harvard Medical School history and the raising of funds for a bust of John Collins Warren (1778-1856). Notable correspondents include Frank Billings, Henry Ashbury Christian, John Miller Turpin Finney, Joel Ernest Goldthwait, Elliott Proctor Joslin, Richard Pearson Strong, Edward Wyllys Taylor, John Collins Warren (1866-1932), and Aldred Scott Warthin. Papers also include letters to the Arnold family of Paris from Shattuck's father, George Cheyne Shattuck, Jr. (1813-1893), and his grandfather, George Cheyne Shattuck (1783-1854). There is also a newspaper clipping of an obituary for G.C. Shattuck, Jr.

creator: Petit-Radel, M. (Philippe), 1749-1815. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86804820
title: M. Petit-Radel papers, 1792-1803 : Paris.
context_snippets: Holograph document, signed. Receipt of payment by M. Panckoucke, probably Charles Joseph Panckoucke (1736-1798), for work on the Dictionnarie de chirurgie. ALS to Nicolas Dubois de Chemant, regarding personal financial and professional matters. Dubois de Chemant's wife adds a postscript.

creator: Throop, Amos, 1738-1814. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n93025568
title: Amos Throop letter, 1807, Nov. 4 : Providence, Rhode Island, to Zachariah Allen, Exeter, New Hampshire.
context_snippets: Pioneer, philanthropist and founder of Throop University, later the California Institute of Technology.

creator: Torrey, John, 1796-1873. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84075762
title: John Torrey papers, 1818-1862? and undated.
context_snippets: ALS. Papers consist mostly of letters written to Torrey by professional colleagues, botanists and geologists involved in exploration and surveyor expeditions. Notable correspondents include Louis Agassiz, A.D. Bache, Spencer Fullerton Baird, George Bentham, Jacob Bigelow, James Dwight Dana, William Darlington, Amos Eaton, Ebenezer Emmons, Asa Gray, A. Guyot, Robert Hare, Joseph Henry, Edward Hitchcock, John Lindley, Josiah Clark Nott, C.S. Rafinesque, and John White Webster. A complete list of correspondents is available.

creator: Treat, Malachi.
title: Malachi Treat letter, 1780, Aug. 22 : Albany, to Andrew Craigie, Philadelphia.
context_snippets: ALS. Treat requests medical supplies and reports of Indian atrocities on the frontier.

creator: Treat, Malachi.
title: Malachi Treat letter, 1780, Aug. 22 : Albany, to Andrew Craigie, Philadelphia.
context_snippets: Physician-General of the Northern Division of the Medical Department of the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War.

creator: Turner, William.
title: William Turner letter, 1802, Sept. 18 : Washington, D.C.
context_snippets: ALS. A copy of his letter to Miss "Fanny" Clifton, written hours before his departure to the Mediterranean for Naval service, in which he passionately bids her farewell.

creator: Mitchell, S. Weir (Silas Weir), 1829-1914. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50036751
title: Silas Weir Mitchell papers, 1809-1915 and undated.
context_snippets: U.S. author, educator, and physician, based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; pioneer in the field of neurology and of the "rest cure" for hysteria, particularly used as a treatment for women.

creator: Thompson, Henry, Sir, 1820-1904, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n89662245 creator.
title: Sir Henry Thompson papers, 1851-1913 and undated.
context_snippets: Most letters in this collection are largely polite and perfunctory notes between Thompson and peers; some correspondents include his wife, the pianist Kate Loder; Empress Frederick of Germany; the Duke of York (later King George V) of England; and King Leopold II of Belgium. The collection documents Thompson's social status and activities between the 1850s and early 1900s. It contains few details about his medical practice, aside from some materials advocating for the adoption of the practice of cremation. Some materials are addressed to members of his family, including son Herbert Thompson. Letters are numbered and itemized inventory is included with the materials.

creator: Simpson, James Young, 1811-1870. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50056894
title: James Young Simpson letters, 1868-1911, and undated.
context_snippets: 92 ms. leaves of Simpson's notes on obstetrics, H.A. Kelly's description of contents of notes, 6 items printed material, 4 ALS from Simpson, a holograph poem, a signed calling card, and ms notes on Simpson in Kelly's hand. In his letters, Simpson writes of acupressure, animal magnetism, smallpox, scarlet fever, classical education, the importance of physical exercise and electoral politics. Printed material relates to members of the Simpson family, including Alexander Russell Simpson and Margaret Stewart Barbour. In his notes, Simpson writes of diseases of the placenta and the fetus, of pregnancies, abortions and premature labor, and of the use of collyria in the treatment of eye diseases. 3 ALS. Only named correspondent is a Mr. Hutchison. Letters reflect Simpson's wide range of interests. He urges measures to stamp out' smallpox and scarlet fever; refers correspondent to Mr. Farrar's lecture on classical education, presented at the Royal Institution; stresses the importance of physical exercise for the student, Miss Campbell of St. Margaret's College; and discusses the electoral prospects of a Liberal candidate, Mr. Pender.

creator: Nightingale, Florence, 1820-1910. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79103647
title: Florence Nightingale papers, 1870-1941 and undated, [bulk 1870-1897].
context_snippets: Papers include letters to William Howell Reed, thanking him for the gift of his Hospital life in the Army of the Potomac; to Lady Marian Alford, relating to the Lord Stratford de Redcliffe Memorial Fund; and a series of personal and very affectionate letters to Miss A.P. Lemon, later Mrs. L. Roscoria, a colleague and personal friend, regarding her health, as well as the illness of her mother, and affairs of the hospital. Other items are newspaper clippings about Nightingale and a postcard bearing her portrait.

creator: Walker, Mary Edwards, 1832-1919. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n85808959
title: Mary Edwards Walker papers, 1885-1898, [Washington, D.C.]

creator: Franklin, Mrs., of Petersburg, Va.
title: Diary, 1899-1907.
context_snippets: Handwritten diary containing an African-American woman's religious and philosophical reflections, inspirational clippings, and lists of books she read along with her opinions of them. Also contains references to St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, St. Paul's Episcopal Church, and the Central State Hospital for the Colored Insane.

creator: Werber, William Murray.
title: Papers, 1968-1969.
context_snippets: Copies of letters William Murray Werber, a Duke alumnus, wrote to President Douglas M. Knight and to Professor Robert S. Rankin, a member of the Federal Civil Rights Commission; letters of Werber to the Duke Board of Trustees; reponses from Dr. Knight; copies of correspondence of Joseph M. Hunt, Jr., Chairman of the NC State Highway Commission; and clippings. These papers concern the admission of blacks to Duke, Dr. Knight's administration, and blacks in our general society. Werber and Hunt were very much opposed to some of the things that were going on at Duke during 1968 and 1969.

creator: White, Van Russell.
title: Papers, 1778-1974.
context_snippets: Papers pertain mostly to the Colonel's service on the UN team in China, during the struggle between Nationalist and Communist parties, 1946-47. Photos are mainly of Colonel White in uniform some at Fort Bragg, and some during WWII. Miscellaneous items include an issue of a newspaper of the Civilian Conservation Corp, a few receipts for slave exchanges and a letter from Governor Thomas M. Holt of NC.

creator: Whiteside, Thomas. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2010184164
title: Papers, 1821-1864.
context_snippets: Gentleman's pocket book, bound in suede with flap. Scanty accounts fill only a small portion of the book. "Thos. Whiteside--His book" is written on the front, and the name is mentioned several times inside. Book appears to have originally been owned by Jesse Broomfield whose initials appear above Whiteside's on the cover and the earliest entries bear his name. Broomfield was one of the original sponsors of the Ebenezer Academy (1834) near Rock Hill, SC.

creator: Whitford, Hardy.
title: Papers, 1861-1886.
context_snippets: Mostly personal letters and business records pertaining to the affairs of the Whitford plantation near New Bern. There is also a sprinkling of legal and tax papers, together with 16 small account books.

There is correspondence to Roy Whitted from his girlfriend, Gladys Brown, a student at the Alice Freeman Palmer Memorial Institute, a school established for blacks in 1901, in Sedalia, NC. There is a letter from Benjamin Berry of Philadelphia, and one from a soldier heading overseas to his teacher, Annie Whitted.

context_snippets: Two letters written by Davis to his wife in Camden, South Carolina, during the Civil War. He wrote the week of May 7-10, 1864, of his efforts to rejoin his command.

creator: Davis, William W., creator.
title: William W. Davis papers, 1835-1856.
context_snippets: Business correspondence dealing with the iron trade. Some of the concerns are iron sales, finances and accounting, employment, slave sales, and some technical matters concerning the iron industry. Possible relationship with the William Weaver Papers.

creator: La Riviere, Savignac de.
title: Savignac de La Riviere letter 1772 July 25.
context_snippets: Collection contains a 3-page letter from La Riviere to Monsieur de Bon, who was seigneur de Savignac. The letter recounted family and business news, and also explained the difficulties of life as a settler in Grenada. In addition, La Riviere also mentions slaves and the employment of blacks.

creator: DeLong, James Reid.
title: Papers, 1847-1911, bulk 1862-1865.
context_snippets: Collection consists chiefly of letters from DeLong to his wife about camp life and surroundings as his unit moved from Baltimore to Virginia, Tennessee and Georgia. Topics include Sherman's march and the Carolina Campaign. There is other family correspondence from DeLong's brother, US Minister Plenipotentiary to Japan and from John Henry Ketchum on congressional stationery.

creator: Dillon, Martin, 1938- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n91015374
title: Papers, 1848-1895 and n.d.
context_snippets: Papers include a petition to Sir Charles Napier (Barrackpure), analysis of Lord Dalhousie's Minute, copy of Sir Napier's Farewell Order to the Indian Army (Camp Ferozepore), a memorial to Lord Napier of Magdala, a copy of a letter from Lt. Col. E.F. Chapman R.A. (Kandahar), to Maj. Gen. C.C. Johnson, and other documents from Sir Colin Campbell and Sir Dillon.

creator: Dodson, Elizabeth F.
title: Papers, 1861-1899.
context_snippets: Collection consists mostly of letters from Confederate soldiers to Miss Dodson, most from Charles M. Lovelace or Robert W. Wilkinson. The contents are mainly personal and describe little about the military. Also included is a copy of Dan A. Grosvenor's military record.

creator: Venable family.
title: Papers, 1831-1904.
context_snippets: Collection contains correspondence between family members dispersed from Virginia to New Orleans. Many are written by women and cover such subjects as children, health, religion, crops, servants, life of Confederate soldiers, Reconstruction and politics. The wife of Dr. R. Venable reports woundings, deaths and imprisonments of Confederate soldiers. There is some correspondence from ministers and one letter reporting the explosion of the ship, PRINCESS, on the Mississippi. Financial records are also included.

creator: Vicars, Henry George Austin, 1833-1867, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2016156300 creator.
title: Henry George Austin Vicars diaries, 1853-1865.
context_snippets: The collection consists of nine diaries, dated during Vicars' military service in India between 1853 and 1865. It includes an account of his experiences during the Sepoy Rebellion of 1857 and 1858. The diaries includes his reports on the mutiny of Indian regiments, the riots and massacres of European civilians in Delhi, the disarming of Sepoys at Firozpur, supervising the blowing up a magazine, distributing Enfield rifles, British executions of mutineers (including , marching on Delhi, the siege and battles for Delhi, and subduing the city. He also describes ongoing cholera epidemics and fevers, his daily life as a soldier (pre- and post-rebellion), and his home leave in England. The diaries touch on his work as adjutant in attending different court marshals and punishments for army men due to theft, drunkenness, or more serious crimes. More routine topics discussed include the climate and weather; his current view and location at different forts and locales in India, Mauritius, Ceylon, at sea, and England; hobbies and pursuits he enjoyed such as horseback riding, shopping, reading, photography, and cricket; and different dinners and events he attended as an officer. There is one folder with a few loose items that were formerly tucked into the diary pages.

creator: Vincent, Frederick, 1796-1873. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2016138389
title: Frederick Vincent papers, 1776-1872.
context_snippets: Vincent lived in Norfolk, VA but spent a great deal of time in Washington, DC. He specialized in land and boundary disputes and had several important Washington correspondents. Included in the collection are court briefs, correspondence, and 18th century Va. land office records.

creator: Weintraub, E. Roy, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82029565 creator.
title: E. Roy Weintraub papers, 1930-2019.
context_snippets: The E. Roy Weintraub Papers document his career as a historian of economics and mathematics, and professor at Duke University. The collection comprises Weintraub's correspondence, writings, and research, providing an overview of his research and writings on the history of economics and role in the community of history of economics scholars. The collection also documents his communications with prominent economists as research subjects such as Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, and Lionel McKenzie. Included in Weintraub's communications are exchanges with prominent figures in the history of economics and related communities of scholars. Along with his own scholarship and writings, the collection documents Weintraub's roles at in the History of Economics Society, at Duke University, and as an editor of the journal History of Political Economy. Forms part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.

creator: Wake County (N.C.) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79005676
title: Wake County indentures, 1805-1838.
context_snippets: Collection comprises primarily land indentures in the county, one involves a ownership transfer made to trustees for the Soapstone Meetinghouse. There are also two powers of attorney, including one where Jesse Thorne, who was a resident of Greene County, Ala., acknowledges receipt of a slave named Daniel. Parties named in the document include Pleasant and Jesse Powell, [J]arratt M. [J]elks, Benjamin Carpenter, Simson Shaw, Peyton High, Willis Goodwin, Nathaniel Warren, Nancy Thomas, Henry Pullen, Joseph Jones, James Kelly, Caswell and Kessy Rains, John and Thomas Holloway, Turner Smith, Uriah Collens, William Ship, and David Delk.

creator: Wall, Alma Stikeleather.
title: Alma S. Wall Papers, 1905-1944.
context_snippets: Alma S. Wall placed her ill husband, Samuel Wall, in a sanitarium and traveled to New York, where she became known as a master of dialects, a singer of spirituals, and a storyteller. She was a great niece of Chief Justice John Marshall. The collection includes some of her writings, photographs of slaves, and photographs documenting the results of the 1926 Miami hurricane. Some correspondence concerns the mental illness of one of Wall's daughters. There are also certificates, a William Jennings Bryan speech, a scrapbook, and diaries belonging to Wall and her daughter.

creator: Wallace, Henry M.
title: Papers, 1912-1943.
context_snippets: Collection consists of telegrams and letters to Wallace, a prominent attorney and Democratic figure in Michigan who moved to Florida around 1936. Almost all of the correspondence is addressed to him; there are no outgoing letters. Included are telegrams and letters from Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., Franklin Delano Roosevelt, and other political figures.

creator: Willis, Bailey, 1857-1949. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n81120941
title: Bailey Willis papers, 1882-1896.
context_snippets: Collection consists mainly of letters Willis wrote to his wife but also includes letters to him and between other family members. They frequently wrote to one another in code; a key to the code is with the collection. His letters pertain to the Geological Survey as well as family, travels, the Appalachians and other prominent geologists such as Raphael Pumpelly. A few sketches are also included.

creator: Willis, Bailey, 1857-1949. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n81120941
title: Bailey Willis papers, 1882-1896.

They frequently wrote to one another in code; a key to the code is with the collection. His letters pertain to the Geological Survey as well as family, travels, the Appalachians and other prominent geologists such as Raphael Pumpelly. A few sketches are also included.

creator: Watson, E. H. Lacon (Edmund Henry Lacon), 1865-1948. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no88002844
title: Papers, 1895-1945, (bulk 1910-1919).
context_snippets: Chiefly letters to Watson's wife describing his life as a war correspondent. The 1918 letters discuss his days on the Italian front during WWI.

creator: McIver, William Hicks.
title: William Hicks and Marjorie Alma Tice McIver Papers, 1882-1974.
context_snippets: Collection includes postcards of various subjects such as architecture and humor. Correspondence to the McIvers (1944-1974) includes letters from congressmen and one letter from Governor Umstead of N.C. Correspondence subjects include federal aid for education, prayer in schools, Kennedy's tax proposal, and the Vietnam War. Other miscellaneous items include a vaccination certificate and a drumstick used by Lester Maddox as a show of force to keep blacks from eating in his restaurant. Other papers concern communism, urban renewal, UNICEF, separation of church and state, Catholicism, WWII rationing, socialism, 1964 presidential election and Niagara Falls.

creator: Conly, Richard T., Lt.
title: Papers, 1937-1953.
context_snippets: The bulk of this collection consists of copies of correspondence sent to an unnamed addressee from Conly in 1943 and 1944. A likely correspondent of Conly's is Norton R. Ganger, an officer in the Drum-Bugle Corps of Miami, active in the Florida State Veterans, the American Legion and the Boxing and Wrestling Board of Miami. Conly was in the North African theater but was later involved in the invasion of Italy. In 1943, his unit was moved there to serve as an umbrella over the U.S. Infantry. That same year he became ill with jaundice. Conly wrote mainly about his WWII experiences such as encounters with German planes, bombings and anti-aircraft fire. There are photographs of the Miami Drum-Bugle Corps; at least two of them show the Corps in France during the American Legion 1937 Foreign Pilgrimage which marked the 20th anniversary of the A.E.F. landing in Europe. Printed materials include a yearbook for 1944-45 of the Harvey W. Seeds Post, No. 29, American Legion, Dept. of Florida, printed by the Ganger Co., and a report of the Florida State Veterans Commission. Other materials include other correspondence to Conly's wife and father, clippings, and pictures.

creator: Powell, Paulus.
title: Papers, 1850-1851.
context_snippets: Papers primarily concern Virginia politics, including the Compromise of 1850, abolitionist resolutions in the Virginia House of Delegates and, candidates for political office.

creator: NULL
title: McKeen-Duren family papers, 1720-1945 and undated bulk 1855-1900.
context_snippets: Collection documents in great detail the histories of the McKeen and Duren families, particularly of Silas, Phebe, and Philena McKeen. Topics of note documented through correpondence, diaries and journals, other peronal papers, printed material, and images include: religious thought and institutions in New England; the education of women and the careers of female educators; photography throughout the 19th century; the Civil War and its effects on New England society; westward migration patterns; social life in Massachusetts and Vermont; family relations in the 19th century; 19th century New England women writers and their activities; tourism in 19th century England, Scotland, Switzerland, and Egypt; and New England genealogy. There are also many clippings in the scrapbooks debating the abolition of slavery, many written by minister Silas McKeen. The photographs series is large and offers many fine examples of 19th century portraiture and photographic processes, including ambrotypes, cyanotypes, daguerreotypes, tintypes, albumen prints, postcards, and early gelatin silver and platinum prints. The majority are portraits but there are also interiors of family rooms and images of educational institutions, especially Abbott Female Academy in Andover, Massachusetts (now Abbot Academy), whose principal over several decades was Philena McKeen. Three photograph albums round out the photograph series.

creator: Blount, H. P., creator.
title: H. P. Blount papers, 1881-1919.
context_snippets: Personal letters from H.P. Blount to his future wife, Loula Blount. Letters including a description (1881) of living conditions and child labor in Atlanta; a favorable recommendation from Judge T. Clarke of Mrs. Blount's singing ability (1884); H.P. Blount's election to the Georgia Historical Society; and a letter regarding the admission of Blount's daughter to the Athens State Normal College (1908).

creator: Price, Sally Caroline Geer.
title: Album, 1867-1872.
context_snippets: Collection is an album in which were copied poems, quotations, and other miscellaneous items, some written by notable authors. Some items were dated, but many pages were completely blank. One page notes events at the diocesan convention of the Episcopal Church meeting at St. James' Church, Wilmington, May 1867. The volume was published by J.C. Riker, N.W. and includes four engravings.

creator: Leech, David. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nb99078150
title: Papers, 1808-1875, (bulk 1822-1842).
context_snippets: Collection contains mainly correspondence of the Leech family, David and his two sons, Joseph Alexander and James. One letter, written from Matthew McDowel of Oh. to Mary Fullerton, also in Oh., discusses the many North Carolinians in Butler Co., Oh. as well the hardships of frontier life. Letters from Woodville, Miss., where James settled, talk of commodity prices, sicknesses, slaves, the 1822 election in Miss. and the hanging of two slaves. M.M.D. Lowry wrote to Leech in 1824 criticizing the doctrine of the New Lights and mentions the rage over tariffs. There are copies of the 1854 prospectus of the Kansas Free State. One letter briefly describes Columbia, S.C. before it was burned.

creator: Lemaire, Francois. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n89122892
title: Papers, 1714-1717.
context_snippets: Collection contains a memoir on Louisiana, 1717, and a letter written in Pensacola, 1714 describing La. and Fla. and the habits of different tribes of Indians.

creator: Le Vert, Octavia Walton, 1810-1877. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n88274012
title: Papers, 1862-1866.
context_snippets: Collection consists of social notes of an author and society personality. Also included are some personal letters from Gen. P.G.T. Beauregard mentioning his sorrow at the death of his wife, and his postwar life as a railroad president.

creator: Leverhulme, William Hesketh Lever, Viscount, 1851-1925. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n85052795
title: William Hesketh Leverhulme Solomon Islands photograph album, circa 1906-1910.
context_snippets: This bound photograph album belonging to Lord Leverhulme is entitled "Solomon Islands Views," and contains 98 black-and-white photographs, averaging 6x8 inches, that illustrate the beginnings of the Lever Brothers Pacific plantations operations from about 1906 to 1910. Images include company buildings, plantations at various stages of development, local inhabitants and dwellings, other cultivated crops, flora and fauna, and steamships. Among the place names listed are Rendova, Pepesala and Guadalcanal. Notable persons found among the images include the Resident Commissioner of the Islands at the time, missionary J.F. Goldie, and various Lever officers.

creator: Lewis, John.
title: John Lewis letter, 1796.
context_snippets: Lewis (d. 1823) was a Revolutionary War soldier, Presbyterian elder and friend to Andrew Jackson. The collection contains a letter to Lewis, dated November 9, 1796, from Robert James, Agent of the North American Land Co., outlining plans for a new road through the W.Va. mountains.

creator: Lewis, John.
title: John Lewis letter, 1796.
context_snippets: Revolutionary War officer.

creator: Lomax, Nannie.
title: Papers, 1846-1848.
context_snippets: Collection contains personal letters from Miss Lomax to her friend in Va. Miss Lomax had moved from Va. with her family to southern Ohio. She wrote about the friend becoming a more devout Catholic.

creator: Lomax, Nannie.

creator: Long, John W. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n87126201
title: Papers, 1834-1888.
context_snippets: Collection contains personal and business papers including a bill of sale for property from the estate of Rebecca Branson; a petition to protest radicals in Congress during the 1876 presidential elections; a diary describing farm activities; and a daybook.

creator: Lewis (Family : active 19th century : Me.) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2015064377
title: Papers, 1802-1852.
context_snippets: Collection contains letters to Lewis (1767-1839) from Alexander Wood, overseer of Audley Farm, Lewis' property in Battletown (now Berryville (Clarke Co.)), Va. The letters give details of the products of the farm and their prices, and note the sales of slaves. There are also letters to Lewis' son, Lorenzo.

creator: Fisher, Mary Wager, 1849-1932.
title: William Righter and Mary Wager Fisher Papers, 1830-1934 and undated.
context_snippets: The papers of William Righter Fisher and Mary Wager Fisher consist primarily of correspondence, but also include photographs (several of them tintypes and cartes-de-visite), financial papers, diaries, clippings, printed material, and writings and speeches. Among correspondents are many journalists, physicians, educators, and other notable figures of the late nineteenth century including Lucy Abbott, Mercy Baker, Jennie Chapin, Mary L. Booth, W.S. Burke, James Gowdy Clark, M.E. Dodge, Weston Flint, P. Girard, S. D. Harris, Albert Leffingwell, Henry C. Olney, W. Trickett, George Boyer Vashon, and Frank J. Webb. The collection also includes letters from James B. Hazelton of the First Regiment, New York Artillery. Hazelton's letters describe battles and political events of the Civil War, including Lincoln's re-election campaign and the anti-draft riots. The papers are particularly rich in documentation of women in medicine and women's medical education in the second half of the nineteenth century; the Freedmen's schools in the Reconstruction South; the movement for women's rights; and friendship among American women in the late Victorian era.

creator: Leckie, Andrew.
title: Account Book, 1774-1775.
context_snippets: Volume contains account receipts; a listing of people who owed Leckie money, including some prominent Virginia family names; a variety of other transactions; a note referring to the critical nature of the times; and entries for the tobacco trade. Bound within the volume is The Virginia Almanack for the Year of our Lord God 1774. Leckie was a merchant appointed to a committee charged to consider the general state of trade in the colony of Virginia.

creator: Lee, Philip Ludwell.
title: Ledger, 1743-1783.
context_snippets: Ledger documents accounts of food, merchandise, equipment, and other plantation supplies.

creator: Lee, Robert Harold. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no99043706
title: Letters, 1862.
context_snippets: Letters of a Confederate soldier to his wife.

creator: Lloyd, John.
title: Letters, 1811-1831.
context_snippets: Collection contains one letter from Thomas H. Drew to Lloyd concerning a property transaction. The other letter is a personal letter from Lloyd's wife, Anne.

creator: NULL
title: Lucas-Ashley family papers, 1830-1909.
context_snippets: Collection includes an 1830 document transferring ownership of a female slave; and report cards from Villeboro Female Seminary in Va. Letters in the collection discuss civilian life during the Civil War, reports of the burnings of Brandon and Jackson, Miss. by Union soldiers, activities of the S.C. 17th Regiment, and a description of student life at Greenville Military Academy in S.C., 1880.

creator: Beatty, Elie. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n94000693
title: Papers, 1816-1853.
context_snippets: Collection (42 items, dated 1826-1851) consists of Beatty's business correspondence. Addition (01-031) (296 items, dated 1816-1857) written to Beatty primarily from correspondents in Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia/West Virginia, and Washington D.C. The letters describe the economic struggles, especially during the 1830s-1840s, faced by Beatty's clients, who ranged from farmers to businessmen. Most letters shed light on business and banking practices and the conventions of business correspondence during the 19th century, including brief instructions or requests regarding the writers' loans or payments, as well as requests that Beatty intercede on the client's behalf with the bank's Board of Directors or provide assistance in dept collection. Other letters (01-031) are more detailed, describing the writers' lives and occupations; some letters discuss the slave trade and occupations such as shopkeeper and engineer. There are two letters from Maryland Representative and later U.S. Congressman John Tomson Mason, Jr., as well as a number of letters from a Virginia bank patron, Lauck and Stephen.

creator: Britt, George, 1895-1988. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no98084878
title: George W. H. Britt papers, 1942-1953, bulk 1942-1944.
context_snippets: Collection includes correspondence, memoranda, intelligence, and statistical reports, reminiscences, news clippings, photographs, and financial papers (primarily 1942-1944) from his employment by the U.S. Office of War Information, overseas office. Includes correspondence between Britt and the American ambassador in Turkey, Laurence A. Steinhardt. Contains legal papers, correspondence, and clippings relating to Karl and Stella von Kleczkowski; he was a German espionage agent in Turkey who defected to the Allied cause in 1943, and with his wife, fought extradition from the U.S. following the war.

creator: McCoy-Love (Family)
title: McCoy-Love family papers, 1774-1970.
context_snippets: Two prominent members of the families were George William McCoy, Sr. (b. 1901), editor of the Asheville-Citizen Times, and his father-in-law, Harry Weaver Love (b. 1883), YMCA executive. The collection contains personal and business correspondence, genealogical material, financial and legal records, printed material, clippings, addresses and writings, scrapbooks, miscellaneous items, photographs, and a number of volumes. Topics include the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, and the Thomas Wolfe Memorial Assoc. Harry Love's business papers include a large number of correspondence, reports, pictures and volumes relating to his work with the YMCA, in the U.S. and abroad. There are a sizable number of papers from Wythe Munford Peyton, a civil and highway engineer, who worked for several N.C. railroads; the papers of William C. Coleman, a businessman who sold and serviced Harley-Davidson motorcycles (1914-1915); and papers of the Frelinghuysen-Southwick family of N.J. and N.Y., one relative being a Senator and another, Emeline Sherman Smith, a poet. There are a few items concerning Thomas Dixon who founded the Mt. Mitchell Assoc. of Arts and Sciences.

creator: McCrea, Jessie Lou Draper.
title: Papers, 1861-1912.
context_snippets: Collection contains correspondence, legal and financial records, and other miscellaneous items. Most of the correspondence consists of letters by John S. Logan (d. 1866), a Union soldier in the 5th Indian Cavalry, to Miss Jessie Lou Draper and they relate his activities and camp life while on duty in Ind., Ky. Tenn., and Ga. Some materials relate to Captain Edward T. McCrea, whom Miss Draper married. Two letters are written to her from her grandson, Forrest Draper McCrea, later a Duke Uniersity faculty member.

creator: McCurdy, Harold Grier, 1909-1999. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n83125208
title: Harold Grier McCurdy Papers, 1918-2006.
context_snippets: Collection contains an unpublished manuscript of A PHOTOREALIST IN QUEST OF GOD by McCurdy. This work traces the artistic development of his son, John. Among the correspondence are letters between John and his parents, and diaries detailing the early lives of both John and his sister, Ann. Also included is an exhibition catalog of John's work (1977); an essay by John with publishers' responses; his doctoral dissertation; reprints of articles John wrote; original art work; legal papers, handwritten notes, printed material, yearbooks, course work, diplomas, correspondence; and slides and photographs. Other works by Harold McCurdy include BARBARA, THE UNCONSCIOUS AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF A CHILD GENIUS, and ABOUT MARY. Another group of materials include correspondence, clippings, articles, and other items relating to Harold McCurdy's writing, teaching, and publishing career. Addition (2000-0424) (8216 items, dating from 1918-1999) provides a relatively well-rounded and sometimes intimate look into McCurdy's personal and professional life over the majority of his lifetime. Materials include correspondence from and to McCurdy; writings on psychology, poetry, and drama; diaries; subject files; cartoons; and 254 color slides of paintings and other sketches and writings by McCurdy's son, John Derrickson McCurdy. Addition (2009-0021) (8 items; 0.2 lin. ft.; 1949-2006) consists of 6 bound notebooks and diaries kept by McCurdy. Some of the diaries appear to be sequential; other notebooks include clippings and writings. There is also an index of McCurdy's submissions (1949-1998), as well as a compilation of his poetry (2006).

creator: McCurdy, Harold Grier, 1909-1999. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n83125208
title: Harold Grier McCurdy Papers, 1918-2006.
context_snippets: Child psychologist and teacher, poet, professor at the University of North Carolina, and father of artist John McCurdy.

context_snippets: Pulliam led one of the more important slave-trading companies of Richmond, Va. These letters refer to the slave market and to the kind of action taken when a purchaser failed to make his payments.

creator: NULL
title: Jamaican Slavery Letters, 1777-1788.
context_snippets: Letter (1788) from John Roberts of Montego Bay to William Robertson of Old Palace Richmond concerning cotton and coffee crops and the sale of 10 slaves, including details of their price, the duty, primage, and "refreshment." Letter (1786) from John McLean of Kingston to Murdoch McLaine of Mull, discussing estate matters, the shipping to the French Islands of a slave woman, and the despatch of 2 puncheons of rum. Letter (1777) from Malcolm Laing in Jamaica to William Phillip Perrin of London discussing the boilers required for the sugar, the arrival of new slaves, the sale of sugar, the possibility of selling the estate, and the dismissal of an overseer due to harsh treatment of slaves.

context_snippets: Letters deal with a lawsuit arising from the sale of slaves held in trust by James Jones and the collection of a debt is discussed.

context_snippets: Collection contains papers concerning the purchase, sale, and transfer of slaves of the Rawls family and Ellen Rawls in particular.

context_snippets: Collection consists of a 216 page typescript copy of Reed's diary mainly concerned with work on his plantation. He comments on social events, visitors, slaves, war-time events, Reconstruction and a yellow fever epidemic.

creator: Reese, E. Y.
title: Letters, 1858-1861.
context_snippets: Collection contains letters written to the Rev. R.B. Thompson of Lynchburg, Va., concerning the business of the Methodist Protestant Church, hymn books, the attitude of the church on the question of slavery, the superannuate fund and Lynchburg College.

creator: Whitshed, J. H.
title: Logs of H.M.S. Imaum, Fisgard, Waterwitch, Sampson, Victory, 1850-1852.
context_snippets: Log book of various ships contains daily entries concerning weather and activities aboard ship.. Includes narrative account (with casualties) of the Lagos Expedition in November and December 1851 during which the author played an active part on H.M.S. WATERWITCH in an attempt to dethrone King Cocioco (who had refused to sign a treaty promising to suppress slave traffic and had forbidden access to British men-of-war) and to place his brother Akkati on the throne. Other sections include partial logs of H.M.S. IMAUM (Port Royal, Jamaica), H.M.S. FISGARD (Woolwich), and H.M. Steam Frigate SAMPSON (Lagos and Sierra Leone). Includes manuscript map of the entrance to Lagos Harbor.

creator: Hutchins, Samuel W.
title: Papers, 1869-1870 and n.d.
context_snippets: 2 diaries(1869 and 1870), each written in Self-Closing Diary for respective years, contain brief entries chiefly regarding Methodist Church and school activities. Author wrote about trips taken to surrounding countryside, and mentioned seeing President Grant with his wife. He also included notes about young women he escorted home from church and social functions, and in one diary included a "List of Ladies that I go home with." Other items include manuscript religious and romantic poetry, presumably by Hutchins, and a fragment of a letter by Hutchins admonishing the recipient for "tattling."

creator: Lucas (Family : Columbus, N.J.) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2020119777
title: Papers, 1813-1867 and n.d.
context_snippets: Correspondence, legal papers, and financial papers of the Lucas family of Raleigh, N.C. Early letters (1813-1816) were written by Alexander Lucas to his wife Mary while he visited Pennsylvania and Washington, D.C. Legal papers pertain to a lawsuit involving William Lucas, Henderson Lucas, and Margaret Lucas and concerning the estate and Revolutionary War military bounty of their grandfather, Thomas Lucas. A letter written to William Lucas from N. Davidson (1857) on an advertising sheet contains descriptions of inventions of 1857, including a counterfeit preventing machine for the printing of banknotes, a windmill, a pump, and a letter-copying press. Also included in the collection are letters (1861-1862) from Henderson Lucas of the 34th Regiment of N.C. Troops, Company G, to his sister Margaret. Lucas wrote from Camp Fisher near High Point, N.C., from Camp Davis near Wilmington, and from Hamilton's Crossing. Clippings include one describing Henderson Lucas' heroism at the battle of Gettysburg. Collection also includes a small account book (1821) in which Mary Lucas made a few brief entries.

creator: Ronan, Harriett Frances.
title: Letters, 1865.
context_snippets: Collection contains letters of Eugenia Carew, wife of Hamilton Carew, to her sister Harriett, and her mother, concerning the fate of South Carolinians at the end of the Civil War, the exchange of her husband who was a prisoner of war, financial problems, food, rationing, high prices, illness, and other family matters.

creator: Roney, Isaac.
title: Papers, 1819-1871.
context_snippets: Collection contains business and financial papers of Major Roney consisting chiefly of bills and receipts, including a physician's bill for attending a slave after childbirth. Also included are an inventory of the estate of Thomas and Rebecca Roney, 1823; and a rental contract (1866) between Roney and a tenant.

creator: Rooke, Giles, Sir, 1743-1808.
title: Letters, 1774-1775.
context_snippets: Collection contains correspondence of Rooke with members of the family of his wife, Harriet Sophia Burrard Rooke, concerning the political struggle between the Burrards and Sir Philip Jennings for control of the governing body of the borough of Lymington, Hampshire.

creator: Roosevelt, Eleanor, 1884-1962. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79144645
title: Papers, 1932-1948.
context_snippets: Reformer and wife of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

creator: Ritsmiller, The.
title: Letters, 1862.
context_snippets: Letters are from Ritsmiller and written to his wife, while he was on military duty in Missouri describing camp life and training routine at Benton Barracks, Saint Louis; and a march through southern Missouri.

creator: Rives, Georges. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no97082128
title: Letters, 1851-1883.
context_snippets: Sparta (Hancock Co.), Ga. lawyer and planter.

creator: Rives, Georges. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no97082128

creator: Richardson, William Abijah B., 1828-1891. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n98070052
title: Papers, 1869.
context_snippets: Collection consists of personal letters of Richardson and his wife, who, together, conducted a school in Wilson. One letter, comments on patent medicines and the proposed annexation of the Hawaiian Islands; another concerns the sale of turpentine in Wilmington, N.C. Included also is a printed circular concerning the school.

creator: Riddle, James N.
title: Papers 1851-1864.
context_snippets: Collection contains personal and family letters of Riddle concerning the death of his wife and his son, tension following John Brown's Raid (1859), and family and religious matters.

creator: Robertson, J. Barr (James Barr)
title: Papers, 1869-1881.
context_snippets: Collection contains letters written to Robertson, a shareholder and board member of several companies, including the Shanghai Steamship Navigation Co. and the Union Steamship Navigation Co. He also wrote journal articles about China and British policy. Six letters are from W.U. Lay from Japan, and are mainly concerned with Lay's proposals of forming a journal to represent British and American views on China and Japan. The name was to be Pacific Mail. The letters also discuss the Japan Times. Five letters are from Charles Wycliffe Goodwin, president of the North China Branch of the Asiatic Society and a British judge. One letter is from Edward Cunningham, chairman of the Shanghai Municipal Council. He discusses views of President Grant. Two letters from G.F.L. in N.J. discuss water supply and tunnel projects in New York city. A letter form T. Hanbury invites Robertson to his farewell party.

creator: Mauskopf, Seymour H. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80049928
title: Seymour Mauskopf papers, 1930-1990s.
context_snippets: Collection contains materials used in preparation for Mauskopf's book, The Elusive Science, co-authored with M.R. McVaugh. Included are audio cassettes, transcripts, and notes. Interviews are with J.B. and Louisa Rhine, B.F. Skinner, Gardner Murphy, J. Gaither Pratt, and other prominent psychologists. Five notebooks contain chiefly Mauskopf's notes on the council minutes of the Society for Psychical Research; and there is also a reel-to-reel tape of an interview with Mrs. K.M. Goldney. Addition (05-071) (2000 items, 1.6 lin. ft.; dated 1930-1978 and undated) includes miscellaneous correspondence, clippings, and printed material produced by and related to J.B. Rhine and the Parapsychology Laboratory, collected by Mauskopf and McVaugh for The Elusive Science. Includes 11 black-and-white photographs, as well as files of note cards indexing portions of the correspondence files in the Parapsychology Laboratory Records. The addition is open to researchers. Addition (11-193) (2200 items, 3.0 lin. ft.; dated 1930s-1990s) includes notes and research, including photocopies of primary documents, about the history of parapsychology and psychical research. The collection also contains some drafts or notes by Mauskopf about The Elusive Science, as well as other writings by him relating to the history of science. Also includes printed materials, miscellaneous correspondence, and articles by other historians, psychologists, and scientists. Addition (2012) (8 items, 0.1 lin. ft.; dated 1990-1992 and undated) contains a folder of materials for the Science, Technology and Human Values Program steering committee, with program brochures, a list of symposium topics and courses, and one set of Mauskopf's committee meeting notes along with his notes on the budget.

creator: Masters, George L.
title: Papers, 1861-1865.
context_snippets: Collection consists of correspondence between Masters, his relatives, and friends. Primarily they concern personal experiences during the Civil War. Topics include camp life, government war policy, slavery, the war's end, and religion. Masters claims that morale is high, but he felt disillusioned that the government's original cause of "Restoration" and the "unshackling of slavery" was being overshadowed by territorial fighting. He did feel that the war would end soon. At one point, Master's was severly wounded, causing considerable grief among his relatives and friends during his recovery. He was praised as "truly brave and devoted to the cause of his country... [a] superior soldier."

creator: Masters, George L.
title: Papers, 1861-1865.
context_snippets: Collection consists of correspondence between Masters, his relatives, and friends. Primarily they concern personal experiences during the Civil War. creator: Megahey family.
title: Papers, 1861-1877.
context_snippets: Collection contains three letters from T.C. Megahey to his family in Charlotte, N.C. He recounts events of a trip to Petersburg, Va., and writes of camp life. For one letter, the stationery is from the U.S. Sanitary Commission. The final item is an April Fool's rhyme sent to Miss Mary Megahey.

creator: Merrill, George Robert.
title: Papers, 1854-1919.
context_snippets: Collection includes correspondence, scrapbooks, and records pertaining to churches Merrill served in Michigan, Maine, Ohio, Minnesota, and Chicago. One scrapbook (1860s) contains many broadsides and programs for organizations at Amherst College, where Merrill was a student. Other items include two diaries, and typed copies with revisions of several essays. One of the diaries dates from 1866, when Merrill taught students recently freed from slavery.

creator: Metzerott, William Gustavus.
title: William Gustavus Metzerott papers, 1838-1889.
context_snippets: Collection contains business and personal papers, correspondence, and photographs of Metzerott who operated under the firm name, W.G. Metzerott & Co. Some material is in French, but most is in English or German. Metzerott writes to his wife in English. Also included are his will, passport, and information about the drive to establish the Garfield Memorial Hospital, headed by Gen. Sherman. Metzerott was on the board.

creator: Michaels family.
title: Papers, 1893-1971.
context_snippets: Collection contains Michaels' family memorabilia including printed materials, clippings about Durham, and photographs. One photo is of Miss Eunice Markham, and others show Durham High School's Class of 1906. Included is a ledger of A. Haley Michaels, a Durham druggist.

creator: McMannen (Family)
title: McMannen family papers, 1829-1975.
context_snippets: Collection contains an 1829 land survey for a tract of land near Greensboro; an undated newspaper advertisement for McMannen's "Tar Mixture," a medicine; receipts for John McMannen from the late 1800s; an undated poem memorializing the death of John and Ella's son Batop McMannen, age nine; clippings and typescript obituaries of McMannens and other Durham figures; two pages of a McMannen family record from a Bible; a small amount of family correspondence from the early 20th century, including a 1907 letter from Alice McMannen alerting her uncle of his brother's death; family photographs of John McMannen, his wife Ella, and their daughters, as well as some unidentified people; a spiral-bound history of the McMannen United Methodist church (1975); and some other miscellaneous newspaper clippings. John A. McMannen's report on the 6th Regiment of N.C. Infantry that appeared in the Hillsborough "Recorder" in October of 1861 is in this collection in typescript.

creator: Brooks, Eugene C. (Eugene Clyde), 1871-1947. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2010061024
title: Eugene Clyde Brooks papers, 1774-1971 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection contains letters, educational reports, original poems, papers relating to tobacco relief, education and agriculture; microfilm of Brooks' papers in the Department of Archives and History in Raleigh; telegrams; cards from Brooks to his wife from abroad; photographs; memorabilia; an itinerary of his trip with other agricultural experts to Europe; numerous writings, and addresses; extensive manuscripts for unpublished works, lecture notes, a scrapbook; an address by Supt. B.L. Smith of Greensboro Public Schools; a contract in manuscript drawn up in 1774 between citizens of Mecklenburg Co. and John Patterson, a school teacher, who was engaged to instruct there; a printed document concerning Judge Walter Clark, and other miscellaneous items. There is also a printed copy of the diary of Dr. J.F. Shaffner, Sr. and blueprints of the N.C. State Fairgrounds.

creator: Brown, Jacob Jennings.
title: Papers, 1814-1825.
context_snippets: Collection consists of two undated engravings of Brown, a letter, and a memorandum bound in pink ribbon. The letter is addressed to the Secretary of the Navy and was written in Brown's capacity as Commander. The full title of the memorandum booklet is "Memoranda of occurences and some important facts attending the Campaign on the Niagara." Brown narrates the events of the campaign. There are verified copies of major communications during the campaign, including messages from J.C. Calhoun, James Monroe, General Ripley, and others. Of special interest is a sort of appendix consisting of "An Estimate of the British Regular Troops in Upper Canada, July 1, 1814. With a view of their distribution." It is a detailed look at early nineteenth century military conflicts.

creator: Malone, Joseph J. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86142831
title: Joseph J. Malone papers, 1917-1982 (bulk 1970-1982).
context_snippets: Collection contains materials in these categories: correspondence, writings (by Malone and others), notes, miscellany, printed materials, picture, and volumes. Geographic and subject areas include General, Arab-Israeli conflict, Energy, Iran, Iran-Iraq conflict, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Middle East & oil, North Africa, OPEC, Saudi Arabia, Soviet Union & the Middle East, Syria, and Turkey.

creator: Malone, Joseph J. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86142831
title: Joseph J. Malone papers, 1917-1982 (bulk 1970-1982).
context_snippets: Middle East expert who taught at American University of Beirut and at the National College in Washington, D.C.

creator: Mangum, Hugh, 1877-1922, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2006129461 creator.
title: Hugh Mangum photographs, circa 1890-1922.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 937 glass plate negatives and printed black-and-white photographs taken by Hugh Mangum from about 1890 to 1922 as he traveled a rail circuit through North Carolina, Virginia, and West Virginia and in photography studios he and partners established in Durham, N.C., and Roanoke, Pulaski, and East Radford, Virginia. Localities known to have been visited by Mangum in N.C. include Winston-Salem, High Point, Raleigh, Reidsville, Lexington, Durham, and Greensboro; in Virginia, Christiansburg, Martinsville, East Radford, and Pulaski. The images are chiefly individual and group portraits of mostly unidentified women, children, and men, either in unidentified studio settings or outdoors. Most are white men and women, but there are also many African Americans and others who may be multi-racial. Hugh Mangum and his wife are present in several images. There are several street scenes identified as Radford, Virginia, as well as Warrenton (probably N.C.), and Christiansburg, Virginia. Some images feature houses, barns, mills, outdoor social gatherings, and animals. The last dated photograph in the collection is a mounted print of Mangum's body in an open casket, 1922. Of the photographic prints, there are 55 prints made from selected negatives, and 50 inkjet digital prints from a 2012 exhibit. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

creator: Marks, R. T.
title: Papers, 1839-1878.
context_snippets: Collection consists largely of bills and receipts. There are also some family letters from and to a Miss Jennie Irvin and James Stacy; and some papers relating to Oglethorpe College property.

creator: Martin, Thomas S. (Thomas Staples), 1847-1919. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n87870749
title: Papers, 1793-1926.
context_snippets: Collection contains primarily Martin's letters and papers, and those of the Poindexter, Clingman, Hunt, Smith and Roberts families. All of these families, at some point, lived in Yadkin or Surry Counties. Some of the letters are from Miss., and Mo. The letters are mostly concerned with family and local news. There are some Surry Co. land deeds. Many of the letters are written by Mrs. A.S. Martin, Thomas Martin's wife; she wrote to their sons in Mo. Their daughter Mary M. (Mollie) married L.G. Hunt and many of her letters are included.

creator: Bush, William H. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n98009881
title: Papers, 1853-1866 and n.d.
context_snippets: Collection consists of family correspondence, official army papers, five diaries, two account books, four tintypes, and seven photographs. Letters include some from Bush to his wife before and during the war. He wrote from Iowa in 1855 and commented on conditions there, and in 1865 describes his visit to Wahington City. In the diaries, Bush records daily activities and provides accounts of action at Winchester, Fisher's Hill, and Cedar Creek. Most events in the diaries took place in Virginia and West Virginia.

creator: Butler, M. C. (Matthew Calbraith), 1836-1909. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no94003296
title: Papers, 1851-1920.
context_snippets: Collection is primarily composed of Butler's personal and political correspondence. A few letters relate to his cousins in Louisiana. He sends detailed accounts of the war to his wife, Maria, daughter of S.C. Governor Pickens. Butler vividly describes battles, troop movements, and camp life. After the war, some correspondence deals with his Senate office, including his involvement in the Spanish evacuation of Cuba. Other papers concern his son's murder and legal matters. There are poems, genealogical materials, a 32-page memoir of Reconstruction in S.C. by Butler's daughter, plus an essay by her.

creator: Wynn-Robbins family.
title: Wynn-Robbins family papers, 1886 [and n.d.]
context_snippets: Collection contains a medical license of Dr. Thomas Palmer Wynn that was issued in New Bern, N.C., 1886; a clipping about Miss Pemberton's recital at the Southern Conservatory of Music; a photograph of Margaret S. Bathgate of New York (photographer: Aime Dupont, N.Y., N.Y.) that she autographed and sent to Mrs. Wynn and Miss Robbins; and a photograph of Miss Daisy Robbins (photographer: Jack Williams, Durham N.C.), sister of Mrs. Ahecta Wynn and Phillip Robbins, manager of the Ellis-Stone Store in Durham.

creator: NULL
title: Nettleton-Baldwin family papers, 1837-1868.
context_snippets: Collection contains letters, some written by Lewis J. Nettleton to his wife Charlotte (Baldwin) Nettleton. Some of his letters were written during the Civil War, while he was in the 15th regiment of Connecticut Volunteers. There are a number of letters between other family members, who comment on such things as John Brown's execution, the Vigilante Committee, Native Americans, Lincoln's assassination, and Yankee prejudice. Clippings are also included, some of which relate attitudes about slavery. Edwin B. Baldwin's and Lewis J. Nettleton's diaries are included. Edwin, a cousin of Charlotte, served in the U.S. forces and wrote about this experience. He discusses the ship, MERRIMAC, and how it was destroyed. Charlotte's brother, DeWitt Baldwin, also wrote to her. He was a Yale graduate and Union soldier, who later became a Wall St. lawyer. Julia Baldwin also wrote to Charlotte and one of her letters includes a recipe for a white cake.

creator: Minnigerode, Julia Hunt.
title: Julia Hunt and Mary Minnigerode diaries, 1907-1910.
context_snippets: Collection contains a two-volume diary kept by Miss Julia Hunt Minnigerode of her trip abroad, 1907-1910. The third volume is also a diary kept by her sister, Mary, on the same trip. They both refer to their parents and their brother being on the trip.

creator: Mitchell, Fannie Yarbrough.
title: Papers, 1934-1977.
context_snippets: Collection largely contains personal correspondence of Miss Mitchell. One correspondent was Mr. W.M. Upchurch, Jr., whom she succeeded at the Appointments Office. Other parts of the collection note her talent as a generous hostess, superb cook, and interesting personality.

creator: Moulton, Joseph Langdon. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n88600926
title: Papers, 1922-1986.
context_snippets: Collection chiefly contains correspondence and journals describing experiences Mouton had while a missionary. Clippings relate to his interest in the history of 20th century India, or his activities as a missionary in Ahmednagar, India. There are letters from Vijaya L. Pandit, a leading Indian diplomat.

creator: Morton, F. Knox.
title: Letters, 1837-1863.
context_snippets: Collection includes two letters addressed to Dr. Morton and two to Miss Lillie Morton in care of Dr. F. Knox Morton in Philadelphia. The fifth letter was written from the headquarters of the Medical Dept. of the 8th Regt. of Pa. Cavalry. One of Dr. Morton's letters is from E.B. Adams, reporting on his travels in Pa. Another is from James Hagan, announcing the death of E.B. Adams.

creator: NULL
title: Morton-Holladay family papers, 1848-1916.
context_snippets: Collection is largely letters written between various family members, especially, Lewis Littlepage Holladay and his wife, Nannie E. (Morton) Holladay. The earlier part of the collection is mainly letters written to her by cousins and possibly some friends. In the 1840s and 1850s, Nannie and her correspondents wrote of romance, marriage, and activities. Later letters were courtship letters written by Lewis to Nannie from Hampden-Sydney College, where he taught, and also letters he wrote while travelling on business. There is a letter from a cousin, Rick Morton, detailing experiences in Brazil. Other correspondents include another Hampden-Sydney colleague, Walter Blair; the Lewis' daughter, Littlepage (Pagie) who travelled to China; Dr. Waller Morton Holladay; and Charles S. Venable of the University of Virginia.

creator: Morris, Gilbert. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84029480
title: Gilbert Morris Papers, 1842-1926, (bulk 1888-1925).
context_snippets: Collection consists largely of letters written by Morris to Miss Delia S. Alexander, tracing their courtship over a period of five years. They were eventually married, despite her father's objections. Other correspondence includes that of W.H. Westall concerning Westall's business that Morris was taking care of; and George H. Strickland, concerning an estate sale. Other items include legal and financial papers, correspondence of Delia's father, B.J. Alexander; and Masonic materials.

creator: McParlin, T. A. (Thomas Andrew), 1825-1897. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n97802752
title: Papers, 1844-1933, (bulk 1871-1893).
context_snippets: Collection consists largely of correspondence between General McParlin and his wife, brother, and daughters. McParlin served as a surgeon with the army at posts in West Point, N.Y., Santa Fe, N.M., New York, N.Y., and Omaha, Neb. The letters deal chiefly with family matters, although social life and administration figure prominently. Also included are some remiscences and meditations on religious and political subjects, composed after his retirement.

creator: Ruff, Susan P.
title: Letters, 1835-1836.
context_snippets: Collection consists of two letters to Susan P. Ruff from her brother, Dr. Samuel W. Ruff, a U.S. Navy surgeon on the U.S.S. ST. LOUIS. He gives information on the attempts of the the Navy to halt the flow of slaves into the U.S.; problems in food supplies, sanitation and sickness aboard the ship; and the Seminole War.

creator: Russell, Daniel Lindsay.
title: Letters, 1872-1873.
context_snippets: Letters are from Russell to his overseer concerning cotton, corn, ditching, and laborers.

creator: Russell, Irwin, 1853-1879. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr91013833
title: Papers, 1877 [and n.d.]
context_snippets: Collection contains a letter from Russell in which he writes to his cousin about the Christmas holidays, about favorable treatment from his publisher, Scribner's, and about his attempt to start a paper. The second item is a manuscript of his poem "Nine Graves in Edinb'ro" with editor's blue marks. Russell is known as the pioneer in the use of African-American dialect for literary purposes.

creator: Rutledge, Archibald, 1883-1973. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50031762
title: Letter, 1939.
context_snippets: Collection consists of a personal letter from Rutledge describing his activities restoring his family home, Hampton Plantation, writing poetry, and hunting arrowheads.

creator: Rutledge, Harriet Horry, 1832-1912.
title: Letters, 1841.
context_snippets: Collection contains letters from Rutledge, as a nine year old child, to her mother, Rebecca Motte (Lowndes) Rutledge. She refers to her studies, Charleston gossip, and Madame Talvande, proprietress of a boarding school. Miss Rutledge later married St. Julien Ravenel.

context_snippets: Autograph book belonging to James Botteley (until 1924) then Charles Hart, containing the signatures of prominent English Methodists, and letters from notable Englishmen including Charles Darwin, Thomas Huxley, John Tyndall, and Robert William Dale.

creator: Gaffney family, creator.
title: Gaffney family papers, 1862-1866.
context_snippets: Collection consists of Civil War-era letters to the Gaffney family of Columbia, S.C., from friends and relatives. A letter (1862) written by P. Lemmons of the 12th South Carolina infantry (Gregg's Brigade) while he was at Camp Arsenal Green in Charleston, S.C., describes the stealing of a steamship, THE PLANTER, by a party of African Americans. Several letters were written by William W. Gaffney to his parents during the Civil War: one (1862 May 20) from Camp Jackson in Spottsylvania, Va., These describe the events of battles in Virginia and Pennsylvania. Two items deal with financial matters at Furman University.

creator: Arrow, Kenneth J. (Kenneth Joseph), 1921-2017. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79074306
title: Kenneth Arrow papers, 1921-2017.
context_snippets: The Kenneth Arrow Papers document his career as an economist, professor, and Nobel Laureate. The collection provides an overview of his many professional activities, along with his research, writings, and collected notes regarding topics such as microeconomics, contingent valuation, social choice theory, general equilibrium analysis, the economics of information, climate change, and endogenous-growth theories. The collection also documents his collaboration and communications with economists such as Frank Hahn, Leonid Hurwicz, Harold Hotelling, Alain Lewis, Lionel McKenzie, Roy Radner, Gerard Debreu, John Harsanyi, and many others. Along with his own scholarship and writings, the collection documents Arrow's role as an expert witness during various legal cases involving anti-trust lawsuits, international trade, and public utilities; his professional consulting work for different groups and organizations; his political activism supporting different human rights organizations, including his involvement in agencies promoting peace in the Middle East, environmental regulation, arms reduction, and nuclear testing bans; and his itineraries, lectures, and public engagements. The papers also document Arrow's leadership roles in the American Economic Association, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the Beijer Institute, the Econometric Society, the International Economics Association, the Office of Naval Research, the Institute of Medicine, the National Academy of Science, the National Bureau of Economic Research, and many more; and his activities for the Economics Departments of Stanford University, Harvard University, and the Santa Fe Institute. The collection also contains personal artifacts and documents from Arrow's childhood and early education; awards and honorary degrees; assorted books from his personal library; foreign editions of his published works; and born-digital records, chiefly email and writing drafts. Forms part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.

creator: Arrow, Kenneth J. (Kenneth Joseph), 1921-2017. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79074306
title: Kenneth Arrow papers, 1921-2017.
context_snippets: Economist, professor, and Nobel laureate. Arrow's career is especially distinguished by his contributions to the theory of social choice, including his book Social Choice and Individual Values, published in 1951, and his contributions to general equilibrium theory. For these achievements, Professor Arrow has been awarded the Johns Bates Clark Medal (1957) and the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics (1972), which he shared with Professor Sir John Hicks.

creator: Wilson, Sarah, Lady, -1929. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr92018781
title: Travel diary, 1920, Mar. 1-July 20.
context_snippets: Wife of Lt. Col. Gordon Chesney Wilson and one of the first women war correspondents. Aunt of Winston Churchill.

creator: Rhodes, James. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2001043807
title: Papers, 1849-1866.
context_snippets: Collection includes a contract between Rhodes and his former slaves, 1865, and financial papers. There is a volume with accounts of Rhodes and his partners, Joseph Borden, and A.M. Garber. It also shows Rhodes' personal accounts.

title: Papers, 1797-1902.
context_snippets: Collection contains an account book with entries for sales to the Quartz Gold Mining Co.; slave hiring; money lending; postmaster transactions of Killian's Post Office (N.C.); and agricultural accounts. Also included is Rhodes' exemption from Confederate military service.

creator: Richard-Henry. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82147323
title: Letter, 1858.
context_snippets: Collection consists of a letter to Richard, from William Edward Forster, responding to Richard's pamphlet about the Indian Mutiny.

context_snippets: Collection contains letters from a New Englander name "Yankee Tom," apparently intended for publication. They describe the seizure by Spanish authorities of a ship bringing 1100 slaves into the Caribbean.

creator: Laurens, Henry, 1724-1792. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79065949
title: Papers, 1777-1792.
context_snippets: Collection contains a letter to Laurens concerning the salary of his aide, Moses Young. A second letter is from Laurens' son, John, in the Revolutionary Army, requesting books on military strategy. Also included is a letter from Thomas Burke, William Sharpe, and Samuel Johnston asking Laurens to support their suggestion that the British Navy be attacked from the coast of N.C.

creator: Channing, William Ellery, 1780-1842, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79091268 creator.
title: William Ellery Channing papers, 1835-1846.
context_snippets: Collection contains a letter requesting money to dispense for a charitable purpose in Boston. The remaining material is Channing's sermon notes. One of the sermons, titled "The Aims of Life," criticizes wealthy slaveholders who occupy the best pews in church, whereas their slaves are much more in need of the Gospel.

creator: United States. Department of the Treasury. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n78096864
title: United States Department of the Treasury records, 1808-1918.
context_snippets: Correspondence, much of it from U.S. politicians, dating from 1808 to 1864; posters from 1918 urging U.S. citizens to purchase bonds and War Savings Stamps; and a bound volume of telegrams chiefly concerning ship movements and other military matters during the Civil War. Correspondents include Gabriel Duval of the Treasury, Horace Maynard of Tenn., Allan A. Hall of the Treasury, Albert G. Brown of Mississippi, Edward S. Philbrook, and John J. Crittenden of Kentucky. One letter of 1864 requests that medicine be shipped to a plantation on St. Helena Island.

creator: United States. War Department. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79084108
title: United States War Department records, 1814-1865.
context_snippets: A detailed list of a cavalry troop; a letter from Tenn. governor Willie Blount to Capt. James Cowan of the U.S. Rangers, concerning the Creek Wars in Tenn.; a letter from Mass. governor Caleb Strong to Adj. Gen. John Brooks referring to appointments to the War Dept.; four letters of recommendation, two of these directed to Joel R. Poinsett, then Secretary of War; a property document (1865) from the Freedmen's Bureau; and a grant of military bounty lands to a Mrs. Sarah Woolley.

creator: McConnell, R. A. (Robert A.) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n83013783
title: R. A. McConnell papers, 1944-2000.
context_snippets: Research materials in parapsychology spanning five decades; data and records from numerous parapsychology experiments (1947-1989); correspondence files, which include nearly all important researchers in parapsychology (1944-1996); and various printed materials, among which are several boxes of "psychic healing" literature and copies of many of his publications. Some papers document important criticism, disputes, and controversies in the field over several decades. The addition (1997-0084) (3500 items; 6.5 lin. ft.; 1951-1997) contains research records (many having to do with funding for projects) and correspondence. Also includes copies of many of McConnell's publications (often two copies of each). This addition also includes correspondence and McConnell's letters with the FLAS (Federation of American Scientists). The addition (2000-0274) (3 items; 0.2 lin. ft.; 2000) contains a copy of McConnell's book JOYRIDE TO INFINITY (2000), related items, and printouts of McConnell's website: www.ramcconnell.com. The addition (2000-0431) (8 items; 0.1 lin. ft.; 2000) includes statements and articles by McConnell summarizing his beliefs and positions on the existence of experimental phenomenon, the importance of parapsychology, and arguments against scientists who claim that parapsychological phenomena do not exist. This material can also be found on McConnell's website. The addition (2008-0290) (4500 items; 6 lin. ft.; 1953-1990s) consists largely of individual correspondence (organized alphabetically), committee materials, and committee correspondence.

creator: Upper Appomattox Company. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2020077994
title: Upper Appomattox Company records, 1803-1917.
context_snippets: Business correspondence and documents generated by the Upper Appomatox Company, which was empowered under Virginia law to cut canals, build locks and dams, engage in river transportation for trade, receive tolls, and lease or sell surplus river water. Until about 1900, it was one of the single most influential economic factors in the business life of Petersburg, Va. and environs. Includes deeds, contracts, indentures, land plots, financial papers, and reports of stockholders' meetings.

creator: Robeson, James A.
title: Papers, 1854-1864.
context_snippets: Collection contains correspondence relative to the estate of James J. McKay, for which Robeson (d. 1864) was administrator. The letters also discuss the transportation of McKay's freed slaves to Liberia, according to the provisions of his will.
