creator: Powell, Charles S., Mrs., 1836-
title: Mrs. Charles S. Powell journal, 1885-1887.
context_snippets: Wife of Charles S. Powell; mother of Charles, Harvey, Nellie, Ada, Lula, Bernice, and Maud; resident of Fair Oaks, Henrico County, Va.; and member of the Antioch Baptist Church.

creator: Barker, Hiram.
title: Hiram Barker papers, 1857-1895 and undated.
context_snippets: Prominent businessman and banker from Farmington, New Hampshire; established and managed multiple business investments in New Hampshire, the Dakota Territory, Florida, Iowa, Illinois, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, and Minnesota in the 19th century.

creator: Sligh, Clarissa T. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no93004398
title: Clarissa Sligh papers, 1950-2012.
context_snippets: Collection includes materials relating to Sligh's career as an artist, with particular focus on her various projects and exhibitions in the 1980s, 1990s, and early 2000s. Projects represented include Jake In Transition/Wrongly Bodied, Witness to Dissent/It Wasn't Little Rock, Coast to Coast, Sandy Ground, Malcolm X: Man, Ideal, Icon, What's Happening With Momma? and an NC Reunion/Slavery project, along with several others. Sligh's files frequently include correspondence, research materials, drafts of essays and exhibition plans, clippings and other source materials, contact sheets and slides, and occasionally exhibit pieces and texts from the actual installation. Other items included in the collection are exhibition binders and scrapbooks kept by Sligh to document her career; correspondence and communication between Sligh and other artists, galleries, or publishers; catalogs and publicity materials from Sligh's many exhibitions, shows, and publications, artists' books, materials documenting Sligh's art and process, large framed photogrphic prints; and other materials. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: United States. Army. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79063202 Colored Cavalry Regiment, 2nd (1863-1866)
title: United States Army 2nd Colored Cavalry Regiment orders and morning reports, 1864-1866.
context_snippets: The United States Army 2nd Colored Cavalry Regiment was organized at Fort Monroe, Va., on 22 December 1863. The regiment operated primarily in the Virginia theater and participated in the Richmond-Petersburg Campaign. It was sent to Texas in June 1865 for service on the Rio Grande and in other Texas locations until February 1866, when its members were mustered out.

creator: Powell, Richard J., 1953- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n87873944
title: Richard Powell papers, 1960-2011.
context_snippets: The Richard Powell Papers document Powell's career as a prominent scholar of African and African American art and professor of Art History at Duke University. The collection contains papers dated from 1960 to 2011, with the bulk of the material dated between 1975 and 2011. The collection includes documentation of Powell's student years, travels, research, correspondence, and work at various cultural institutions including Duke University, the Smithsonian American Art Museum, and the Washington Project for the Arts. The collection includes extensive materials on Powell's books, exhibitions, and other professional activities. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Mela Ram & Sons.
title: Mela Ram & Sons Waziristan campaign photograph album, 1919-1920.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a photograph album with 33 gelatin silver prints illustrating the British and Indian armies' Waziristan campaign of 1919-1920. Images are 8.5" x 11" (29) and 3.5"x11.25" (4); all containing captions pasted in, and all but two with number of the negative identified. Two panoramic views were folded for placement in the album. Images feature various military camps; local villages; Mackin before and after its destruction; Mashudi fighters and village leaders, including a jirga; and a group portrait of the General's staff. The studio's label is pasted onto the verso of the album cover. A boxlist accompanies the material.

creator: NULL
title: History of Medicine picture file, 1523-2002 and undated.
context_snippets: Assembled by the staff of the Duke University Medical Library, the History of Medicine Picture File holds thousands of small and large images organized into series for individuals, places, and subjects related to the history of medicine and medical practice. The great majority portray notable physicians, scientists, naturalists, philosophers, and other individuals with important links to medicine. Places featured include hospitals and other institutions of medicine, and scenes in specific locations related to events in medical history. The subject categories cover many topics, with the largest groups including advertising, anatomy, caricatures, cartoons, pediatrics, physicians, and surgery. Predominant formats are engravings, lithographs, print materials (such as posters, clippings, and postcards), and many modern photographic reproductions of older works; there are also albumen photographs, negatives, slide reproductions, and other image formats found throughout the files. Languages other than English include French, German, Italian, Dutch, and Latin. Aquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: Walker, Simeon.
title: Simeon Walker journal, 1853-1878.
context_snippets: Collection comprises Simeon Walker's journal, which has three parts. The first details a wagon trip Walker took from Illinois to Texas in 1853 that included travel through Missouri, Arkansas, and Louisiana. The purpose of the trip is unclear, and Walker's approach is straightforward and factual. He commonly notes counties, geographic features, weather, the state of the soil and crops grown, as well as the religious denominations in the areas he passes through. While traveling in Arkansas he comments on a tour of Arkansas Women's College, and notes his "great satisfaction as well as surprise to learn" that a fine and imprisonment were penalties for selling liquor to Native Americans (9 December). The second section, dated 24 July 1863-26 Feb 1864, contains Walker's entries made during the Civil War. He was against the "wicked rebellion," and found Biblical symbolism in the fighting, especially as it reflected God's judgment on the Rebels. He visited African American churches, supported former slaves' service in the Union Army, and noted violations of their rights, including indignities and beatings they suffered from other soldiers. He also chronicles stealing and killing by troops, hospital conditions, capture of prisoners, and camp discipline. There is description of the battle at Vicksburg and day-to-day events in the Western theater of the war. In the final journal segment Walker records his autobiography, covering his birth in 1802 to 1878, the year he begins writing. He describes the life his family led as pioneers, including their interactions with Native Americans, and outlines the family's roots and traditions, as well as the details of geographic features, flora, and fauna of their settlement in Illinois. Item is in fragile condition.

creator: Schuman, Henry. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2005062273
title: Henry and Ida Schuman papers, 1920-1997 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection consists chiefly of card indexes representing the medical history rare book and manuscript inventory that Henry and his wife Ida Schuman assembled and managed as part of their antiquarian book business. The cards were very likely used to assemble the dealer catalogs published by the Schumans. Many of the cards record purchases and other transactions, and which institution acquired the item. The larger card file consists of 15 boxes and is alphabetically organized by author or title. Smaller cardfiles exist for mathematical works and other unidentified divisions. There are also several boxes of the Schumans' business and professional papers, including several folders of correspondence between the Schumans and their clients, including Dr. Josiah Trent of Duke University, and bills of sale for rare books and manuscripts. After her husband's death in 1962, Ida Schuman carried on with the business until her death in 1977. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: Bourne, Samuel, 1834-1912. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82235787
title: Samuel Bourne photographs, circa 1861-circa 1889.
context_snippets: Collection consists of 19th century albumen photographs taken by commercial photographer Samuel Bourne and other partners as they traveled to sites in modern-day India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Burma. Of the 546 prints in the collection, 200 are mounted in three large commercial photograph albums while the remaining 346 are single, loose prints; all were published by the firm Bourne & Shepherd. The majority of the prints range in size from roughly 6x9 to 10x12 inches. Subjects include the vast landscapes of nothern India; landmarks such as temples, rivers and canals, monuments, mountain hostels, and European-built cathedrals and civic structures; rural scenes from villages and tea plantations; and scenes from the cities of Delhi, Bombay (Mumbai), and Calcutta (Kolkata). Almost every print features a few human figures, carefully posed for scale or atmosphere. There are also several dozen ethnic portraits of native inhabitants. A number of images have been attributed to Bourne's partners Charles Shepherd and Colin Murray.

creator: NULL
title: Recueils. Affaires Diverses du 18e Siecle, Particulierement de Celles de Dauphine, circa 1770-1790.
context_snippets: Manuscript volume includes thirty-two articles of varying lengths relating mostly to the political, economic, social, and ecclesiastical history of the French province of Dauphine during the eighteenth century. No authors are given for any of the writings. The volume probably dates from the decade before the outbreak of the revolutions. Topics of the articles include: the boundary between Dauphine and Sardinia; the government of Geneva in 1733; extracts from the registers of the Council of State about certain ecclesiastical matters; the boundaries of Dauphine; methods of teaching at the University of Paris; population, emigration, and the Huguenots; the condition and productivity of Valence, Montelimar, Crest, and Die; commerce, silk and textile production; meat production; a history of fiefs; a petition from the nobles to the King, 1770; Princess Charlotte of Brunswick-Wolfenbuttel, wife of the Russian Tsarevich Alexius Petrovich; affairs concerning the parliament of Dauphine; and other matters.

creator: National Coalition for Haitian Rights (United States), http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2009096889 creator.
title: National Coalition for Haitian Rights records, 1968-2008, bulk 1982-2004.
context_snippets: The NCHR records span the years 1982 to 2004 and contain the organization's administrative records, program and project files, legal files, extensive subject files, as well as a large collection of print materials. NCHR maintained offices in New York City and in Port-au-Prince. The files in the NCHR records are largely those of the New York office, but there is also extensive overlap with the activities and files of the Haiti office. Key Haiti activities documented include human rights training, monitoring and reporting, judicial and penitentiary reform, Haitian National Police monitoring, and returning refugee monitoring and advocacy. Key US activities documented include Haitian community development, promoting and protecting rights of Haitian immigrants, promoting naturalization and citizenship, and educating Haitians on government services and citizenship. The Administrative series documents the management and day-to-day operations of NCHR. These files include organizational planning, board of directors, development, and operational files. The Program and Projects series contains the files produced by NCHR's major programmatic work: The Community Action Program (CAP), the Haitian-American Community Action Network (HACAN), Legal Education and Assistance Project (LEAP), and Restavek. The Legal series contains files related to NCHR's work on broad legal cases effecting US immigration policy and human rights accountability in Haiti, as well as legal support NCHR provided to individuals, largely related to immigration and asylum in the US. The William O'Neill Files series documents O'Neill's work for NCHR, primarily related to the United Nations mission to Haiti. The Subject Files series is the largest series in the collection, documenting a wide variety of NCHR's work in Haiti, the US, and the Caribbean. Important sections include Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haitian migrant workers in the Bahamas and the Dominican Republic, "Boat People" and interdiction, elections in Haiti, Guantanamo and Krome detention centers, and police reform. The Subject Files series may overlap with many of the other series in the collection. The Print Material series contains an extensive collection of reports, newsletters, bulletins, and other publications primarily concerning human rights and Haitians. These materials compliment the other series in this collection, particularly the Subject Files. The Audiovisual series contains videos, photos, and audiotapes documenting NCHR's work. Key figures documented in the collection include Prosper Avril, Anthony J. Bevilacqua, Anne Fuller, Michael S. Hooper, Jocelyn McCalla, and Bayard Rustin. Organizations covered include Caribbean Rights, Haitian Center for Human Rights, Komite National du Kongres des Mouvements Democratiques, and Ligue des Anciens Prisonniers Politiques Haitiens. Additional topics include HIV and AIDS, migrant labor, and judicial corruption.

creator: Deen Dayal, Raja, 1844-1905. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79141503
title: Raja Deen Dayal photographs of India, 1870s-1905.
context_snippets: Indian-born professional photographer active in the last half of the 19th century; died in 1905.

creator: Reis, Ronald E., 1936?-2014, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2016137446 photographer.
title: Ronald Reis photographs, 1954-2014 and undated.
context_snippets: The images in this collection were taken by photographer Ron Reis from the 1950s to 1979 and from 2004 to 2014. The earlier body of work (1962-1974) contains 289 black-and-white photographs typically measuring 11x14 inches, accompanied by negatives and contact sheets. The later body of work (2004-2014) contains 3,719 black-and-white and color laser inkjet prints, chiefly measuring 11x17 inches, with a majority dating from 2012 to 2013. Reis focused his camera on street scenes primarily in New York and New England, but also in Colorado and the midwest. He also traveled to Europe (Italy, England, Ireland, and Greece), and to the Middle East. His images capture anti-war demonstrations, feminist and gay pride parades, and ethnic festivals from the 1960s to the 2000s in cities such as New Haven and New York City. At the same time he also documented the more quotidian life of urban neighborhoods, street markets, and other public spaces such as Speakers' Corner in London's Hyde Park and New York City's Washington Square. The collection includes manuscript and printed materials such as curriculum vitae, some correspondence, exhibition publicity, articles, and photo essays. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

creator: Danckelman & Schrader Company.
title: Danckelman & Schrader Company cigarette card album de figuritas "Londres," between 1900 and 1910.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a folio album holding 978 gelatin silver prints (2.25" x 1.75") of cigarette trading cards produced by the company, all mounted on album leaves, many hand-colored. Contains a near-complete run of Series 1-42 produced by the company. The vast majority of the images depict bullfighters and beauties; other categories include children, costumes, and posed scenes. Contains the ownership mark of Elena Brito MacEachen and a child, Lucy, who used pages of the volume to practice her cursive writing strokes.

creator: Northfield Seminary for Young Ladies. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n88159866
title: Photographs of women's college production of a Sanskrit drama, circa 1905.
context_snippets: Group of 62 captioned black-and-white photographic prints mounted on 14 cardstock boards, documenting an elaborate stage production of a well-known classical Sanskrit drama, the Sakuntala. The play was probably produced at the Northfield Seminary for Young Ladies in Northfield, Massachusetts around 1905, at a time when Indian dramas were popularized and produced by many women's colleges. The photographs are mounted on the rectos and versos of the cardstock boards, and portray individual young female actors playing male and female roles, as well as tableaus with multiple actors. The images capture the actors' vivid expressions and gestures, and detailed Oriental costumes and props. Most of the handwritten ink captions name the characters depicted, and many also list quotes from the particular act or scene. One image features a view of Northfield Seminary from across the Connecticut River. The images range in size from range in size from 5.5 x 3.75" to 8 x 13.75", with the mounts measuring 9x14". Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture at Duke University.

creator: Stevenson John (John Alun)
title: John Stevenson Papers 1947-1983 and undated.
context_snippets: Pioneer in direct mail, director of Greystone Press which specialized in subscription encyclopedias and continuity series books.

creator: Barbelle, 1888-1957. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2003006949
title: Albert W. Barbelle Illustrated Sheet Music Collection, circa 1915-1955.
context_snippets: Collection of American popular music from first half of twentieth century, whose cover art was created by artist Albert W. Barbelle. Issues referred to by cover art and lyrics include World War I and II, romance and courtship, immigration and racial identity, and travel.

creator: Couper (Family)
title: Altama plantation and Couper family photographs and reunion scrapbook, 1900-1940.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 33 gelatin silver photographs and 16 manuscript items. There are 24 photographs of Couper family members, all but two unidentified. In addition, there are pages from a scrapbook documenting a family reunion held in 1940 at the invitation of Cator Woolford, who was owner of the plantation at that time. Scrapbook photographs from the event are captioned and include views of the front and rear of Altama House along with the lawns and landscaping, and recently-completed Playhouse; several Couper family group photographs; as well as images of a vocal performance by the Hopeton plantation slaves' descendants, led by Deaconess Anna E.B. Alexander (the first African American to be ordained in the Episcopal Church), with their white audience listening. Manuscript items in the scrapbook include the family reunion invitation, guests invited, the event program, a biographical sketch of James Hamilton Couper, toasts made at dinner, a list of Couper family officers, and a newspaper clipping containing coverage of the reunion. Acquired are part of the George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana.

creator: Couper (Family)
title: Altama plantation and Couper family photographs and reunion scrapbook, 1900-1940.
context_snippets: The Couper family includes descendents of James Hamilton Couper (1794-1866), a planter who acquired his wife's interest in Hopeton Plantation, on the Altamaha River near Brunswick, Georgia, around 1827. In 1857 he and his wife occupied their new home there, which they called "Altama." Their slaves numbered up to 1500.

creator: Couper (Family)
title: Altama plantation and Couper family photographs and reunion scrapbook, 1900-1940.
context_snippets: The Couper family includes descendents of James Hamilton Couper (1794-1866), a planter who acquired his wife's interest in Hopeton Plantation, on the Altamaha River near Brunswick, Georgia, around 1827. In 1857 he and his wife occupied their new home there, which they called "Altama." Their slaves numbered up to 1500.

creator: Bastian, H. Charlton. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n83237219
title: Henry Charlton Bastian papers, 1841-1932 and undated.
context_snippets: The collection documents Bastian's rise as a neuroscientist, biologist, writer, and reseacher, and encompasses typed and manuscript letters to and from Bastian, research notes and writings, scientific photographs, ink and pencil drawings, and professional reviews and accolades. The largest series contains correspondence between Bastian and other prominent scientists, neurologists, scholars, publishers, assistants, and friends, including Louis Pasteur, Caleb Saleeby, Thomas Huxley, Sir John Bretland Farmer, Aristide Pratelle, and William Paton Ker, among many others. There are also exchanges with the Academie des Sciences in France. The correspondence usually concerns Bastian's research projects and publishing activities, particularly his work on abiogenesis, but also on paralysis. Other materials are more personal, and include obituaries, condolences, Christmas cards, and newspaper clippings. The collection also contains numerous pieces of correspondence addressed to Bastian's daughter, Sybil Bastian, who was also a scientist, and Bastian's wife Julia. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: Bryn, Doris.
title: Doris Bryn Papers, 1939-1998 and undated.
context_snippets: Doris Bryn (nee Krehnbrink) was a prominent fashion and cover model during the 1940s-1960s and co-designer of several lines of fashion accessories with her husband Roger Vsn Schoyck under the brand names Roger Van S. and Mr. R.

creator: Priest, James M., approximately 1816-1883. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n95068308
title: James M. Priest letter, cover, and newspaper, 1837-1844.
context_snippets: Collection comprises an issue of the Christian Intelligencer newspaper (New York, Saturday, 14 October 1837) that contains a letter from Priest requesting monetary support for his return to the United States and for his studies. There is also a 6-pg. letter from Priest to Walter Lowrie, former United States Senator and Corresponding Secretary of the Board of Missions, 12 October 1844, in which he questions whether the Board of Foreign Missions intends to provide monetary, material, and political support for his ministry equal to that they would provide a white man. He wonders how much of his concerns are in fact miscommunications with the Board, but stresses that he will not retain his authority with the natives if a white missionary is sent to his area and given more power. He points out that his wife has just given birth to twin boys, so now the family requires more support. Other topics include house-building supplies, crops, and the sale of a horse. Includes the letter's cover. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Priest, James M., approximately 1816-1883. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n95068308
title: James M. Priest letter, cover, and newspaper, 1837-1844.
context_snippets: James M. Priest was born ca. 1816 in Paris, Ky.; he died in 1883. He was a Kentucky slave who was given a theological education in Indiana by the religious woman who owned him. He was then freed to go to Liberia in 1835 with his wife, who was also a freed slave. In 1843 they moved permanently to Liberia, where he served as Presbyterian missionary in King Will's Town, and later Greenville. He became the Liberian vice-president, 1864-1868; and then associate justice of the Liberian Supreme Court.

creator: Jackson, Kate. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nb99178852
title: Kate Brigham Jackson letters, 1911, 1926.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 14 typescript copies of letters (84 pages) Kate Brigham Jackson wrote to her sister Nancy "Nannie" Gates Pratt in Savannah, Georgia, during two trips Jackson made with her husband; the first to India, Pakistan, and Cairo in 1911, the second to India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Persia (Iran) in 1926. Her descriptions of their travels are detailed, and often provide a distinctly female perspective on events. There are accounts of her husband's lectures; meetings with members of the Parsee community (Mr. Jackson was accorded celebrity status by the Parsees); descriptions of Zoroastrian ceremonies for marriage, burial, and navjote; and their attendance at commencement ceremonies, charitable events, and exhibitions. She describes her servants and their families in great detail, often comparing them to African Americans who would have served her in the South, and outlines their travel by steamer, train, camel, and car, with in-depth discussion of the "discomfort, even primitiveness," of travel in Iran. She comments on the lack of racial mixing and the impact of British rule in India, shopping, dancing and balls, women who smoke, and schools for girls in Iran. The couple socialized and visited with English governmental representatives, the Gaekwar of Baroda, Dr. Maneckji Dhalla, and Lady Ratan Tata. Among the sites they visited were the Taj Mahal, the caves of Ajanta, and the Golden Temple. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Jackson, Kate. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nb99178852
title: Kate Brigham Jackson letters, 1911, 1926.
context_snippets: Kate Jackson was born Kate O'Brien Brigham in 1870 in Savannah, Georgia. She was well educated, studied at the Sorbonne, and was a member of the American Oriental Society. She translated from French to English a book on Persian poetry by James Darmesteter. In 1911, she became the second wife of Abraham Valentine Williams Jackson, who was a pioneer of Iranian studies in America and professor of Indo-Iranian languages at Columbia University.

title: Lectures on the Theory and Practice of Medicine, circa 1850.
context_snippets: Mitchell was a notable physician and educator teaching at Jeffereson Medical College in Philadelphia. Fitts was an Alabamian physician educated in Philadelphia and practicing in Carroll County, Mississippi in the mid-19th century.

creator: Rush, Benjamin, 1746-1813. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50000649

creator: Hanaoka, Seishu, 1760-1835. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n88091783
title: Notes from lectures of Seishu Hanaoka, circa 1802-1806.
context_snippets: Bound manuscript written in Japanese script by a student known only as "Kamon," containing notes on medical procedures conducted by physician Seishu Hanaoka, including extirpation of breast tumors and anesthesiology. Includes 16 hand-colored drawings of breast tumors and surgeries, including illustrations of instruments.

creator: Hanaoka, Seishu, 1760-1835. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n88091783
title: Notes from lectures of Seishu Hanaoka, circa 1802-1806.
context_snippets: Hanaoka was a notable surgeon from Japan, active in the late 17th cent.-early 18th cent. Kamon was a student of Seishu Hanaoka.

creator: United States. Congress. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79006865
title: Letters and memos from the U.S. House and Senate, 1965-1977.
context_snippets: Bound volume of typed correspondence from members of the U.S. House and Senate consisting of inquiries sent to physicians by congressmen requesting expert medical opinion on legislative or constituent concerns.

creator: Griggs, Lee, 1790-1831.
title: Lee Griggs physician's ledger, 1823-1831.
context_snippets: Bound manuscript ledger containing receipts of payment, payments due, and other records of transactions. Includes entries referring to patients, among them slaves, whose names and treatments are recorded.

creator: Russell, James A., 1807-1864.
title: Physician's account book, 1839-1847.
context_snippets: North Carolinian physician who practiced in Tally Ho, Granvile County, North Carolina in the mid-19th century. In an 1851-1852 directory he is also listed as a physician in Tar River, Granville County. An 1860 slave census indicates that he owned 12 slaves in Ledge of Rock, N.C.

creator: Physick, Philip Syng, 1768-1837. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84027159
title: Lectures on surgery by Philip S. Physick and John S. Dorsey, 1811-1812.
context_snippets: Philip Syng Physick was a noted surgeon on staff at Pennsylvania Hospital and professor of medicine at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia; dubbed "The Father of American Surgery." John Syng Dorsey was also an American-born physician; in 1804 he returned from studies in London to assist Physick at the new Pennsylvania Hospital, and also became a professor at the University of Pennsylvania. He died of typhus in 1818.

creator: Rent, Steven.
title: Steven Rent photograph album, 1927-1948.
context_snippets: Steven Rent was a Staff Sergeant in the U.S. Eighth Army Division that provided forces for the occupation of Japan at the end of World War II. He was a resident of New York City, where he lived with his wife, Helen (Bado), and their daughter, Norma.

creator: Helfand, William H. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82134328
title: William H. Helfand collection of medical prints and posters, 1695-1991, bulk 1800-1899.
context_snippets: The William H. Helfand Medical Prints and Posters collection consists of 34 medical prints and posters dating from 1695 to 1991, with the bulk of the prints dating from 19th century. Paris is the provenance for many of the posters, but several hail from London and America. The posters are represented in two formats: lithographs and engravings, some of which are hand colored. Ranging in size from 5"x8" to 19"x23", the prints include caricatures, political satire, comics and advertisements, dealing with a range of subjects from quacks, alchemy, charlatans and cheats to pastoral and hospital scenes. George Cruikshank and Honore Daumier are represented amongst the artists. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: Bland, Eunice Andrews Smith, 1928-
title: Loy Connell Smith and Eunice Andrews Smith Bland papers, 1958-1999.
context_snippets: Dr. Loy Connell Smith (1925-1968) and his wife, Eunice Andrews Smith (b. 1928), were Southern Baptist missionaries to Nigeria from 1959 through 1968.

creator: Pope, John W. E.
title: John W. E. Pope papers, 1910-1957.
context_snippets: Collection includes family correspondence between Pope, his wife, and extended family, reporting on local news and family health. There is a small amount of financial materials, including receipts, insurance policies, unemployment statements, and other documentation about the Popes' finances. Also includes some official correspondence between Pope and the National Fraternal Society of the Deaf from the 1930s.

creator: NULL
title: Lettres Philosophiques..., 1771.
context_snippets: Collection comprises the manuscript volume Lettres Philosophiques, Critiques, Historiques, Nouvelles, et galantes, sur la Liberte d'aimer; Entre un frere et une seur [sic], dont l'une est A Paris, et l'autre qui voyage dans Different pays de l'Europe. Premiere Edition, avec figure. Dediee a la plus Belle et la plus vertueuse femme de l'univers. "A Cithere" [?Paris], 1771. (pp. [ix],6, [6], 109, the final 3 pages blank, including 4 full-page gouache illustrations, and several coloured borders and tailpieces). The manuscript is an unpublished libertine and utopian conte philosophique in the form of an illustrated correspondence, ostensibly between a brother and sister, on the subject of "La liberte d'aimer" (freedom to love). The anonymous author, unidentifiable from the initials subscribed to the dedication, follows Voltaire's recently-published LA PRINCESSE DE BABYLONE (1768), by presenting the correspondence as letters home from a young man travelling the world, from Paris, Copenhagen, London, Japan, China, North America, and India, presenting his impressions on their respective customs and beliefs. His interest is in relations between men and women, the pursuit of erotic pleasure ("Volupte") and varieties of partnerships and marriage. Beginning with an "Apologia du beaux sex," the author sets out his desire to celebrate the perfection of the female sex: "De tous les etres, je n'en conoius point de plus parfait que la femme." He refers to a "livre infernal" by Jacques Olivier, presumably the violently anti-feminist ALPHABET DE l'IMPERFECTION ET MALICE DES FEMMES (1617 and frequently reprinted) and declares that where that book was dedicated to the intrinsic badness of women, his Is to be devoted to their good. His first point of call is Constantinople, which yields a breathless letter on the beauty, desirability and availability of women there, comparing the ease with which erotic pleasure is found in comparison to Paris. Journeying on to Peking he makes a brief stop in London, allowing himself a few comments on English culture and society, noting in passing Pope's "poeme sur la Bouche de Cheveux" [The Dunciad] and the work of Newton. He spends some time in Japan with the Formosans and then continues to North America. From Canada he describes the Iroquois, Illinois, Algonquins, and Hurons and the simplicity with which a man chooses a wife: "...sans plus ceremonie que cet machine mecanique de Descartes, il partage avec elle que son coeur aime, les plaisirs d'une volubte [sic] si parfaites, qu'il est imposible a ma plume de pouvoir l'exprimer.." The brother's final account describes the people of the Gangarides (a mythical land on the eastern bank of the Indian Ganges), shows the strongest debt to Voltaire's work. It is after this letter that the sister announces to him the birth of her son, asking that he be a guide to the infant, teaching him the philosophies of the age just as Rousseau had for done Emile. The four illustrations depict the author in his study, pen in hand; a Turkish beauty; a virtuous European woman; and lovers on the banks of the Ganges (with a unicorn emerging from the virgin forest).

creator: Jansen, Thomas. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n83180481
title: Thomas Jansen last will and testament, 1796 December 29.
context_snippets: Collection comprises the 7-page will of Thomas Jansen, who made provisions for his children and heirs. He divided among his children and grandchildren several slaves, along with furniture, livestock, money, and land. Includes revisions to the document. Witnessed by Jeremiah Decker, Jesse Mack, and John[son?] Bruyn. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: NULL
title: Sherard Plantation tenant farmer appreciation ceremony scrapbook, 1937-1950.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a bound volume (70 pages, 9x11.5-inches) entitled, "Appreciation Ceremony: Sherard Plantation Negroes Gather to Honor Owners, April 30, 1950, Sherard, Mississippi." The volume serves as a scrapbook, and holds 35 black-and-white and 3 color photographs and photocopies that are reproductions of photographs, often with captions; letters; newspaper and magazine articles; reminiscences; and songs that document the history of the Sherard plantation, the celebratory event, and the national press coverage it received. The materials date between 1937 and 1950. For their part in making improvements on the estate, including churches, a post office, a railway station, and a school, honorees for the day included J. Holmes Sherard, part owner and manager of the estate, and his sister, Mallie Sherard Rawles. There were over 600 tenants in attendance. The first John Holmes Sherard established the 6000-acre plantation in 1874 when he moved from Alabama with supplies and many of his family's former slaves. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: NULL
title: Sherard Plantation tenant farmer appreciation ceremony scrapbook, 1937-1950.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a bound volume (70 pages, 9x11.5-inches) entitled, "Appreciation Ceremony: Sherard Plantation Negroes Gather to Honor Owners, April 30, 1950, Sherard, Mississippi." The volume serves as a scrapbook, and holds 35 black-and-white and 3 color photographs and photocopies that are reproductions of photographs, often with captions; letters; newspaper and magazine articles; reminiscences; and songs that document the history of the Sherard plantation, the celebratory event, and the national press coverage it received. The materials date between 1937 and 1950. For their part in making improvements on the estate, including churches, a post office, a railway station, and a school, honorees for the day included J. Holmes Sherard, part owner and manager of the estate, and his sister, Mallie Sherard Rawles. There were over 600 tenants in attendance. The first John Holmes Sherard established the 6000-acre plantation in 1874 when he moved from Alabama with supplies and many of his family's former slaves. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Elliot, Hugh, 1752-1830.
title: Hugh Elliot letter, 1808 March 24.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a letter to "Mrs. Pollard" that Elliot composed on behalf of his wife. Topics include waiting for the King's orders for a post, possibly in either Sicily or Barbados; the last days and horrible suffering of a female mutual friend; his concern for the safety of another mutual friend, Col. Taylor, who has embarked with his regiment to Sicily; and the threat of Napoleon's invasion.

creator: Collier, George Ralph, Sir, 1774-1824.
title: George Ralph Collier Memo of Instructions to convoy of British trading ships, 1821 February 12.
context_snippets: Collection comprises Sir George Collier's instructions to trade ships off the coast of Africa. They direct traders to support British merchants in Portendick, Gambia, with advice, assistance, and protection as needed; avoid controversy with the French and pay the proper respects when in port; avoid going onshore among the Moors unless absolutely necessary, and never let your guard down if they must; and be prepared to recognize when trade has been established and leave the coast. The orders these instructions accompany are not included within the collection, and there is no mention of the slave trade in the document.

creator: Collier, George Ralph, Sir, 1774-1824.
title: George Ralph Collier Memo of Instructions to convoy of British trading ships, 1821 February 12.
context_snippets: Sir George R. Collier was an officer of the Royal Navy during the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, and the War of 1812.

creator: Housewives League of Detroit. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n92054525
title: Housewives League of Detroit ephemera collection, 1940-1950 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 9 items related to the activities of the Housewives League of Detroit, including the program for its founders celebration in honor of Rev. and Mrs. Wm. H. Peck (1940), fifth annual Garden Party broadside (1949), and the sixteenth anniversary Homecoming program (1946). One issue of the organization's official serial is present, "The Housewives League Bulletin," Vol 1, No 2 (March, April 1947). There is a typed letter from Dorothy Hall Guest House at the Tuskegee Institute regarding reservations for a room at the 1950 National Negro Business League meeting. Also includes undated material, a typed list of 53 businesses, entitled "Research Committee;" an information form for completion by African American business owners, from the Housewives League of Detroit and the Booker T. Washington Association Research Survey; and a broadside for a Women's Fair sponsored by the League. There is also a program for the 20th Anniversary banquet for the Booker T. Washington Trade Association (1950), also founded by Rev. William H. and Fannie Peck. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Grote, Harriet, 1792-1878. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no90000268
title: Harriet Grote letters to Joseph Parkes, 1834 and undated.
context_snippets: Harriet Grote was an English biographer and, as wife to political radical and historian George Grote, served hostess to the English philosophical radicals of the early nineteenth century. Joseph Parkes was an English political reformer.

creator: United States. Army. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79063202 Colored Infantry Regiment, 46th (1863-1864)
title: United States Army 46th Colored Infantry Unit muster and pay rolls, 1863-1864.
context_snippets: The 1st Arkansas Infantry (African Descent) was organized in April and May 1863. In May 1864, it came under the Bureau of Colored Troops and was designated the 46th United States Colored Infantry. The unit served at Milliken's Bend, Louisiana, and at Vicksburg, Mississippi, before moving to New Orleans in February 1865. In May 1865, it moved to Brownsville, Texas, where it was mustered out on January 30, 1866.

creator: Great Britain. India Office. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80040166
title: Great Britain India Office conveyance of Cooper's Hill Estate, Egham, Surrey, 1911 January 17.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a volume containing the indenture between the Secretary of the Council of India and the trustees of the Lord and Lady Cheylesmore's marriage settlement, to serve as a conveyance for Baroness Elizabeth Richardson Cheylesmore's purchase of Cooper's Hill, Estate, Egham, Surry, for use as a family home. The property was at Runnymede, and was used by the Royal Indian Engineering College. The piece is written in ink and contains duty and tax stamps, and wax seal stamps on ribbon. Includes a map of the property. Acquired as part of the William B. Hamilton Collection of British Manuscripts.

creator: Scarlett, M. J. (Mary J.) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2012184530
title: Mary J. Scarlett letters and broadside, 1845-1864 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection contains seven letters (22 pages) M. J. Scarlett wrote between 1845-1864. Two letters were addressed to her sister, Elizabeth (1845, 1849), and five to her niece (1858, 1860, 1863, 1864). In the letters she discussed details of her life at the time, from the teaching of students to the choosing of proper fabric for sewing a dress, making a comfortable sitting room, or studying public health and hygiene. She also mentioned many family matters. She commented on her hopes for the abolition of slavery and the infighting among abolitionists at a recent national meeting, and noted her puzzlement that those Quakers who would quickly speak as abolitionists would not also speak up on issues of faith within the Society of Friends. During the Civil War, she described the effect of the draft in Philadelphia, recorded the general concern that the Army of the Potomac needed to be successful, and pointed to camps nearby as well as to funerals passing. Collection also includes an undated broadside for "An Introductory Lecture to a Course on Physiology" to be delivered by Scarlett. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections (Duke University), the Lisa Unger Baskin Collection, and the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Anderson, Robert, 1781-1859.
title: Robert Anderson papers, 1735-circa 1878, 1908 and undated, bulk 1735-1859.
context_snippets: Collection comprises correspondence, documents and print materials belonging to merchant and land owner Robert Anderson of Williamsburg and Yorktown, Virginia. The materials date from 1735-1908, with the bulk dating from 1735 to 1859, and consist of over eighty letters, both incoming and outgoing, many legal and financial papers, other manuscript documents, and ephemeral print items such as broadsides and circulars. One folder contains military muster lists and fines stemming from Anderson's service as clerk of the 68th regiment of the Virginia militia. Topics in the correspondence include slavery and slave trade, especially in Virginia, colonization efforts in Liberia, emancipation, the status of mixed-race individuals, Virginia and U.S. politics, Virginia military history, shipping, religion and church affairs, and education. Of particular note are several letters and documents relating to Anderson's children, who he fathered with one or more slaves; one of these children, his daughter Haidee, was sent to Eaglewood, a boarding school run by abolitionists Angelina Grimke Weld and Theodore Dwight Weld. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Newman, F. W. (Francis William), 1805-1897. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50005229
title: Francis William Newman letters, 1840-1887.
context_snippets: Collection comprises five letters by Newman, including a congratulatory letter to a successful former student regarding forming regular habits of study, and a formal letter regarding moral and religious truth and its place in the study of the Bible to a student seeking his opinion. There are also three letters on British politics and public opinion regarding continental politics, particularly events in Venice, Austria, and Italian unification. Two of these letters are addressed to Mrs. Schwabe, and the other was mailed as a personal opinion letter to the editor of the Daily Mail.

creator: Myers, C. W. (Charles Wesley), 1890-1985.
title: Charles W. Myers case reports manuscripts, 1928-1932.
context_snippets: Dr. Charles Wesley Myers was a physician and hospital administrator. He was born in Marysville, Pennsylvania, and graduated from the University of Maryland School of Medicine in 1915. He served in the Army Medical Corps during World War I, and received the Distinguished Service Cross and the Croix de Guerre (twice) from France. Following the war, he became a surgeon for the U.S. Vetrans Bureau in Indianapolis, Indiana, before moving to City Hospital, there. During his tenure there as superintendent and medical director (1931-1952), Meyers opened new wards for African American patients, appointed blacks to hospital staff positions, and oversaw the construction of improved special care facilitites.

creator: Saltar family.
title: Saltar family correspondence, 1759-1880 and undated.
context_snippets: Over 200 pieces of correspondence dating from 1759-1880, written by women of the Saltar and Gordon families of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Maryland between themselves and other family relations. Over a third of the letters date before 1825. The principal correspondents are Elizabeth "Betsy" Gordon Saltar, her daughters Lucy Saltar and Frances "Fanny" Saltar, and Elizabeth's cousins Mary Gordon and Polly Gordon. Dozens of other letters come from family friends and relatives, male and female, from prominent families in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland, New York, and some from the Midwest and New England states. Topics include courtship; marriage; religion; pastimes; visits and travel; and the welfare of family members and friends. There are many references to illnesses, with many details on treatments and outcomes. There are also long passages and references to grief and mourning on the death of loved ones, and some discussions of finances. There are a few references to slavery and to enslaved people and servants. Letters sent during the Civil War discuss events centered around Pennsylvania, particularly in 1863; one discusses African American troops and their role in the war, and the circumstances surrounding the recruitment of the 3rd United States Colored Troops commander, Benjamin C. Tilghman. A few earlier letters speak of the War of 1812, especially in and around Baltimore and Philadelphia. Acquired by the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: James, John H.
title: John H. James Lectures on Revelations manuscript, 1877.
context_snippets: Collection comprises James' "Lectures on the Epistles to the Seven Asiatic Churches" that he copied by hand and had bound as a gift copy he then inscribed In August 1877 to W. Bickford-Smith, who was a manufacturer and liberal member of the House of Commons. There are two lectures (653 pgs.); the first is 32 pages and the second is divided into 22 sections. Among the themes are apostolic recognition, orthodoxy and purity of the Church, and the suffering and persecution associated with the pursuit of godliness and truth. Includes W. Bickford-Smith's engraved bookplate in the front.

creator: Oakeley, Henry, 1816-1877. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84236196
title: Henry Oakeley naval service journal and commonplace book, 1840-1855, 1917.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a journal (125 pages, plus 47 blank) Oakeley maintained during his naval service of the period. He listed that service on the first page of the volume. It opens with 21 pages of copies Oakeley made of official orders dictated by James Clark Ross on the HMS Erebus during its Antarctic expedition, 1840-1843. The next section of the volume (99 pages) is devoted to his service aboard the 8-gun brigantine-sloop, HMS Cygnet, that operated off the West African Coast to suppress the African Slave trade, 1844-1847. The majority of these pages carry tables providing geographical and meteorological information, along with day-to-day remarks regarding the ship's activities. There are also lists of slave vessels captured, with two extended entries on abandoned slave ships. This section is followed by 36 pages containing a similar log and journal for his service on the HMS Madagascar, 1853-1855, detailing the ship's activities in Rio de Janeiro, providing reports on all vessels entering and leaving the harbor. Two temperature tables are tipped in. His journal of the brigantine HMS Spy, 1855, notes ships cruising along the Brazilian coast, Fortaleza de Santa Cruz da Barra, Paranagua, Rio de Janeiro, Bahia and Pernambuco. There is also a loosely-inserted set of notes on temperatures. During this voyage there was an outbreak of yellow fever on board and nine crew members died. Oakeley became ill, was invalided and returned to England. The journals are followed by two tables: "Navy Bills sent to Union Bank of London," logging payments made to his wife; and ship stock, including beef, oysters, and wood, purchased at various locations. At the rear of the volume are nineteen pages of calculations, many regarding course and distance, and time gained. Loosely inserted are a further nine leaves of calculations, as well as three original photographs, an albumen showing the grave of Oakeley's mother-in-law, another albumen the grave of "Sophia, widow first of Capt. Richard Francis Cleaveland RN and second Capt James Johnstone McCleverty," and a gelatin printing-out paper print showing six senior WWI army officers. Copied out on seven pages are jeux d'esprit, and twenty-two pages feature clippings from magazines, including seven devoted to maritime engravings. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

Richard Francis Cleaveland RN and second Capt James Johnstone McCleverty," and a gelatin printing-out paper print showing six senior WWI army officers. Copied out on seven pages are jeux d'esprit, and twenty-two pages feature clippings from magazines, including seven devoted to maritime engravings. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Oakeley, Henry, 1816-1877. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84236196
title: Henry Oakeley naval service journal and commonplace book, 1840-1855, 1917.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a journal (125 pages, plus 47 blank) Oakeley maintained during his naval service of the period. He listed that service on the first page of the volume. It opens with 21 pages of copies Oakeley made of official orders dictated by James Clark Ross on the HMS Erebus during its Antarctic expedition, 1840-1843. The next section of the volume (99 pages) is devoted to his service aboard the 8-gun brigantine-sloop, HMS Cygnet, that operated off the West African Coast to suppress the African Slave trade, 1844-1847. The majority of these pages carry tables providing geographical and meteorological information, along with day-to-day remarks regarding the ship's activities. There are also lists of slave vessels captured, with two extended entries on abandoned slave ships. This section is followed by 36 pages containing a similar log and journal for his service on the HMS Madagascar, 1853-1855, detailing the ship's activities in Rio de Janeiro, providing reports on all vessels entering and leaving the harbor. Two temperature tables are tipped in. His journal of the brigantine HMS Spy, 1855, notes ships cruising along the Brazilian coast, Fortaleza de Santa Cruz da Barra, Paranagua, Rio de Janeiro, Bahia and Pernambuco. There is also a loosely-inserted set of notes on temperatures. During this voyage there was an outbreak of yellow fever on board and nine crew members died. Oakeley became ill, was invalided and returned to England. The journals are followed by two tables: "Navy Bills sent to Union Bank of London," logging payments made to his wife; and ship stock, including beef, oysters, and wood, purchased at various locations. At the rear of the volume are nineteen pages of calculations, many regarding course and distance, and time gained. Loosely inserted are a further nine leaves of calculations, as well as three original photographs, an albumen showing the grave of Oakeley's mother-in-law, another albumen the grave of "Sophia, widow first of Capt. Richard Francis Cleaveland RN and second Capt James Johnstone McCleverty," and a gelatin printing-out paper print showing six senior WWI army officers. Copied out on seven pages are jeux d'esprit, and twenty-two pages feature clippings from magazines, including seven devoted to maritime engravings. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Alligood, Douglass L. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr2006000179
title: Douglass L. Alligood papers, 1963-2013 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection spans the years 1963-2013, with the bulk of materials spanning 1980-2006. It contains primarily of research reports focused on ethnic minority (African American, Asian, Hispanic) and youth consumer market demographics. The collection also includes clippings and a 1963 audio recording, Adventures in Negro History. Companies referenced in the materials include BBDO, RCA, Chrysler and Pepsi. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

creator: Noyes (Family)
title: Noyes-Balch family papers, 1854-1957 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises correspondence, including 136 letters (603 pages); 3 diaries; a photograph album and loose photographs. as well as a wooden box in which the family stored letters from Catharine Porter Noyes. The collection centers around Catharine, who detailed her experiences while teaching newly freed slaves at plantations on the Sea Islands of South Carolina, from 1863-1864 and 1869-1870. She described the challenges of her teaching situation, social events and celebrations, attitudes about freed blacks and her teaching them, black funeral and religious practices, and general conditions on the islands. She included her hand-drawn maps of the area, indicating its relation to the mainland. In addition to these letters from the Sea Islands, there are letters Catharine wrote while she was in Illinois and from the family home in Jamaica Plain, Mass., before she made her trip South. There are also family letters written to Catharine, 1860-1892, especially from her sister, Ellen (Nellie); Ellen's husband, F. V. "Frank" Balch; and her cousin, Mary, who taught with Ellen in South Carolina, among others family members. Another set of letters were written by Ellen to Frank while he served as secretary to U. S. Senator and abolitionist Charles Sumner (R-Ma) in 1864 in Washington, D.C.; and by artist Emily E. Balch to Richard Noyes Stone. The collection contains a diary maintained by a 12-year-old girl, probably Ravella Balch, and there are two diaries maintained by Emily E. Balch in 1929. Common topics in all the letters include family news, health matters, visiting, travel plans, reading, lectures and church services attendance, theater performances, and pastimes. The photograph album contains 32 black-and-white photographs of Noyes and Balch family members, as well as family friends. There are 31 cartes-de-visite and one tintype; two of the cartes-de-visite have been hand-painted. The majority of the photographs are labeled, several in ink, in a later hand. In addition to the photograph album, there are 17 loose black-and-white photographs, dated 1877-1957, including 4 cartes-de-visite, 6 tintypes, and 2 photo postcards. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture, and as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Virginia Barber Literary Agency, creator.
title: Virginia Barber Literary Agency records, 1968-2003.
context_snippets: The collection includes client files and correspondence for the VBLA's many clients during the late 1970s through the early 2000s. There are also legal and financial materials, correspondence files with other agencies and publishers, including Virago Press, and materials from Barber's work with professional organizations such as the Independent Literary Agents Association. Notable clients represented in this collection include Peter Mayle, Anita Shreve, MacDonald Harris, Anne Rivers Siddons, James Dodson, Rosellen Brown, and Paul Ehrlich.

creator: Irvin, Cynthia L. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n99005319
title: Cynthia Lorraine Irvin papers, 1966-2011.
context_snippets: Cynthia Irvin was a senior social science scholar with the Research Triangle Institute International, where she worked on projects in the areas of human rights, post-conflict reconstruction, and peacebuilding. Her research interests included ethnic conflict, humanitarian aid, human rights, peacebuilding, and economic aid and women and politics.

creator: United Nations. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79021345 Ad Hoc Committee on Slavery.
title: United Nations Ad Hoc Committee on Slavery records, 1918-1956 and undated, bulk 1949-1951.
context_snippets: In 1949 the United Nations general assembly asked secretary general to create a committee to investigate the status of slavery and the slave trade. The committee, which was active in 1950-1951, was a joint effort of the U.N. Economic and Social Council and the International Labour Organization. The committee published their findings in a report in 1951.

creator: Tayloe, Julia Maria.
title: Julia Maria Tayloe notes and invitations to Dolly Madison, 1837.
context_snippets: The collection is comprised of brief notes concerning social and household matters, including invitations. They are undated but were probably written to Mrs. Madison after she resumed her residence in Washington in 1837. Internal evidence verifies Madison as their recipient. References are made to "Ralph," a servant to the Madison family for many years, and to "Miss Payne," a niece who resided with Dolley Madison in Washington.

creator: Tayloe, Julia Maria.
title: Julia Maria Tayloe notes and invitations to Dolly Madison, 1837.
context_snippets: Julia Maria Tayloe was the first wife of first wife of Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, a prominent landowner from Virginia who resided in Washington, D. C., much of his life and at one time owned the Willard Hotel. The Tayloe and Madison families were close friends for many years. When Dolley Madison returned to Washington after her husband's death, she lived near the Tayloe home on LaFayette Square.

creator: Lowrie, Walter, 1784-1868. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n85259301
title: Walter Lowrie letters, 1838-1852.
context_snippets: Collection includes six letters (10 pages) written to Walter Lowrie by African American missionaries and emigrants to Liberia while he served as Secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions. Among them were freed slave and missionary James M. Priest, who wrote about the enlargement of the Mission, health matters, and with a request for medicine and general support (1845). Black abolitionist, cooper, missionary, and school master employed by the American Colonization Society, Ephraim Titler wrote regarding his health and with questions about intended support for the Mission in the southern end of the country (1846). Other letters were penned by brothers G. R. Ellis and Washington W. McDonogh, former slaves educated by their former owner at Lafayette College in Easton, Pennsylvania, then sent to Liberia. Ellis wrote of his appointment as receipt agent for the Mission, and mentioned a recent shipment and payment for his work (1848), while McDonogh recorded the activities and growth of his school. Includes a disparaging letter about Priest's abilities as a missionary sent by W. L. Breckinridge, a white minister in Kentucky (1846), as well as a letter from George P. Todsen (1836) regarding his claim for payment for physician services he provided to missionaries in Monrovia. Collection includes background information and transcriptions of the letters. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Anthony, Susan B. (Susan Brownell), 1820-1906, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82096260 correspondent.
title: Susan B. Anthony letters to Minnie C. Rodey, 1905.
context_snippets: Collection contains two letters Susan B. Anthony wrote on National American Woman Suffrage Association letterhead in February 1905 to Minnie C. Rodey, who was chair of the "Women's Club" in Albuquerque, New Mexico. In the letters, Anthony described informational material she will be sending Rodey, including a history of woman suffrage. In addition, she recommended a process by which the territory would vote on the issue of woman's suffrage before it acquiring statehood, since she considered the legislature and governor more likely to pass it than the general male voters in the state. She added, "... I read yesterday of the number of Indians and Mexicans and negroes that were in the territories. It is amazing that people want to make a state out of a territory composed of a majority of what we should term 'incompetents' Voting should be confined to intelligent beings." She also inquired of mutual friends and recommends her relatives who are visiting Albuquerque. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Anthony, Susan B. (Susan Brownell), 1820-1906, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82096260 correspondent.
title: Susan B. Anthony letters to Minnie C. Rodey, 1905.
context_snippets: Susan B. Anthony was born February 15, 1820 in Adams, Massachusetts. She was brought up in a Quaker family with long activist traditions. Early in her life she developed a sense of justice and moral zeal. After teaching for fifteen years, she became active in temperance. Because she was a woman, she was not allowed to speak at temperance rallies. This experience, and her acquaintance with Elizabeth Cady Stanton, led her to join the women's rights movement in 1852. Soon after, she dedicated her life to woman suffrage. Ignoring opposition and abuse, Anthony traveled, lectured, and canvassed across the nation for the vote. She also campaigned for the abolition of slavery, the right for women to own their own property and retain their earnings, and she advocated for women's labor organizations. In 1900, Anthony persuaded the University of Rochester to admit women. Anthony, who never married, was aggressive and compassionate by nature. She had a keen mind and a great ability to inspire. She remained active until her death on March 13, 1906.

creator: Stout, Mary Elizabeth Jordan.
title: Mary Elizabeth Jordan Stout travel diary, 1857,1862.
context_snippets: Collection comprises primarily a travel diary (12 pages) Mary E. J. Stout maintained for a trip dated 1857 Aug 8 -Oct 24. Stout, her husband, their children, and their slaves set off from Mississippi to attend a religious convention in Knoxville, Tenn. Afterward, they traveled on to visit cities in Virginia, then Washington, D.C. After a stay of several days in the capital, the Stouts traveled on to Philadelphia and New York, leaving the children and slaves behind in a boarding house. Upon their return, they found that their young son Johnnie was gravely ill; he died the following day. This left the parents grief stricken and also with feelings of guilt. They buried Johnnie in a cemetery in Georgetown and took a desultory journey back home to Mississippi. Over the first 5 days of 1862, Stout again took up the diary to make daily entries (2 pages) that focus on her perceptions regarding how her life changed since the beginning of their trip in 1857. Travel entries detail travel made via rail and boat. Descriptions focus on acquaintances made, sightseeing done in the major cities, and religious services attended. Stout often expresses strong opinions regarding the quality of their boarding and whether she enjoyed the sightseeing. There are detailed entries regarding her son's death and the mourning period following it. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

There are detailed entries regarding her son's death and the mourning period following it. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Great Britain. Parliament. House of Commons. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79113783
title: Draft of agreement proposed to be entered into with African chiefs, 1840.
context_snippets: Collection comprises an 8-page draft agreement drawn up to facilitate Great Britain's negotiations with West African chiefs between Sierra Leone and the Gambia for land, trade, and security, as well as the cessation of slavery and human sacrifice, where they existed. The key points of the agreement cover the following areas: the abolishment of slavery (including "white slavery"), the respect of land rights, the provision of payment by the English for land if terms are met, recognition of trading rights, and the upholding of the rule of law. It begins with an outline "Object" and then provides 11 distinct "terms" followed by a 12th term which is effectively a concluding statement with a space for the English commander and tribal chief to sign and agree. Then follows a section headed "Additional Terms," which list 4 more clauses, presumably for special circumstances, including the ending of human sacrifice. The paper carries two watermarks: a female monarch holding an English shield and scepter, and "W. Tucker" accompanied by the year 1837. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: NULL
title: Cholera epidemic in Havana official reports, 1833 March 10-12.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 17 reports, from different neighborhoods in Havana, in Spanish, containing information on deaths and new illnesses attributed to the cholera outbreak. The disease first arrived in the Caribbean in late February 1833, and went on to kill an estimated 30,000 people on the island, spreading like wildfire through barracks full of slaves and on into the countryside. The documents are written and signed by local authorities in Havana, and all but one are addressed to the Governor and Captain General of Cuba, a position held by Mariano Ricafort Palacin y Abarca (1776-1846) at the time. There is detailed information regarding deceased slaves, prisoners, soldiers, and residents, including names and ages; along with address as well as social status in some cases. Occasional notes regarding burial or medical treatments are present, as well. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections.

creator: Griffith, Israel, 1799-1875.
title: Israel Griffith papers 1830-1867.
context_snippets: This collection contains business papers and 1 personal letter of affection also contaniing postal delivery instructions from Israel Griffith to his wife written in Cape May, New Jersey where Griffin was working temporarily. The business papers are predominantly addressed to Griffith in Baltimore, Maryland. They primarily discuss debts, property values and potential saled of land and property.

creator: Kenyatta, Charles. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2016004284
title: "Death, 'A Rumor in our Communities'" essay, 1971.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a typed copy of Kenyatta's 6-page typed essay, "Death: 'A Rumor in our Communities,''' regarding the place of the judicial system, racism, governmental systems, but most especially police department's brutal role in rising death rates in Harlem. The essay has mimeographed and stapled self-wrappers. These feature inflammatory headlines and photos from two New York newspapers from May 1971, and the title, "Harlem's Free Press; 'Revolt! Buy Shotguns! Declare All-Out War!'" The piece was likely sold on the street for $.25. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: NULL
title: Observations sur les sages-femmes, 1786 Mai 30.
context_snippets: In early 1786, Calonne, then Controller General of Finance, launched an extensive investigation to assess the number of midwives in France and their levels of training. It was discovered that not all areas of Provence had been provided the training offered by the court-appointed midwife Madame du Coudray between 1759 and 1783, who had been commissioned by Louis XVI to provide it throughout France. The first round of Coudray's training in the region was held in 1780 in Arles and Marseille, and excluded the rest of the province. This statement describes the situation in a rural area neglected by this national training campaign, and reveals the important differences existing in the kingdom that left it in a medical stance equivalent to that in other parts of France before 1750. It also shows how doctors and surgeons placed their own pawns to oust midwives or at least subordinate them.

creator: Dykes (Family)
title: Dykes family papers, 1942-1945.
context_snippets: The Dykes were an African American family residing in Akron, Ohio, in 1940. Among the extended family were parents Rev. Arthur Lee (1894-1964) and Daisy Arnold Dykes (1895-1973), along with their sons: Lawyer Lee Dykes (1915-1982) and his wife, Hattie P. (1916-2005), and William (known as Leo?) J. Dykes. Leo Dykes served in the 5th Marine Ammunition Company during World War II; he eventually rose to the rank of corporal. Hattie's brother, Benjamn J. Peavy, also resided in Akron, and served in the army's 51st Aviation Squadron during World War II, where he was promoted to corporal.

creator: Herdman, J. Herbert, 1866-1943.
title: J. Herbert Herdman photograph album, 1890s.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a photograph album (36 pages) maintained by J. Herbert Herdman during a trip or trips to the United States in the 1890's, along with unrelated period photographs of Egypt and Great Britain by other photographers. There are 47 albumen photographs of the trip to the United States, with images varying in size from 9 1/4 x 11 1/2 inches to 5 3/8 x 4 inches, plus the additional 9 photographs, all 10 1/2 x 8 1/4 inches, several of printouts of images photographed by Felix Bonfils. The 47 images include begin with four images of the S.S. Majestic (1 exterior and 3 interior images), the ship Herdman sailed over the Atlantic. The album continues with 10 images in Minnesota, including a group of Sioux Indians photographed by Truman Ward Ingersoll, a view of Duluth, and images of homesteaders on wagons. The next image in the album is of an African American baby; on the same page is an image of the album's compiler and his traveling companions during a trip to Lookout Mountain in Tennessee, with an ink inscription dated 3 April 1892. This is followed by 12 photographs of the battleground by Lookout Mountain photography firm Hardie Brothers, with their printed description laid in. Three photographs of adult African Americans follow, one identified as "Uncle Pope, Old Ky. U.S.A." The page also holds a circa 1890 printing of an 1861 photograph of Jefferson Davis's inauguration as President of the Confederacy. On the next leaf is a large view of Montgomery, Alabama, with the Court Square fountain in the foreground and the Capitol in the distance. The next image is of a lynched African American man. On the same page is an image of two teams of horses pulling large blocks of granite. The next four images relate to the Coal Creek War in Tennessee, including two views of the mine, Fort Anderson, as well as the infamous images of a posed group of Tennessee militiamen in a trench with guns aiming at an "escaped" African American convict and the following image showing the convict shot dead after one of the guns accidentally discharged. Eight images of views in various Southern cities follow, including two images showing two African American fishermen on a Louisiana bayou and an African American cotton picker on a horse-laden cart of cotton. Includes a piece of John Herdman & Sons company stock letterhead regarding flour orders, which holds Herdman's notes on the photographs.

creator: Alpert, Alan.
title: Alan Alpert illustrated journal of business travel in Greece and India, with notes on Indian religious beliefs, 1978 July 6-1979 Jan 3.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a volume (68 pages) containing Alan Alpert's journal of his travels while doing business in Greece and India, 1978 July 6-December 23; although the majority of his time was spent in India. Alpert is a young designer of furniture and clothing; he is present mainly to oversee factory production of furniture designed for the American market, according to his specifications. This proves frustrating. He details his day-to-day work (with names and contact information listed), business socializing, and free-time activities. Alpert provides an engaging and complex picture of his interior and emotional lives, with some focus on the state of his relationship with his partner, Michael, in New York, his parents, along with description of attachments he forms with men met during his travels. The journal includes about 12 accomplished pen, ink, and watercolor portraits of men he meets, as well as portraits of women and families, and assorted views, designs, and doodles. The journal is preceded by 18 leaves containing unfinished paintings and drawings, and is followed by 15 pages of his notes regarding Indian philosophy and religious beliefs, dated 3 January 1979.

creator: Wright, Charlie Erin Hanna.
title: Charlie Erin Hanna Wright papers, 1825-1899 and undated.
context_snippets: Charlie Erin Wright Hanna, who is referred to as Erin in the collection, was a mother and wife living in various locations throughout her life in Tennessee and Kentucky.

creator: Longpre, Jean-Baptiste, 1776?-
title: Jean Longpre Haitian independence documents, 1799, 1804.
context_snippets: Collection comprises two documents from a collection of Jean Longpre's papers, including an excerpted copy of a will for Monsieur de la Martinier (1799) and a manuscript copy of Haiti's Declaration of Independence. The extracted will mentions those with family members who became key Haitian revolutionaries. De la Martinier was a rich plantation owner whose illegitimate mulatto son, Louis Daure Lamartiniere, did not inherit due to his mixed race. Lamartiniere and his wife, Jeanne Marie, were key figures in the fight for Haitian independence. In the document, Jacque (sic?) Drouet and Bernard Pemerle are appointed executors of de la Martinier's estate because of assistance they have provided. Drouet or his son was the person for whom Fort Drouet, built in 1804 by General Dessalines, was named. Bernard Pemerle was the father of Martial Pemerle, a noted freedom fighter in the 1790s. Both men signed the document, which also mentions another family (the handwriting is not legible) as recipients of property in Martinique. The contemporary manuscript copy (4 pages; 8 5/8" x 12 3/16") of the Haitian Declaration of Independence begins "Liberte, ou la mort, Armee indigene. Aujourd'hui 1er de Janvier 1804, le Gen en Chef de l'armee indigene, accompagne des Generaux de l'armee, convoques a l'effer de prendre les mesures qui doivener tender au Bonheur du pays ..." The Declaration takes has three parts. In the first part, the Generals of the Haitian army sign their names to an oath swearing to renounce the French yoke or to die rather than to live under French domination. In part two, General-in-Chief Jean-Jacques Dessalines addresses the Haitians in an impassioned defense of independence. Finally, Haitian generals proclaim Dessalines Governor-General for life and swear to obey laws issued under his authority.

creator: Longpre, Jean-Baptiste, 1776?-
title: Jean Longpre Haitian independence documents, 1799, 1804.
context_snippets: Jean-Baptiste Pierre Aimee Colheux Longpre was born between 1770 and 1780 in the parish of Leogane, Haiti. His father, Jean Baptiste Pierre Colheux, is stated to have been "ancient Conseiller au Conseil Superior de la Colonie de St. Domingue." Longpre lived in America until 1802, but his whereabouts after this date are unclear. He either returned to St. Domingue (Haiti) or went to Cuba. By 1809, he immigrated to Philadelphia, where two years later he filed his petition to become a citizen of the United States, which ocurred about 1816. Longpre became a well-known merchant and negociant in New Orleans. His marriage there, on 14 October 1813, to Victoire "Victoria" Francoise Adele Fitzgerald, daughter of banker J.R. Fitzgerald, brought him $4,000 in movables and slaves. He had $10,000 of his own at the time of his marriage. Longpre was a shareholder of the Louisiana Insurance Company and elected a director in 1827. He had two children, his son Jules, a law student, and his daughter Ernestine, who married her cousin M Leon de Saint-Maurice in 1838. Longpre moved to France in 1833 after the death of his wife, accompanied by his mother-in-law, Madame Victoire Descac Fitzgerald. He settled in Nantes, but also lived in Montpellier. Longpre's sister was the Countess de Gaalon.
