creator: Freeman, A. Myrick, 1936- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50025696
title: Myrick Freeman papers, 1967-2010.
context_snippets: The Myrick Freeman papers date from approximately 1970 to 2010 and document Freeman's career as a prominent economist at Bowdoin College and senior fellow at Resources for the Future in Washington, D.C. The materials in the collection cover Freeman's consulting work, participation in conferences and workshops, writings, as well as testimony for the U.S. Congress and other government entities.

creator: Horton, Marie W.
title: Marie W. Horton letter, 1847 February 21.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a 4-page letter written by Horton to Martha P. Jones in Portland, Maine. The letter contains comments on the activities and health of various friends and relatives, but Horton's primary focus is the description of efforts by Philadelphia women, including herself, to gain support for the abolition of the death penalty in Pennsylvania. She details the petition drive the women developed directed at the legislature, then adds: "I was one of a commission of twenty-five to circulate these petitions (of which we had many hundreds printed) among the females our city for signatures I obtained seven hundred & ninety two names & this was done by going from house to house reading to them our petition & asking them to sign their names to it some of them would not treat me with common civility, saying it was entirely out of the sphere of females to interfere with such matters we had much better leave them for the men & mind our children at home. One person told me it was I & such as I that was encouraging the murderers, that 'life for life' was a command of God & whoever strove to abolish it was no better than a blasphemer, but all did not think so as thou wilt conclude by the number of names I obtained there have been already several thousand sent up to the Legislature & though it is hardly probable there will much result from it this year yet we have much to encourage us for the future. I am now enjoying the luxury of staying at home...." Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Pillsbury, Parker, 1809-1898. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50009640
title: Parker Pillsbury diaries, 1864-1896.
context_snippets: Parker Pillsbury (1809-1898) was an American minister, lecturer, newspaper editor, and advocate for abolition and women's rights. The collection is composed of 33 pocket diaries Parker Pillsbury kept for the years 1864 to 1896. The diaries offer a consistent, uninterrupted record of Pillsbury's life during these years, particularly his work fighting for the rights of women and African Americans and promoting Free Religion. Pillsbury records his interactions with leading social reformers of the nineteenth century, including William Lloyd Garrison, Frederick Douglass, Abby Kelley and Stephen S. Foster, Gerrit Smith, Wendell Phillips, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Susan B. Anthony, Lucretia Mott, Robert Ingersoll, Charles Sumner, Henry Ward Beecher and Theodore Tilton among many others. His entries occasionally are accompanied by tipped in newspaper clippings about national events.

creator: Jones, Judith Leavitt, 1815-1846.
title: Judith Leavitt Jones poem, 1841.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a poem, "Dedicated to her Mother," Jones composed regarding her voyage on the ship "Dalmatia" with her husband from Boston to Batavia, Indonesia, beginning 12 January 1841. The manuscript is dated 15 April, with the Indian Ocean as the locale. Includes corrections and a few marginal annotations. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Herrick, William.
title: William Herrick letters, 1864.
context_snippets: This collection contains three letters written by William Herrick to his aunt and cousin from Fort McPherson in Natchez, Mississippi, where he was stationed in 1864. The letters discuss the news and events of Herrick's family in New Hampshire and a specific photography album belonging to Herrick's wife. Also included in the letters is information about the Mississippi weather and camp life in general.

creator: Hallowell, Richard P. (Richard Price), 1835-1904. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr89010376
title: Richard P. Hallowell papers 1888-1902.
context_snippets: Richard P. Hallowell was an abolitionist and Quaker who lived in Boston, Massachusettes. He oposed practices that prohibited African American men from voting following the passage of the 15th ammendment, and published works on this topic and those related to being a Quaker.

creator: Holt, Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock, 1881-1980.
title: Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock Holt papers, 1889-1980.
context_snippets: The Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock Holt Papers date from 1889 to 1980 and chronicle the personal life of Wylanta as well as the business and financial transactions which she conducted as a prominent landowner in Durham. Materials include correspondence, photographs, and financial records.

creator: Holt, Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock, 1881-1980.
title: Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock Holt papers, 1889-1980.
context_snippets: Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock Holt (maiden name Rochelle, 1881-1980) was the daughter of Durham merchant Leander Sydney and Jeanette Stanley Rochelle. She was the fourth and final wife of Brodie L. Duke and a Durham landowner in her own right.

creator: Diamond, Peter A., http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84007075 creator.
title: Peter Diamond papers, 1963-2013.
context_snippets: The Peter Diamond papers date from 1963 to 2013 and document Diamond's career as a renowned economist whose work has focused on U.S. Social Security policy and other forms of social insurance. The collection's materials cover Diamond's writings, grants, and participation in lectures, seminars, and other events, as well as Diamond's association with groups such as the National Science Foundation (NSF), the American Association of Retired Persons (AARP), and the National Academy of Social Insurance (NASI). Writings drafts include both paper and electronic formats. Forms part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.

creator: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no99091652
title: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor collection, 1945.
context_snippets: Collection contains 17 items related to advocacy on behalf of Mrs. Recy Taylor's case, primarily press releases from the Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor and the Alabama Committee for Equal Justice. The press releases in this group reflect the evolution of the case and the committees. The January and early February items remind members of the importance of the case as "a fight for all American womanhood. It is a fight for equal justice and for unity of all our people." Names of prominent sponsors are listed. After the second grand jury meeting on February 14, the press releases take on a more politically forceful tone. Members of local NAACP chapters were joined by members of labor unions and prominent citizens in demanding national action. The Alabama Committee's press releases record the intimidation of their executive secretary Caroline Collier Ballin when she attempted to interview members of Mrs. Taylor's family. Also includes a brochure on the incident with appeals for support, a petition form, a newspaper article on the case from "The Worker," and a flyer on this case and others requiring action to protect civil rights. One press release contains a list of supporters. There is also a custom case created to house the materials. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no99091652
title: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor collection, 1945.
context_snippets: Collection contains 17 items related to advocacy on behalf of Mrs. Recy Taylor's case, primarily press releases from the Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor and the Alabama Committee for Equal Justice. The press releases in this group reflect the evolution of the case and the committees. The January and early February items remind members of the importance of the case as "a fight for all American womanhood. It is a fight for equal justice and for unity of all our people." Names of prominent sponsors are listed. After the second grand jury meeting on February 14, the press releases take on a more politically forceful tone. Members of local NAACP chapters were joined by members of labor unions and prominent citizens in demanding national action. The Alabama Committee's press releases record the intimidation of their executive secretary Caroline Collier Ballin when she attempted to interview members of Mrs. Taylor's family. Also includes a brochure on the incident with appeals for support, a petition form, a newspaper article on the case from "The Worker," and a flyer on this case and others requiring action to protect civil rights. One press release contains a list of supporters. There is also a custom case created to house the materials. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no99091652
title: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor collection, 1945.
context_snippets: Mrs. Recy Taylor was abducted and raped by six white men in Abbeville, Alabama, on the night of September 3, 1944. Despite admission of guilt by one of the men, who also named the others involved, Henry County's all-white grand jury which convened in October failed to return an indictment. The "Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor" was formed a few weeks later, appealing to the Governor of the State to pressure the County to reopen the case. The local chapter of the NAACP, under the leadership of Edgar D. Nixon, helped organize the push for justice (Rosa Parks was working in the NAACP offices during this time and was active in the case). A second grand jury heard the case in February 1945, but again refused to return an indictment. The committee continued to apply pressure through their membership, local NAACP chapters, labor unions, and prominent citizens, but the case was never brought to trial. Many of the organizers used what they learned in subsequent campaigns for civil rights. Recy Taylor and her family lived on in Abbeville for many years, often intimidated and threatened. In 2011, the Alabama's House of Representatives formally apologized to Taylor for the state's failure to prosecute her attackers.

creator: Gesell, August, 1856-1933.
title: August Gesell account and sketch book, 1865, 1875-1909.
context_snippets: Collection comprises an account book [50 pages, plus blanks] maintained and illustrated by August Gesell. The volume was initially established as a "Protocoll buch fur den Lieder kranz in Catonsville, Januar 1865," but those pages have been excised. A descriptive and decorated pencil drawing on page two advertises Gesell as a "House and Sign Painter and Glazing," and a second colored drawing in the in the form of an 1870s trade card decorated with leaves contains the inscription, "August Gesell Catonsville Md." On 32 pages, Gesell sketched in pencil and painted in watercolors a wide variety of fanciful artistic ornaments, designs, initials/monograms, male busts, animals, birds, and flowers, all of which he likely incorporated in his decorative work for signs, furniture, walls, and ceilings. Several designs encompass a half or full page and many are dated between 1875 and 1909. Gesell also used 18 pages to record his accounts and specific jobs performed for named local customers, several of which he later marked paid. Includes one song and one verse. There were three pieces of paper with drawings and writing practice, laid-in. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History and the George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana..

creator: Gesell, August, 1856-1933.
title: August Gesell account and sketch book, 1865, 1875-1909.
context_snippets: August Gesell was born in Prussia, Germany, in 1856. He immigrated to Baltimore with his family in 1860. The family settled in Carroll County, Maryland. He and his (second?) wife, Gertrude, had several children and lived in Catonsville. Gesell worked as a decorative painter; he died in 1933.

creator: Roberts, D. H. (Douglas Hall), 1860-1945.
title: Douglas Hall Roberts papers, 1903-1929 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection primarily comprises two manuscript physician's account ledgers (365 pages and 125 pages, each with 12- page indexes containing 148 and 115 names), dated 1922-1927, relating to Douglas Hall Roberts' medical practice. His accounts include the patient's name, occasionally an address, along with the type of treatments and medicines prescribed or administered, together with the dates and fees for rendered services. Entries detail office and home visits, the dressing of heads, limbs, and boils, the treatment of fractures and bone dislocations, the adjustment of bandages, the examination of noses, eyes, and ears, the stitching of wounds, the opening of abscesses, obstetric cases, and "30 day treatments." His letterhead held the statement "Chronic diseases given special attention," and specified those as cancer, rheumatism, hay fever, bronchial asthma, dermatosis, anemia, goiter, and tuberculosis. These account books are unusual in that they contain the doctor's often lengthy diagnoses of his patients' illnesses and their treatment, his patients' testimonials to him regarding their treatment, and often his personal assessments of them: "The most conscious and satisfactory patient I ever had. A moral girl. A Christian girl who has a wonderful mother. May she continue to regain her health and live a long and useful life." The collection also contains additional materials regarding Roberts' practice along with a few items reflecting family matters. There are patient statements, medical supply company literature and bills, and Roberts family accounts (including utility, tax. and personal billing statements and receipts). In addition, there are letters from patients regarding their accounts and other matters; one patient asks him to obtain a bottle of the "disinfectant and germ destroyer" he had mentioned to her so that she could pick it up, adding that she "can not take another chance of becoming pregnant again as I went and got myself cleaned up." There are a few family letters, including Roberts' love poems to his wife, one of which was rejected, along with a grieving letter he wrote following her death. In addition, there is one black-and-white photograph proof along with two watercolor paintings. Includes an information folder. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine collections.

creator: Bedford, Kristin, photographer.
title: Kristin Bedford photographs, 1930s-2018.
context_snippets: The collection consists chiefly of 172 color photographs taken by Kristin Bedford from 2012 to 2018, deriving from three projects: "Be Still: A Storefront Church in Durham," which consists of images of African American worshippers and their pastor in Durham, North Carolina; "The Perfect Picture," images of members of the multi-racial Peace Mission Movement religious community, founded by Father and Mother Divine in the 1930s, and the community's estate, Woodmont, near Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; and her latest work, "Cruise Night," a photographic essay on low-rider car clubs and culture in Los Angeles, California and other areas. The "Perfect Picture" prints are accompanied by a variety of related materials dating from the 1930s, including movement publications and print ephemera, historical photographs, memorabilia, a CD of sermons, and other items; materials in this series speak to race relations in the 20th century, the civil rights movement, and African American religious culture. The color photographs for all three projects include large exhibit prints as well as a set of smaller reference prints for research use, and an essay written by the photographer for each project.

creator: Wunderlich, Martin A. (Martin Alfred), 1893- .
title: Martin A. Wunderlich papers, 1936-1942 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection contains letters, transcripts, printed matter, newspaper clippings (including a scrapbook), handwritten notes, photo postcards, membership cards, receipts. The majority of the material is newspaper clippings, some loose and others affixed to approximately 25 sheets of paper. Their topics are primarily the charges and legal proceedings brought against German American Bund leaders on Long Island in 1939 (the so-called "Camp Siegfried Trial"). There are two typed pages of testimony given by Wunderlich at the trial. This testimony is not an official transcript, but a self-styled record entitled "Summary of what had happened and what I said on the Witness-stand." Includes Bund materials, including a photo postcard of "Norland," a recreational camp in New Jersey for Federation members and their families; photographs of two members and friends of Wunderlich in Brownshirt uniform; five receipts for membership dues paid by Wunderlich, and his printed membership card. In addition, there are five typed sheets in German, possibly a handout for members, on the Federation's organization and activities. There is also a mimeographed sheet in German of general instructions for the Seventh National Conference of the Bund, held July 2-3, 1939, with a schedule of meetings held during both days. Also includes a file of materials regarding Wunderlich's service as a witness in the Siegfried trial and, later, regarding his naturalization status. There is a printed subpoena from a Special Session of the Court of the City of New York (1940) and a grand jury subpoena from the Southern New York U.S. District Court (1942) with a typed copy of the complaint filed against Wunderlich, who was charged with "fraudulently and illegally" procuring US citizenship. The complaint asks the court to revoke Wundelich's citizenship on the basis of his acting as an agent for a hostile power. In response, there is a copy of a three-page typed letter from Wunderlich to the Assistant US Attorney in New York, complaining that he has been mistreated by the law and by other Americans, attaching a photostat of a threatening postcard he received. Printed material present includes: Ernst Rohm, "Why S. A.? Addressing the Diplomatic Corps in Berlin on December 7, 1933." Berlin: Liebheit & Thiesen, n.d. [1933]; "The Edmondson Case. Jews vs. Christians in Court." 2nd ed. NY: Edmondson Source, 1936; Siward (pseudonym), "The Reign of the Elders, Part II." N.p. Self-published? N.d. [1939?]; Anon., "The Sign of Satan. If you want to save Canada from Communism never vote for a Freemason or a Jew!" Winnipeg: Canadian Nationalist Party, 1935; and the newsletter "Our Common Cause." NY: n.p. (1942). There are also symbols printed on fabric for the Ukrainian Liberation Army (YBB), an ethnic unit established by the Germans in 1943 following their invasion of the Soviet Union. The relation of the swatch to this collection is unclear.

creator: M. Le Clear & Co.
title: M. Le Clear & Co. Frederick Douglass photograph portrait, between 1865-1895.
context_snippets: Collection comprises an M. Le Clear & Company black-and-white photograph portrait taken in their studio between 1865 and 1895. It is a 2.25" x 3.5" albumen three-quarter view vignette portrait, in which Frederick Douglass is looking directly at the camera, and is wearing a light-colored suit, dark vest, white shirt and a tie. The background is clear. The photograph was acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin papers, and is accompanied by copies of letters regarding its provenance.

creator: McIntosh, Alexander.
title: Alexander McIntosh papers, 1860-1865.
context_snippets: Chiefly letters to McIntosh from his wife and other relatives. Several were written to him in early 1865 while he was stationed as a shoemaker with Company K, 4th Regiment, Senior Reserves in Salisbury, NC. The majority of the letters date from 1865. Topics include family and other personal news, matters related to his wife's running of the farm, deserters, African Americans being pressed into service to defend Charlotte from Gen. William T. Sherman, the impressing of mules, horses, and other goods for Confederate use. Another letter, dated February 4, 1865, was written to McIntosh's wife by her brother, R. Gerrard Sifford, while he was being held as a prisoner of war at Point Lookout, MD. He states that he is well cared for, but it is difficult to determine whether his tone is sarcastic or forcibly light.

creator: Gunn, J. W., (John William).
title: J. W. Gunn one-act play "Jim Lee & Co. Laundry" production binder, 1937.
context_snippets: Collection contains a 2-ring contemporary binder holding 3 typescript copies (with minor variations) and one handwritten draft of the one-act play "Jim Lee & Co. Laundry," prepared for the chapter and performed by its members on 11 October 1937. Includes assorted notes. Set entirely in a Chinese laundry, the play partakes of an array of stereotypes. The "Dramatic Personae" include African-Americans ("Sambo Washington," "a dark cloud"), Germans ("Baron Goofus" and "Weenie Schnitzel"), Chinese ("Quong What," "Chong Foey," and "More Yet"), homosexuals ("Bill Lightfoot," a "foxy gent"), and even a Chinese homosexual ("Sing High"), among others. Almost entirely in awkward dialect with some faux Chinese and German thrown in, what plot there is revolves around the misunderstandings of various customers as they interact with laundry proprietor Jim Lee. Acquired as part of the Leona Bowman Carpenter Collection of English and American Literature.

creator: Williams, Louis E. (Louis Eugene), 1933-2013.
title: Louis E. Williams papers, 1951-1971 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises correspondence, along with select records for the Maryland Committee for Democratic Rights and the Southwestern Recreation Committee, printed materials, photographs, and ephemera. Includes incoming correspondence for Louis Williams, dated 1962-1971 and undated, with a few written in Polish and one in Russian. Topics relate to his travel to Poland, volunteer work and training, and appreciation for his teaching. In addition, there are 72 items of correspondence, dated 1968 October 8-1969 July 24, between Betty and Howard Langford while he was working at Morris College in Sumter, S.C., and later given to Williams for archiving. In addition to their daily activities, topics include her job in the Baltimore Department of Welfare and plans for her to move to South Carolina, racism, Civil Rights issues in Baltimore and related generational clashes, Williams' work with the youth (and their vandalizing of his car), a visit by actor Dustin Hoffman to Williams' neighborhood, black militancy and community center infighting and it's impact on Williams' leadership, as well the couple's financial support of Williams. Includes Betty Langford's 3-page recommendation for Williams application as a community organizer. Material from the Maryland Committee for Democratic Rights includes printed information on the McCarran Act (1950), which the group was fighting; Madalyn Murray's resignation as chair and Williams' written reaction to it as the new chair, interviews with or letters from congressional representatives regarding their stance on the Act, an incomplete 1963 speech on the work of the group by Williams and directed to Marylanders; and a meeting flyer. Records from the Southwestern Recreation Committee, which Williams directed for the benefit of inner city youth, include one page of a 1967 program report, a funding proposal, participant lists, questionnaire results, staff contact lists, and financial records. The records make clear the financial struggles of the organization between 1967-1970. There are 10 photographs in the collection, 3 color and 7 black and white, ranging in size from 2x3 school photographs to 5x7 portraits. They are mostly uncaptioned and date between 1961-1967 and undated. The printed material in the collection includes a notice of the recommissioning of the S.S. Jarvis, railroad tariff documents, Howard Langford's play "Salt of the Earth" with Williams' forward, a 1968 financial statement for Holy Cross National Catholic Church, and a press release for the play "A sleep of Prisoners." Collection includes two formal evaluations of Williams' teaching, a report card for his son, and ephemera includes greeting cards, two napkins containing hate language, documents related to Williams' travel in Poland and Russia. Acquired as part of the George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana.

creator: Williams, Louis E. (Louis Eugene), 1933-2013.
title: Louis E. Williams papers, 1951-1971 and undated.
context_snippets: Louis E. Williams was born on 8 January 1933 and died in Baltimore, Maryland, on 19 January 2013 at age 80. He married Constance M. "Connie" Williams (born Zyglarski), and the couple had three children, Kenneth Williams, M.D., Louis Williams, and Connie Louise Williams. Williams served in the Navy during the Korean War, aboard the U.S.S. Jarvis; he later a public school teacher, youth worker, and community organizer in Baltimore. A resolution recognizing his work was published by the Baltimore City Counicil following Williams' death. He was close friends with Beatrice (Betty) W. and Howard D. Langford (1896-1984). Betty, Howard's second wife, was as a social worker; Howard was an English professor. Both were affiliated with the Communist Party, and Betty served with Williams on the Maryland Committee for Democratic Rights.

creator: NULL
title: Haitian revolution letter describing local conditions, 1802 March-May.
context_snippets: Collection comprises an unsigned letter composed by two individuals who report on conditions in Haiti during the revolution, including descriptions of cities in flame and ineffectual French troops, and voicing the opinion that the revolutionaries are better trained than they were in 1791. It is possible that the letter is directed to Stanislas Foache in Havre, France, who had been a merchant in Santo Domingo and slaveholder Haiti. There is a hole in the text and some moisture damage.

creator: North Carolina. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79007042 Court of Pleas and Quarter Sessions (Warren County)
title: Indictment of Free black Noah Ashe for living with slave woman, 1851.
context_snippets: Collection comprises an indictment from the May term in 1851 of the Court of Pleas and Quarter Sessions in Warren County. It is entitled "State vs. Noah Ashe free man of color, Cohabiting with slave, J. G. J., Witness Peter D. Powell.... a True bill John Bowdon, foreman." The indictment states, "The jurors for the State, upon their oath, present that Noah Ashe, a free man of Color...on the tenth day of December... eighteen hundred & fifty...& on divers other days...fully & willfully...did cohabit and live together as man & wife with one Polly, a slave, the property of Peter D. Powell...against the peace & dignity of the State." North Carolina antebellum "Black codes" provided that "It shall not be lawful for any free negro or free person of colour to intermarry or cohabit and live together as man and wife with any slave; and any free negro or person of colour so intermarrying or cohabiting...shall be liable to indictment, and upon conviction shall be fined and imprisoned or whipt...not to exceed thirty-nine lashes...." The slave in question was probably 50 year-old Polly Dancy, one of 30 slaves Peter Powell had just inherited from his deceased father. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture and the George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana.

Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture and the George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana.

creator: Love, Catherine, -1832.
title: Catherine Love poetry and miscellaneous scrapbook, 1832 March 10.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a volume (74 pages) entitled "A Scrap-Book of Poetry &c., selected from the Works of Byron, Burns, Campbell, Beattie &c., and anonymous authors. 1832." It is inscribed on a preliminary blank "To Miss Catherine Love. Les petits presens entretiennent l'amitie - 10th March 1832." Includes calligraphic title and inscription pages; 3 pen-and-ink drawings; and 4 inserted leaves for musical notation, one of which has been used. Additional blank leaves at the end. Bound in contemporary blind stamped calf, with small gilt floral devices to the spine and corners, and red morocco label. Neatly mounted onto the inner rear board is a letter from William Drummond, dated 1 May 1832, with a transcription of "A Scottish Ballad, by W. Motherwell, Esq." Other poems include pieces by J.H. Willis of Quebec, Wordsworth, and Coleridge. There are also Christian prayers and a pages of notes on the Bible. Laid-in is an undated note documenting Love's death from cholera and that she worked one of the needlework pictures now in the drawing room at Dacre Banks in Yorkshire. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Rimington, William Drewry, 1775-1799.
title: William Drewry Rimington letters, 1799 May-October.
context_snippets: Collection comprises three letters written by Rimington, from Cork, Ireland; Boston, Mass.; and Newport, R.I.; describing to his father and brother his outward voyage to America, his first impressions of Boston, and relating news of the spread of yellow fever in New York. There is an additional letter written by Edward Wilson to Rimington's father describing the circumstances of the young man's death from yellow fever in Essex County, N.J. In the first letter, 5th May, Rimington states that they set out from Cork on 31 March, but were forced to return to port after the ship was damaged in a terrible storm, " a gale of wind, which continued 12 days the most tempestuous Captain Tinkham ever experienced though he has crossed the Atlantic thirty six times...." Rimington details the rest of the voyage, including engaging three French privateers and the crew's near mutiny. He penned a second letter to his father upon his arrival in Boston, 4th Aug., and provided his initial impressions of the city, "...the people in general drink a good deal but it is looked upon as actually necessary, they who drank freely was preserved from the yellow fever last year when others who thought of saving themselves by living low fell victims to it." He then outlined his plans for travel to New York and Philadelphia, and on to "Madeira to Cape de Verd & Sandwich Islands also Othate where Ct. Cook was killed--from there to Cape of Good Hope...." Rimington addressed the third letter to his brother, and it is in two sections. The first part is written while he is still in Boston, 29 Aug., and recounts news received in the morning papers, "a gentleman arrived from New York on Friday last we are informed that the yellow fever has again made its appearance and is making an alarming progress in that city and that the inhabitants are leaving in great numbers." He informs his brother that he has already sent his trunks there, so is unfortunately committed to travel there. By the time writes the second section of the letter, 1 Sept., he is ill and confined to his room with a doctor in attendance. Edward Wilson wrote to Michael Rimington, 24 Oct., and described the final care given his son at the house of I. Tuttle in Essex Co., N.J. Includes a typed transcription of the letters. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections.

creator: Logan (Family)
title: Logan family papers, 1952-1994.
context_snippets: William Wayne Logan, an orthodontist, was a Southern Baptist missionary to Nigeria with his wife Dorothy and their three children, Becky Sue, Martha Alyce, and Steven.

creator: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79022968 creator.
title: Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle papers, 1820-1927 and undated.
context_snippets: The collection consists primarily of the Correspondence Series, 1820-1927 and undated, between Thomas Carlyle, Jane Welsh Carlyle, and various other correspondents. Correspondents include Carlyle's secretary, Henry Larkin; John Fergusson; Thomas Murray; Basil Montagu; Bryan Waller Procter ("Barry Cornwall"); Thomas Erskine; Richard Owen; Frederic Chapman; William McCall; and John Reuben Thomas. Letters present not only a narrative of their own lives, but also provocative discussion of the ideas and events of their time, including the Peterloo Massacre of 1819, the coronation of Queen Victoria, the repeal of the Corn Laws, the Great Exhibition of 1851, the deaths of Sir Robert Peel and the Duke of Wellington, the Crimean War, and the rise of modern Germany. Also present are vivid references to the works and movements of noteworthy contemporaries such as Robert Browning, Alfred Lord Tennyson, Charles Dickens, Ralph Waldo Emerson, Margaret Fuller, Ivan Turgenev, and others. Most of the letters are outgoing from the Carlyles; there is also one letter dated 1860 April 25 from Ralph Waldo Emerson to Thomas Carlyle, asking Carlyle to sit for a portrait. There is also an August 1863 letter from T. Carlyle likely directed to Virginia devine and abolitionist Moncure Conway, who travelled to London in 1863 armed with letters of introduction from Emerson, his mentor. There are several letters from Jane Welsh Carlyle to Henrietta Maria, Lady Stanley of Alderley, discussing day-to-day life with numerous references to her husband, Thomas Carlyle. Also included is a fragment of a letter from Thomas Carlyle to his wife containing reference to Lady Stanley's little boy. The collection also includes miscellaneous correspondence, such as one letter to Charles Kingsley promising to help Kingsley get his book published; one letter to James Aitkin; one to Sir Richard Owen concerning inviting O. M. Mitchel (an American astronomer) to lecture on the Mississippi at Somerset House; one letter from Walter Savage Landor prior to Thomas Carlyle's only visit with Landor; one letter from Thomas Carlyle to London publisher [Frederic] Chapman referring to two manuscripts by Mr. Meccall; one letter from T. Carlyle to Boehm; and one letter from T. Carlyle to John Reuben Thompson, as well as several pieces to or from unidentified correspondents. Also includes a letter from T. Carlyle to D. B. Brightwick at Greenwood College regarding teaching virtue by example (includes published transcription). The Scrapbook Series consists of a volume of clippings and annotations on Thomas Carlyle's life and works compiled by his biographer, David Alec Wilson. The Writings Series consists of manuscript fragments of Thomas Carlyle's "Shooting Niagara: And After?" and his History of Frederich II of Prussia.

creator: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79022968 creator.
title: Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle papers, 1820-1927 and undated.
context_snippets: Thomas Carlyle (4 December 1795 - 5 February 1881) was a Scottish philosopher, satirical writer, essayist, historian and teacher. His wife, Jane Welsh Carlyle (14 July 1801 - 21 April 1866, nee Jane Baillie Welsh in Haddington Scotland) was also a prolific letter-writer.

creator: Chamberlain, Neville Francis Fitzgerald, 1856-1944.
title: Neville Chamberlain letters, 1881-1933.
context_snippets: Collection contains four of Chamberlain's letters. There are two letters to Alexander Scott, one from India (28 June 1881) regarding paintings Scott has sent, along with notes on visitors and hunting, another 12 Dec. 1912, from Dublin, discussing his daughter's marriage and the hanging of Scott's painting's at Lord Robert's estate. There are also two letters Chamberlain wrote to Scott's wife, Alice, regarding an exhibit of her husband's paintings and the impossibility of his purchasing any, as a result of taxation and rheumatism that would prevent his traveling to view the works. Includes detailed remedies of contemporary treatments for rheumatism.

creator: Taylor, H. P.
title: H. P. Taylor papers, 1826-1903 and undated.
context_snippets: H. P. Taylor was a resident of Richmond, Va. His wife was known as "Birdy."

creator: Dundas, David, 1799-1877. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2010181780
title: David Dundas songs and verses, 1864, 1867 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises five songs and verses laid into a presentation copy of SONGS AND VERSES SOCIAL AND SCIENTIFIC presented to Dundas by Lord Charles Neaves. Includes a verse in Latin, "The Death of a Respected Thomas Grenville." There is also a copy of "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star," in Greek; along with "Mr. Buckle," and "To the Wallflower," and a third item whose title is unclear, all in English.

creator: Roane, William, active 1821.
title: William Roane diary, 1813-1821.
context_snippets: Collection comprises the diary Roane maintained between 4 October 1813 - 8 August 1821. Entries primarily record his travel as an attorney for various Superior Courts, but he also outlines his service in the United States Navy (1813-1818) aboard the corvette "John Adams," and notes successful appointment to the Superior Court, his illnesses and their treatment, and the names of those he visits.

creator: Dexter, Andrew Alfred, 1809-1854. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr00022218
title: Andrew Alfred Dexter partial letter, 1841 Jan. 1.
context_snippets: Andrew Alfred Dexter was a civil engineer. He surveyed first railroad from Charleston, S.C. to Augusta, Ga. and laid out the town of Aiken, S.C. He became a cotton planter in Macon County, Ala., but died of yellow fever while surveying a railroad from Mobile to New Orleans.

creator: Dexter, Andrew Alfred, 1809-1854. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr00022218

creator: NULL
title: Brookline, Massachusetts, circular in support of the Roanoke Island Freedmen's Colony, around 1863.
context_snippets: Collection is comprised of a "Circular" disseminated in the Brookline area of Boston, Massachusetts, somewhere around 1863. The small broadside solicited the donations of blankets, clothing, and other necessities for the Roanoke Island Freedmen's Colony. Philanthropist Edward W. Kinsley is mentioned, along with General Edward A. Wild, and it includes a proposal to organize a branch of the "New England Educational Commission for Freemen." The item was likely tipped into a book or other publication; mounting remnants along one edge on verso. Printer: Searle. Committee circulating the request included: D. R. Griggs, T. Howe, C. W. Scudder, W. A. Wellman, and E. G. Tileston. Acquired as part of the George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana and the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Felton, Rebecca Latimer, 1835-1930. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80010324
title: Rebecca Latimer Felton letter and William J. Northen pamphlet, 1894, 1899.
context_snippets: Collection contains a 6-page letter, dated 7 June 1899, from Rebecca Latimer Felton to William J. Northen, who was Georgia's governor between 1890-1894, regarding his request for her critique of a speech he made in Boston (the speech is not present in the collection). She applauded his stating of the facts regarding mob violence and lynching in the South to Northerners, who were anti-Southern and "Negropolists." She then defended the need for lynching, discussed the results of educating African Americans since the Civil War, and promoted her views of white supremacy. Collection includes Northen's pamphlet (17 pages) published in 1894, "The Negro at the South." In it, Northen responded to a number of letters sent to him that promoted lynching by citing Ida B. Wells, the noted African American journalist who exposed the myth of the Black man as rapist. Northen noted not only the extreme numbers of lynchings being carried out, but that they were not restricted to the South, and were also present in states like Ohio and New Jersey. He promised to continue to fight against mob violence and lynching. Acquired as part of the George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana and the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Baker, Ross (Collector)
title: Ross Baker collection of William Styron letters, 1952-1953.
context_snippets: Collection includes 10 letters Ross Baker likely collected in association with his position at Bobbs-Merrill. A few of the letters were published incompletely in the SELECTED LETTERS OF WILLIAM STYRON, but the majority are unpublished. There are seven handwritten letters from William Styron to his editor, Hiram Haydn, composed while Styron was in Paris and Italy during 1952-1953. The letters discuss at length use of Styron's original ending to THE LONG MARCH rather than the standing ending, which Haydn had criticized. This original ending became the published version, rather than what scholar's have accepted as a revised version. Other topics include his thoughts on both the writing and editing processes; Haydn's input; and his activities in Rome and Ravello, which include mention of his future wife, Rose. In addition to THE LONG MARCH, Styron mentions his work LIE DOWN IN DARKNESS, and notes that "The Nat Turner thing still simmers, but I'm not sure I want to start that yet; I have a feeling that I might forestall that for years." Includes a typed copy of the first letter regarding the ending to THE LONG MARCH. The collection also contains two letters from Styron's father, William Clark Styron, Sr., to Haydn. Topics in the first letter (probably dated 1952) include promotions for LIE DOWN IN DARKNESS, news of Bill in Paris, his son's good fortune, and his relationship with Haydn. In the second letter, Styron, Sr., tries to interest Haydn in a writing project for his wife on professional nursing and Nancy Vance.

creator: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80049704
title: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People records, 1960-1965 and undated.
context_snippets: The collection comprises primarily printed N.A.A.C.P. ephemera, including a reprint of a New York Times editorial by NAACP secretary Roy Wilkins on withholding federal funds from states that provide segregated facilities, as well as brochures on the importance of voting, staying in school, and life membership in the organization. It also includes funding support requests and a newsletter from the organization's Legal Defense and Educational Fund, along with a 1960 "Selected Bibliography of Books on Race Relations and the Negro" from the NAACP Division of Research and Information. In addition, there is a brochure entitled, "The Story of the NAACP" that was distributed by the Association of Citizens' Councils in Greenwood, Miss.

In addition, there is a brochure entitled, "The Story of the NAACP" that was distributed by the Association of Citizens' Councils in Greenwood, Miss.

creator: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80049704
title: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People records, 1960-1965 and undated.
context_snippets: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is a black civil rights organization founded in 1905 by a group led by W.E.B. Du Bois and William Monroe Trotter. The organization's mission is to ensure the political, educational, social, and economic equality of rights of all persons and to eliminate race-based discrimination.

creator: Brown, Carl S., 1907-1991.
title: Carl S. Brown letters, 1943-1957.
context_snippets: Collection primarily comprises 33 typed letters Carl S. Brown wrote to his wife during two periods of separation, first 1943, then in 1957; there is also a letter to his daughter he composed while she prepared to attend Northwestern University in 1957. The first set of letters discuss his physical, mental, emotional, and financial transition as he moved from Chicago to serving as Vice President of Operations for the Sherman & Marquette agency in New York City. Topics in the letters include travel via train, subway, and ferry; restaurants; clients; and meetings; his sense of being overwhelmed with New York and its comparisons to Chicago; the impact of World War II on the city; his plans for renting a house for the family; his administrative responsibilities, opportunities, and his confidence in his decisions. His major clients at the time included Colgate and Quaker Oats; he considered the William Esty and Ted Bates agencies his primary competition. His work focused on media presentations, including radio and television advertisements. His negative assessments of African Americans and Jews are readily apparent in his description. The letters written in 1957 continue the general discussion of work and clients, although it is clear that he is now operating at a higher administrative level. However, in general this set of letters are concerned with family matters, including his wife's travel in Europe, her purchase of a Mercedes and it's shipment to the U.S., their children's education at Choate School and Northwestern University, along with general discussions of their social life and country clubs, planned visits with friends and family, and their home in Greenwich, Conn. In all the letters, his affection for his wife and children is evident. One letter in the collection was accompanied by a newspaper clipping, another by three 1.5x1.5-inch black-and-white photographs, featuring images of a dog; a woman with a child who is holding a camera; and a couple with a little girl, all posing in front of a car. Includes a letter from a friend in Washington, D.C., written to Brown before he relocated to New York City, congratulating him on his new position. There is also an empty envelope. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

creator: Brown, Carl S., 1907-1991.
title: Carl S. Brown letters, 1943-1957.
context_snippets: Carl S. Brown, a native of Bethany, Mo., attended the University of Missouri and was a reporter and advertising manager for several newspapers before opening his first advertising agency in 1938. In 1941 he became executive advertising manager of Blackett, Sample & Hummert in Chicago. He came to New York as general manager of the Sherman & Marquette agency and in 1948 founded Brown & Butcher, later the Carl S. Brown Company. He retired in 1962, selling his agency to Cunningham & Walsh, and raised Black Angus cattle on a 100-acre farm in Sharon, Conn. His first wife, the former Elizabeth Hartwig, died in 1966. The couple had three children.

creator: Clark, Kenneth Willis, 1898-1979. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84174751
title: Kenneth W. Clark Civil Defense vertical file, 1942-1943 and undated.
context_snippets: Kenneth Willis Clark was a professor of New Testament at Duke Divinity School (1931-1967); he was a renowned textual critic and leading authority on ancient Christian manuscripts. He married Adelaide E. Dickinson; she served as executive secretary for the Durham County Civilian Defense Council.

creator: American Friends of Vietnam. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86054219
title: American Friends of Vietnam collection, 1957-1960.
context_snippets: American Friends of Vietnam was formed in 1955 to promote United States interests in the country, with the specific goal of saving it from Communism. The organization was formed by prominent liberals and conservatives who considered Vietnam a critical contest in the Cold War. Its membership was selective, and included scholars, journalists, business representatives, as well as members of Congress,

creator: NULL
title: Communist and Socialist songs and lyrics, 1900-1932.
context_snippets: Collection comprises song or lyric sheets for nine Communist and Socialist pieces, including the "Internationale"; "March of the Toilers"; "Banker and Boss"; "Men of the Soil"; "Socialist March"; "The Holhen Bride"; "The Banking Song"; "It's a Long, Long Trail Awinding"; and "Babies Just Babies." Most lyrics are in English, but there are a few in German and Italian. There is also a 70-page songbook, "International collection of revolutionary songs ; International Musical Bureau of I.U.R.T." (Moscow: Moscow State Musical Publishing Office, 1933), with the song in its original language, accompanied by translations in English, German, and Russian.

creator: Hoskins, Sarah.
title: Sarah Hoskins photographs, 2000-2014.
context_snippets: The Sarah Hoskins Photographs contain materials related to two photography projects: The Rosenwald Schools and The Homeplace. The Homeplace series contains 250 11x14 prints documenting Hoskins' visits and relationships with rural African American communities in Kentucky, originally established by freedmen in the 19th century. Her photographs include community events and activities such as hog butchering, tobacco farming, church services, family reunions, and gatherings of charity groups. The Rosenwald Schools series contains 303 digital images of Kentucky, Alabama, and North Carolina schools and buildings built for African American students in the Jim Crow era through the Rosenwald Fund. There are also some portraits of former students. Hoskins' captions and notes about her experience and documentary process for both The Homeplace and the Rosenwald Schools series are included in the collection guide.

creator: Committee to Defend Francisco Molina. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2008035191
title: Committee to Defend Francisco Molina case description, flyers, and articles, 1961.
context_snippets: The Committee to Defend Francisco Molina was formed in 1960. The pro-Castro Francisco Molina, a Cuban American worker from New York, was framed with the death of a Venezuelan girl following a shooting in September 1960. He was arrested and the case went to trial just before the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in April 1961. Molina was convicted, but as a result of the work of the Committee, he was repatriated to revolutionary Cuba in a prisoner exchange for counter-revolutionaries captured during that abortive invasion.

creator: Fulford (Family)
title: Fulford family account, receipts, and letter book, 1799-1805 bulk 1805.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a Fulford family unbound account book that was also used for recording receipts and as a letter book; partial pages have been removed to serve as letters. Accounts are primarily dated 1805, and have to do with the rental of schooners and other ships to transport cargo such as lumber, rum and other liquors, and tobacco, along with supplies for sails and shipping, and occasionally to transport slaves. Each of the elder children in the family are represented in the accounts, but the majority tracked are for Absalom, and Rodney is mentioned often. Receipts for monetary transactions include one for Absalom's rental of the slave Isaac from Zackariah Harker for labor projects. Letters have to do with business and legal transactions.

title: Fulford family account, receipts, and letter book, 1799-1805 bulk 1805.
context_snippets: The Fulford family resided in Carteret County, N.C. William Fulford (1723-1806) had two wives, the first wife's name is unknown and Mary Magdalen Rumley (1755-). The children of his first wife were James M. (1755-1839), Absalom (1758-1826), Jedidiah (1762-1801), Uriah (1766-1825), and Joseph (1770-1804), and his second were Anna ( -1826), Ruth, Mary Magdalene (1775- ), Rodney (1779-1806), Adah (1804- ), and Nancy (1806- ).

creator: San Francisco Women's Centers. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n85096829
title: San Francisco Women's Centers Women's Building records, 1970-1996 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises foundational records for the San Francisco Women's Centers, mostly dating from the 1970s, including articles of incorporation, bylaws, administrative and organizational plans, job descriptions and budgets. Beginning about 1978, the records focus on the organization's purchase and administration of the Women's Building, along with the activities centered there. There are records for tenants, with a lease form, correspondence regarding leases, closing schedules, and an advertisement for leasing space. However, the majority of the collection material comprises flyers, dated 1979-1996, for activities, courses offered, films, speakers series, and ethnic events, along with calls for action, protest, and organizing. Includes a few calendars of events, newsletters, and newspaper coverage of fund raising to renovate the building in 1988. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Toy, Eckard Vance, Jr., 1931-2013, collector.
title: Eckard V. Toy Jr. papers, 1920s-1995.
context_snippets: Collection includes Toy's research files and related materials on various extremist groups in the United States, particularly right-wing Christian extremists, the Ku Klux Klan, and Holocaust revisionists. Files are arranged by group or topic and at times include Toy's correspondence with various representatives. Prominent in the collection are the Church of Jesus Christ Christian, various factions of the Ku Klux Klan, the German American National Political Action Committee (GANPAC), the Institute for Historical Review, pro-Aryan white nationalist groups, and Christian Biblical America. Collection also contains Toy's research on Francis Yockey and Gordon Kahl. Materials from the IHR include two VHS tapes and one audiocassette on Holocaust revisionism.

creator: NULL
title: Letter, account, and dividend book, 1839-1867 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises one volume that served as both a letter book, account book, and dividend book, for different Charleston, South Carolina, companies. Includes a letter book (72 pages) dated 1839-1844 for shoe merchant Joel Witherby & Co. The final letters document Witherby's closing of the company because of his financial troubles. This is followed by 9 pages of an undated account for John Boyle, who was paid for sales of cloth, clothing items, and accessories, although the final two pages also include furniture and housewares. Boyle's account is followed by records (42 pages) of dividends paid by the J. Hunt & Sons shoe wholesaling company. There is one page laid-in from a check record book for N. Hunt & Son. The spine of the volume has an illegible label.

creator: Hozman, Ellsa Lucile.
title: Ellsa Lucile Hozman travel diary, 1913 April 29-1913 August 28.
context_snippets: Collection primarily comprises Ellsa Hozman's travel diary written in ink (85 pages, dated 29 April to 4 July 1913) with diary publisher's title "My Trip Abroad," along with five separate diary pages written in pencil on hotel stationary (dated 11-28 August 1913) and 3 pieces of artwork, all laid-in. The travel diary includes 8 pages printed color lithographs and 12 pages printed information on ships (night signals, time changes, latitudes & longitudes of cities, etc.), as well as a large, folding world map in color bound at the rear of the volume. Ellsa identifies herself on the back of a silhouette of herself in "Quaker costume." She is a young woman traveling in Europe with her parents and two sisters, Jennie and Bessie. The family are wealthy and hire a guide for their travel in Spain. They have friends in many of the cities where they travel, and relatives as well as friends in Berlin. Ellsa describes with great detail their travel in Spain, a country that was likely new to her, including the cities of Algeciras, Tangier, Ronda, Granada, Seville, Cordova, Madrid, Toledo, Escorial, Burgos, San Sabastian, and Barcelona. She used her diary to record much of the history she learned from their guide, along with sites seen, including paintings, as well as a long passage describing a bull fight in Madrid. Her description of the two-day trip to Tangier covers 10 pages, with description of the people, donkeys, and activity in the streets, including a Muslim wedding procession, which leads her into a long passage on Muslim wedding customs. Other cities visited include Gibraltar, Genoa, Milan, Lucerne, Interlaken, Bern, Frankfurt, and Berlin, where her description is more routine, and includes mostly activities like walking, shopping, swimming, going to a "moving picture," and visiting an aquarium, along with frequent visits with relatives and friends. One unexplained event occurred in a Frankfurt hotel, where her mother refuses to stay when she sees a "not wanted" sign. Includes two small drawings of Moorish architecture that were laid-in. The penmanship changes mid-way through the volume, then back again, so it may be that Ellsa shared authorship with her sisters. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Hozman, Ellsa Lucile.
title: Ellsa Lucile Hozman travel diary, 1913 April 29-1913 August 28.
context_snippets: Ellsa Lucile Hozman was a born into a wealthy family from the United States, around 1895.

creator: Heiskell, Henry Lee, 1803-1855.
title: Henry Lee Heiskell letter, 1841 March 26.
context_snippets: Collection comprises Heiskell's letter to Dr. Benjamin King at Fort Clinch, Fla., on 26 March 1841. Heiskell provides his opinion about the state of affairs with the Seminoles in Florida; and goes on to note that no Florida doctors will be called before the medical board, although there are 12 other candidates ready to appear. He mentions Dr. Pitcher's application to have his name restored to the Army Register, despite the fact that he was appointed without an examination. He discusses Lt. Fayette Robinson's court martial and the promotion of several men, and points out that Maj. Cooper has been relieved of his duties in the War Department, before recording general troop movements in Florida, and his disapproval of the appointment of General Brown as commissioner to "trust with the Indians." He mentions a visit to King's family, and the daughters' love affairs. The letter is marked private.

creator: Lethbridge, John Hesketh, 1798-1873.
title: John Hesketh Lethbridge diary, 1829 January 1-1831 December 31.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a diary John Hesketh Lethbridge maintained daily beginning in 1829 and ending in 1831. Entries for 1829 and 1831 are preceded by a page or two of verse simply illustrated with drawings of flowers in colored pencil. These are followed by brief daily entries of a few sentences, which usually note his location, any travel, and the weather, along with his family's religious observations and his own beliefs and written prayers. He then recorded his daily activities, including paying bills, letter writing, reading, horseback riding, walks, visits and visiting, dinners and concerts, and whether all of these activities were done alone or with others, especially Julia, his wife at that time. He made special note of a mare who had proven dangerous, speeches made regarding the Catholic question (1829), a duel the Duke of Wellington had with another peer, an exhibition of Chinese art in London, and the King's death (1830). He recorded the birth of Julia's first child, and described his own illnesses and those of family members, including dental work, and the draughts and pills used to treat them. Laid-in is a bookmark made of braided hair.

creator: Wilson (Family : Wilson, Alexander, 1799-1867) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2021016673
title: Col. David S. Wilson family papers, 1847-1907.
context_snippets: The Col. David S. Wilson Family Papers document the activities of Col. David S. Wilson and his family of Dubuque, Iowa, from the mid-1850s through the early 1870s. The majority of the collection consists of the family's correspondence. David and his wife, Henrietta, wrote frequent letters during his many absences from Dubuque. Both parties are well-represented in the family's papers. Topics tended to center on the family's finances, personal and family news, and local events. Col. D.S. Wilson's military service during the 1860s was only mentioned in passing, as it related to the family's travels or finances. Later letters from D.S. Wilson's time in San Francisco discuss court cases and business news, and include details on family disputes between David and his brother Samuel M. Wilson, also a lawyer. D.S. Wilson repeatedly wrote about his unhappiness at being separated from his family in San Francisco. He finally returned to Dubuque to practice law there and in Washington, D.C. Other major sources of correspondence are the couple's four children, particularly Henry (called "Harry") and Gertrude (called "Gertie") Wilson, who spent time at Kenyon College in Ohio and Brooke Hall in Pennsylvania. Henry and Gertrude regularly wrote home to their parents and included news about their activities and classmates. Nearly all of the collection's letters from 1873 and 1874 are directed to Gertie, who was actively courted by several men. Gertrude's suitors between 1870 and 1874 include James S. Donnell (Pittsburgh), John H. Rutherford (Cincinatti), Alonzo E. Wood (Dubuque), James H. Park, Charles Plunkett, and George Brock (Chicago); she eventually married Brock on March 2, 1874. The Wilsons' third child, John, appears to have attended school in Dubuque; letters between him and his classmates are also present in the collection and include many secret messages, codes, and nicknames. "Johnnie" was regularly referred to as the Champion Flirt of Iowa. Only a few letters remain for the youngest son, David Jr., nicknamed "Dada." The collection includes interesting political and legal documents. A diary kept by Wilson in 1860 records his activities as a state senator in the Iowa General Assembly. Also present are miscellaneous materials from some of D.S. Wilson's court cases, including several from the U.S. District Court of Southern California relating to the case McGarrahan vs. the New Idria Quicksilver Mining Company. Wilson's materials also contain a cipher that appears to relate to that case, including code names for various parties and terms. There is also a 1855 General Land Office certificate for D.S. Wilson, signed by President Franklin Pierce.

creator: Wilson (Family : Wilson, Alexander, 1799-1867) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2021016673
title: Col. David S. Wilson family papers, 1847-1907.
context_snippets: David S. Wilson was born in Steubenville, Ohio, and moved to Dubuque, Iowa, in 1839. He practiced law in Dubuque, San Francisco, and Washington DC; he was also a representative and senator in the Iowa General Assembly and served as a colonel in the 6th Cavalry of Iowa from 1862 until 1864. He and his wife, Henrietta, had four children: Henry, Gertrude, John, and David.

creator: Lyon, Rosina.
title: Rosina Lyon letters, 1846-1849.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 4 letters written by well-educated individuals, including three directed to Rosina Lyon between 1847 and 1849. There is a letter written by an unnamed writer in Louisville, K.Y (30 Nov. 1847), to "sisters Rosina, Louise, and Cousin Beulah," so most likely from a female family member. She writes of teaching her niece and "two colored pupils residing in the family," along with an additional class of African-American students at the local school, as well as settling in her new place, meeting new people, getting involved in the local sewing circle, and her loving memories of her classmates and teachers at Mount Holyoke. In another letter from Louisville (27 Jan. 1848), "L.," writes about Rosina's dislocated arm, her participation in local "religious awakenings," and describes African-Americans of all ages who attend the local "colored school. All seem interested. There are but few teachers--little interest seems to be felt in teaching the blacks." The third letter to Rosina is written by her brother-in-law in Fellowsville, Va. (17 Dec. 1849) thanking her for her loan of money and assuring it's receipt. He writes that he is a pastor for 3 churches, with additional preaching duties at three other churches per month. There is an additional letter, written 24 Feb. 1846, by Fanny A. Coleman written to Joseph, a childhood friend. Coleman is a teacher working in Camden, S.C. She writes of the changes in Joseph's family life related to from the death of his father and the resulting unsettled estate, her coming status as an "old maid" and what that means to her, the romantic possibilities for other family members, the Revolutionary War site in Camden, her prospects for advancement to the position of principal, and the fact that teaching positions are as plentiful as ever in the South, but the salaries are lower than they have traditionally been.
