In another letter from Louisville (27 Jan. 1848), "L.," writes about Rosina's dislocated arm, her participation in local "religious awakenings," and describes African-Americans of all ages who attend the local "colored school. All seem interested. There are but few teachers--little interest seems to be felt in teaching the blacks." The third letter to Rosina is written by her brother-in-law in Fellowsville, Va. (17 Dec. 1849) thanking her for her loan of money and assuring it's receipt. He writes that he is a pastor for 3 churches, with additional preaching duties at three other churches per month. There is an additional letter, written 24 Feb. 1846, by Fanny A. Coleman written to Joseph, a childhood friend. Coleman is a teacher working in Camden, S.C. She writes of the changes in Joseph's family life related to from the death of his father and the resulting unsettled estate, her coming status as an "old maid" and what that means to her, the romantic possibilities for other family members, the Revolutionary War site in Camden, her prospects for advancement to the position of principal, and the fact that teaching positions are as plentiful as ever in the South, but the salaries are lower than they have traditionally been.

creator: Lyon, Rosina.
title: Rosina Lyon letters, 1846-1849.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 4 letters written by well-educated individuals, including three directed to Rosina Lyon between 1847 and 1849. There is a letter written by an unnamed writer in Louisville, K.Y (30 Nov. 1847), to "sisters Rosina, Louise, and Cousin Beulah," so most likely from a female family member. She writes of teaching her niece and "two colored pupils residing in the family," along with an additional class of African-American students at the local school, as well as settling in her new place, meeting new people, getting involved in the local sewing circle, and her loving memories of her classmates and teachers at Mount Holyoke. In another letter from Louisville (27 Jan. 1848), "L.," writes about Rosina's dislocated arm, her participation in local "religious awakenings," and describes African-Americans of all ages who attend the local "colored school. All seem interested. There are but few teachers--little interest seems to be felt in teaching the blacks." The third letter to Rosina is written by her brother-in-law in Fellowsville, Va. (17 Dec. 1849) thanking her for her loan of money and assuring it's receipt. He writes that he is a pastor for 3 churches, with additional preaching duties at three other churches per month. There is an additional letter, written 24 Feb. 1846, by Fanny A. Coleman written to Joseph, a childhood friend. Coleman is a teacher working in Camden, S.C. She writes of the changes in Joseph's family life related to from the death of his father and the resulting unsettled estate, her coming status as an "old maid" and what that means to her, the romantic possibilities for other family members, the Revolutionary War site in Camden, her prospects for advancement to the position of principal, and the fact that teaching positions are as plentiful as ever in the South, but the salaries are lower than they have traditionally been.

creator: Bengal Chamber of Commerce and Industry. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50078698
title: Bengal Chamber of Commerce letter of gratitude to Daniel Mackinlay upon his retirement, 1860 February 21.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a letter of recognition and gratitude from members of the Bengal Chamber of Commerce to Daniel Mackinlay, who was retiring as their president and returning to England. The letter is 17x26-inches and is composed of vellum parchment. In 1844 Mackinlay (1810-1882) had been sent to Calcutta to take over management of the firm Gillanders, Arbuthnot, & Co. The letter outlines their esteem, confers their best wishes, and announces their intent to have his portrait painted. It is signed by nine members. In its obituary of Mackinlay in 1882, THE CELTIC MAGAZINE described his retirement as follows, "So much esteemed was he by his brother merchants in Calcutta who had previously conferred upon him the Presidentship of the Chamber of Commerce the highest honour at their disposal that, on his retirement, they had his portrait painted and hung up in their Chamber, while at the same time they presented him with a valuable service of plate, in recognition of his services to his brothers in commerce."

creator: Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies (U.S.), http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no90022649 creator.
title: Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies records, 1966-2014.
context_snippets: The collection is comprised of JCPES administrative records including correspondence, memorandums, budgets, funding reports, publications, policy research studies, conference materials, photographs, audiovisual media, and electronic files. Areas of study include healthcare, HIV/AIDS, minority business, television violence, young fathers, education, and minority community representation. Among its many publications, JCPES published FOCUS magazine from 1972 to 2011, which covered national issues for an audience largely comprised of black elected officials (BEOs). The collection also includes oral histories of Joint Center founders and influencers, interview transcripts, an extensive history of JCPES, materials from the The Joint Center South Africa office which provided post-Apartheid political assistance activities, and original Southern Regional Council publications. Materials of interest to researchers include the interviews/oral histories with founders Louis Martin, educator Kenneth B. Clark who was the first African American president of the American Psychological Association; and McGeorge Bundy, who served as United States National Security Advisor to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson on foreign and defense policy from 1961 through 1966. Interviews and transcripts that add historical perspective to African American issues are conversations with southern black mayors; African American architect and social activist Carl Anthony; and Ernest Green, one of the Little Rock Nine. Conferences include forums, roundtables, and speeches from notable figures, elected officials, and congressional members including Maya Angelou, Joe Biden, Cory Booker, Edward Brooke, Ron Brown, Carol Moseley Braun, George H.W. Bush, Barbara Bush, Henry Cisneros, Shirley Chisholm, Bill Clinton, Hillary Clinton, Charles Diggs, John Hope Franklin, Jesse Jackson, Maynard Jackson, Valerie Jarrett, Barbara Jordan, Vernon Jordan, Jack Kemp, Coretta Scott King, John Lewis, Eleanor Holmes Norton, Barack Obama, Colin Powell, Charles Rangel, Ronald Reagan, Kasim Reed, Condoleezza Rice, Susan Rice, Donna Shalala, Rodney Slater, Doug Wilder, and Andrew Young. Joint Center historical notes compiled by Darlene Clark Hine are included, as well as Juan Williams' historical publication The Joint Center: Portrait of a Black Think Tank. The files and speeches of Joint Center past presidents Eddie N. Williams; Togo West, Jr.; Ralph Everett, Esq.; and past vice president Eleanor Farrar add insight to the Joint Center's mission of illuminating concerns and trends affecting 20th century African Americans to the legislative influencers most able to effect change.

creator: American Colony. Photography Department.
title: American Colony lantern slides of biblical lands, 1910s-1940s.
context_snippets: Collection consists of a set of sixty-six commercially produced, hand-colored lantern slides, featuring photographic images taken in the early 20th century in areas of modern-day Israel, Palestine, Jordan, Lebanon, and Syria. Also includes an original list of titles and a slide projector. The slides were sold in sets by the American Colony Stores, the commercial department of a missionary community based in Jerusalem. The landscapes and scenes were intended to illustrate biblical sites, or to remind the viewer of well-known biblical passages, but a few also depict other types of archaeological sites. The slides measure 4 x 3.5 inches. Locations include but are not limited to: the city of Jaffa (Tel Aviv); Sea of Galilee; Jerusalem; Bethlehem; Mount of Temptation (identified with Mount Quarantania); Jericho; Jordan River; Mount Hermon; Bethsaida; Mount of Olives; Emmaus (El- Kubebeh); the mosaic floor at Beit Jibrin; River Abana (El-Barada); Tyre; and the Temple of Sethos. There are also two glass slides with maps of ancient Middle East and Palestine. Five of the slides are damaged and are filed at the end of the collection. The collection is accompanied by a lantern slide projector and by an original list of slide titles. Acquired by the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

creator: American Colony. Photography Department.
title: American Colony lantern slides of biblical lands, 1910s-1940s.
context_snippets: Based in Jerusalem, the American Colony was founded in 1881 as a utopian Christian community by emigrants from Chicago, United States, who were soon joined by Swedish Christians and other supporters. The community performed many charitable works in the city of Jerusalem and in surrounding areas. Soon the community included a cluster of commercial enterprises, the most successful of which was their photography department. Under the leadership of photographer Elijah Meyers, then Lewis Larsson and G. Eric Matson, the unit expanded and provided a steady income from the sale of souvenir images of the Palestine region, both prints and glass lantern slides. The unit was eventually renamed the Matson Photographic Service. The colony disbanded in the 1950s, but their main headquarters still remains as the American Colony Hotel.

creator: NULL
title: Patent medicine pamphlets, advertisements, mailers, and packaging collection, 1905-1935 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 46 (plus several duplicates) pamphlets, advertisements, mailers, and packaging for popular medicinal cures and treatments dating 1905-1935 in the United States, although the majority date from the 1920s. The medicines come in the forms of gels, pills or tablets, creams, laxatives and toiletries, and claim to help treat diseases and symptoms over a wide spectrum of complaint, including but not limited to: "womanly troubles," ulcers, biliousness, hysteria, rheumatism, sprains, cough or croup, liver disease, asthma, diabetes, hay fever, constipation, backache, dyspepsia, headache, muscle pain/gout, nervous disorders, and excessive perspiration. Companies mentioned include Chamberlain Medicine Co., N.Y. & London Drug Co., Glessner Co., Dr. A. W. Chase Medicine Co., Dr. J. H. McLean Medicine Co., World's Dispensary Medical Association, Dr. Earl S. Sloan Inc., Dr. Scales Pill Co., Foley & Co., E. C. DeWitt & Co. Inc., E. E. Sutherland Medicine Company, Clifton Drug Co., Goodrich Drug. Co., Crane's Medicines, Dr. Miles Laboratories Inc., Rea Bros. & Co., The Blough Remedy Co. and The Haller Proprietary Co. A few items have multi-lingual translation, including Russian, German, Swedish, and Norwegian. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections and the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

creator: Jongintaba, Yahya. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2020039405
title: Yahya Jongintaba papers, 2001-2011.
context_snippets: Collection contains ten volumes written by Yahya Jongintaba in a calligraphic hand, along with his father's architectural plans for a house to be built in Tanzania. The first three volumes are entitled WANDERER (v. 1, 315 pages), HEALER (v. 2, 314 pages), and PERFECT HEALING HEALTH NATURALLY, ORGANIZATIONAL MANUAL (v. 3, 31 pages). The journals were bound in India and record his travels in Zanzibar, Tanzania, India, and Tibet, with a focus on his training as a naturopath. Volume 1 was written in 2006 and begins with Jongintaba's reflections prior to leaving the United States for Africa in 2005. Journal themes are developed as various types of slavery; and include information on his family history, intellectual development, political beliefs, and religious training. He notes throughout his observations on native life, nature, and includes his personal experiences while living in Zanzibar. Volume 2 was written in 2006 and chronicles Jongintaba's travel from Zanzibar to India and Tibet for his studies in natural healing, and is organized by topic, including diet, fasting, self-healing, contemplativeness, continence, exilism, healfulness, and resolution. Volume 3 was written in 2006 as a supplement to volume 2, and serves as a practical reference for establishing a naturopathy practice, including patient notices, forms, fee charts, lists of supplies and their treatment uses, and recommended reading. Volumes 4 and 5 are journals (100 pages each; dated 2001-2005) entitled RECORD OF MY CONVERSION TO NON-ATTACHMENT that trace Jongintaba's spiritual attempts to rid himself of his belongings. Volumes 7 and 8 are journals (151 pages, dated 2003; and 136 pages, dated 2003-2005) entitled BLUEPRINT FOR FREEDOM: RECORD OF EMIGRATION TO AFRICA that pick up the themes of volumes 4 and 5, and record his final preparations for leaving the United States. Volume 6 is a letterbook (93 pages) entitled LETTERS TO MY CHILDREN, containing copies of letters he composed to his girls between 2002-2005; volume 9 is a letterbook (55 pages, others excised) entitled LETTERS FROM AFRICA, comprised primarily of personal letters composed to family members in 2005 July-Nov. Volume 10 is a journal (127 pages) of reflections and advice intended for this son, entitled THE BABY BOOK OF IZENGO, dated 2010-2011. Finally, there is a set of architectural plans, dated 2004-2005, for Uruhu House, the residence Jongintaba built in Marangu, Tanzania. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Jongintaba, Yahya. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2020039405
title: Yahya Jongintaba papers, 2001-2011.
context_snippets: Yahya Jongintaba, formerly Jon Michael Spencer, left his life as tenured professor and scholar of theomusicology in the United States in 2005 and expatriated to Tanzania, in East Africa, with time spent living in Uganda and Ethiopia. He then pursued training in India for a Ph.D. in naturopathy, which he received from the Indian Board of Alternative Medicine. Throughout his career he has taught in the US and Asia.

creator: Triman, Eugene.
title: Eugene and Margaret Triman papers, 1944-1946.
context_snippets: The collection consists largely of correspondence from Eugene Triman to Margaret Bond between December 1944 and April 1946. It is unclear how the couple met, but early letters indicate that Margaret was originally dating another man, "Bert." By November 1945, Eugene and Margaret had begun dating, and by February 1946, they were engaged. There are a few letters from Margaret to Eugene in the weeks leading up to their marriage. Their wedding occurred in late April or early May, 1946. The last letter in the collection is from Margaret's mother in May 1946, wishing the couple a happy married life and enclosing 5 photographs of the wedding ceremony. Most letters are from Eugene to Margaret, and largely center on his affection and love for her. He writes intimately about their relationship, and discusses their future, his expectations of her as his wife, his sexual desires, their need for birth control and contraceptives once married, his conversion to Catholicism, and his plans for employment and education following his discharge from the U.S. Navy. Other topics of interest are his activities and Navy life aboard ships, particularly the USS Howard Gilmore, and his various deployments in New York, Florida, and the Pacific. Other items in the collection are three clippings from local newspapers announcing Margaret's deployment as a servicewoman in the Women's Army Corps, dating from August 1944.

creator: Hedges, Hezekiah, 1796-1847.
title: Hezekiah Hedges receipts, accounts, and letters, 1838-1847 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 8 receipts, several for the firm Hedges & Robinson, an 1845 blacksmith's account for Hezekiah Hedges along with and an 1846 account for meat. Also includes a doctor's prescription for pills to treat "Diane," who is bilious. The doctor also recommends that she "wear a bandage to support her womb as it comes down occasionally" (19 July 1846). This is accompanied by a letter written by the man from whom Hedges hired Diane, offering to decrease the cost of her fee if she is going to be confined in the Hedges' house; it is unclear if she is a slave. There are several undated receipts and pages of calculations.

creator: Hall, William C. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2016033055
title: William C. Hall papers, 1873-1876 and undated.
context_snippets: William C. Hall and his wife, Caroline, were residents of Medina, Ohio. William was a farmer.

creator: Gravely, Jabez, 1777-1872.
title: Jabez Gravely papers, 1822-1848.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 2 letters regarding legal matters, 2 receipts, and a note regarding the leasing of a slave. The first letter (1822) was written regarding the sale of land in Henry County in the possession of Henry Morris. It suggests that Gravely investigate the state of the deeds for the property. The second letter (1841) is from Henry Jones in Lincoln Co., Missouri, and contains his request for remittance of his legacy for his father's estate, so that he may purchase the property he has improved, and on which he lives. There is also a note regarding Gravely's leasing (July 1843) of a slave boy named Milton for half a year, from Christopher Y. Thomas, for $32. The note adds that he will furnish the boy "with shirt and pair of summer pantaloons, also with the usual clothing for winter, including shoes and socks & blanket." The receipts are for a $5 subscription (1835) to the RICHMOND WHIG and a $16 purchase (1848) of two shares of stock in the Richmond and Danville Rail Road Co. Cataloger has been unable to firmly establish that these are papers of the elder Jabez Gravely, rather than his son, Jabez Leftwich Gravely, yet assumes the former.

title: Jabez Gravely papers, 1822-1848.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 2 letters regarding legal matters, 2 receipts, and a note regarding the leasing of a slave. creator: Gravely, Jabez, 1777-1872.
title: Jabez Gravely papers, 1822-1848.
context_snippets: Jabez [E. "James" ?] Gravely (1777-1872) was resident of Leatherwood (Henry Co.), Va. He married Judith Wells (1772-1860) in 1797, and the couple had seven children, John Wells, Joseph, Judith, Eleanor, Jabez Leftwich (1809-1883), Francis Cox, and Benjamin Franklin. The Gravely family included tobacco growers who later became the first processors of plug chewing tobacco; many of their slaves took the last name "Gravely." Cataloger is assuming the collection includes the papers of the elder Jabez Gravely, rather than his son, Jabez Leftwich Gravely.

creator: Graves, James T., 1835-1914.
title: James T. Graves papers, 1841-1883 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises primarily physician bills and receipts for Dr. James T. Graves, along with a letter to Graves from his father (1875) regarding family matters, an undated partial page from an account book for the physician's personal expenses, and an business card for O. E. Duffy, who was a solicitor of patents and a mechanical expert in Washington, D.C.

creator: Tinsley, J. T. (John Thomas), 1833-1891.
title: J. T. Tinsley papers, 1847-1896.
context_snippets: Collection is primarily comprised of J. T. Tinsley's financial records, including orders, bills, receipts, statements, invoices, and a few business letters, primarily for his business, but also his personal and household accounts. Together these provide a detailed picture of his professional services and family purchases made for the household and farm. There are freight invoices, reports from a lumber inspector, invoices for blacksmiths, insurance policies, and formalized agreements for land tract use or purchase, including lumber stands, payments witnessed, along with receipts for taxes paid. Includes documents regarding the rental of a slave named Henry, and the purchase of slaves Dorcas and her child [Feu]nardo in 1864. There is also an invoice for lumber delivered to the United States Army in Petersburg in 1864 that is flagged "Loyalty questionable; to be paid if he does not commit any overt act." Tinsley sold his house and moved to a new residence in 1881; there is a list of personal property and farm implements and animals sold by auction, followed by invoices for interior decorating and other improvements made the new home. There are a few items relating to the private education of Tinsley's children, including bills for music lessons, tutors, attendance at Petersburg Female College, McCabe's University School, and the University of Virginia. However, a significant number of the items are related to the settling of Tinsley's estate and the disbanding of his business by his lawyer, W. R. McKenney, following Tinsley's unexpected death at the end of 1891. A separate file contains family papers (16 items), primarily letters from Tinsley's son William, regarding his work, entertainments, and possible travel home. Other letters announce the birth of his daughter Laura's child and his son S. J.'s lack of funds to travel to Petersburg.

creator: Parks, D. C. (David C.), 1834-1917.
title: David C. Parks letters, 1881-1888.
context_snippets: Collection comprises four letters written to D. C. Parks, one regarding a lien he held for property in Alabama (1881). Another announced his election to the Platonic Literary Society of Rutherford College (1883) and requested a liberal donation to help the Society furnish its hall. A third writer (1886) sent Parks a working stick from the Kings Mountain Revolutionary War battlefield as a memento and discussed amounts of tobacco shipped and received from Asheville, N. C., to Lynchburg, Va. A final writer (1888) requested that he rush to officially notarize a document to hold a third party to the agreement.

creator: Dingman, Benjamin, 1804-1871.
title: Benjamin Dingman path-master's warrant and manuscript record of marks, 1805-1845 and undated.
context_snippets: Benjamin Dingman served as an Overseer of Highways for the town of Hartwick (Otsego Co.), N.Y. He married Arminda Newkirk in 1833 and the couple had 13 children.

creator: Vela Piskova Midwifery Institute.
title: Vela Piskova Midwifery Institute presentation photograph album, 1947-1948.
context_snippets: The Midwifery Institute in Sofia, Bulgaria, was named after a famous female organizer of the Bulgarian Revolutionary Workers' Movement, Vela Piskova (1889-1925).

creator: NULL
title: Legal forms for use in Franklin County, Pennsylvania, and Maryland, between 1820-1850.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a volume (150 pages, plus index) containing handwritten samples of legal forms and lists of fees to be charged when they were issued. The samples date between 1760 and 1850; the legal office was probably based in Franklin County, Pa., but the unnamed lawyer also handled cases from Maryland, nearby. The forms are wide ranging, including bonds, letters of attorney, deeds, and conveyances, and topics range from marriage and estate settlements to manumission of slaves to court documents.

creator: NULL
title: Legal forms for use in Franklin County, Pennsylvania, and Maryland, between 1820-1850.
context_snippets: Collection comprises a volume (150 pages, plus index) containing handwritten samples of legal forms and lists of fees to be charged when they were issued. The samples date between 1760 and 1850; the legal office was probably based in Franklin County, Pa., but the unnamed lawyer also handled cases from Maryland, nearby. The forms are wide ranging, including bonds, letters of attorney, deeds, and conveyances, and topics range from marriage and estate settlements to manumission of slaves to court documents.

creator: Mulligan (Family)
title: Mulligan family papers, 1864-1880 and undated.
context_snippets: The Mulligan family resided in St. Lukes Parish, Beaufort, S.C. during the 19th century. Francis Mulligan (1820- ) was a teacher in the parish's Free Schools; one of his sons, Franklin J. (1846- ) Mulligan, was a farmer and trial justice, who resided with his wife, Sarah, at Stafford's Cross Roads.

creator: Adler, Leon S. (Leon Sidney), 1912-1990.
title: Leon S. Adler papers, 1943-1993.
context_snippets: Collection comprises letters, military service and medical records, two photograph albums, and printed items maintained by Leon S. Adler, along with a scrapbook maintained stateside by Roslyn "Posy" Adler between 1943 and 1945 to record Leon's naval service, from his training and teaching at Ft. Schuyler, N.Y., to his service as part of the fleet which occupied Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan, following the war. Includes two printed items, a copy of the book U.S.S. Biloxi published around 1945, and a CRAM'S WAR ATLAS, dating between 1941-1945, along with a U.S. Service flag from World War II. One photograph album is entitled "Nagasaki: City of the Dead" in a calligraphic hand, and focuses on Adler's tour of the city one month after the United States dropped the atomic bomb, 1945 September 18-24. On 20 pages, there are 61 black-and-white 3x5-inch photographs of his tour, documenting the destruction, buildings still standing, medical treatment areas, returned prisoners of war ("ramps"), and conditions for residents remaining. Includes an hand-written introduction, and all photographs are fully captioned in ink. The album also contains a map of Nagasaki and a undated certificate of recognition signed by President George H. W. Bush following Adler's death in 1990 (also mentioned in the military service records file). A second photograph album has a leather cover stamped with the U.S.S. Biloxi banner and Adler's name. This album (133 pages, 351 black-and-white photographs and snapshots, sizes from 2.5x4-inches to 8x10-inches) comprehensively documents life aboard the ship, during leisure and training periods, along with their assignments in Okinawa, Nagasaki, and Hiroshima. Some photographs duplicate those in the Nagasaki photograph album. Most photographs are accompanied by typed captions. There are three loose letters Adler composed to his parents between 5 and 24 Sept. 1945. Topics include the end of his tour of duty and the ship's assignments in Nagasaki. In addition, there are files containing Adler's military service record (1944-1993), as well as his Veteran's Administration medical file (1983-1992 and undated). Adler developed cancers at the end of his life that were potentially related to his exposure at the atomic bombing sites in 1945. The scrapbook maintained by Posy Adler (1943-1945) contains naval service forms, letters, informational documents, certificates, and newsletters and publications, along with a few family letters and letters from business connections regarding Leon's commission, greeting cards and postcards, mementos and newspaper clippings, and twenty two black-and-white photographs. However, the primary focus of the scrapbook was to hold Leon's telegrams and over 183 letters he wrote to Posy during his service. Leon wrote weekly, sometimes daily, and the letters provide a complete description of his service, including training, leisure activities, excursions, homesickness, and other experiences. They often also touch on Adler Company business matters, and his pride in his wife's operation of the store during his absence. Once Leon joined the crew of the Biloxi, his letters focused on life aboard ship, his duties, description of ports, family matters, then the end of the war, the dropping of the atomic bombs, and his preparations to leave the navy. Printed items include a copy of the book U.S.S. BILOXI, probably published in 1946 and a CRAM'S WAR ALAS, undated, for World War II. Oversize materials include a black-and-white photograph of the 29th Indoctrination Class at Ft. Schuyler, N.Y., in dress uniform. Adler was a member of the class, and his classmates signed the photograph and provided their addresses. In addition, there is a U.S. Service Flag from World War II.

creator: Adler, Leon S. (Leon Sidney), 1912-1990.
title: Leon S. Adler papers, 1943-1993.
context_snippets: Leon S. Adler was the son of Marcus Mordechai Valentine Adler and Jeanette B Sternberger and was born in Lebanon, Ind., in 1912. He married Roslyn Woolf, known to the family as "Posy," in 1937; the couple had two children. He was a successful manager of retail clothing stores. Adler became a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy Reserves during World War II, eventually serving as a Communications and Public Information officer from Feb. 1945-Dec. 1945 aboard the U.S.S. Biloxi. He was among the first U.S. occupation forces that arrived in Hiroshima and Nagasaki following the dropping of the atomic bombs, and his photographic and written documentation was uncensored.

creator: Ransom, Edward S. (Edward Stebbins), 1843-1927.
title: Edward S. Ransom letters, 1863 May, November.
context_snippets: Collection comprises two detailed letters (36 pages) written by Edward Stebbins Ransom to his mother during his Civil War service. The letters demonstrate that Ransom was well educated, devoted to his family, and well liked by members of his company. In the first letter, dated 8 May 1863, Ransom detailed his participation in the fighting at Chuckatuck and Reed's Ferry, and the Nansemond River on 3 May. He described their light marching before the battle; skirmishes; deaths he considered unnecessary and a crime, because the doctor was too afraid to cross the river to be with the men; Rebel prisoners from Texas who still itched to fight and North Carolina deserters who were conscripts and refused to do so; and mud too deep to wade in. Also, the men caused a false alarm of attack by pillaging and shooting pigs, and he suffered swelling because of mosquito bites. During their light march, he described their passing through a Virginia town, where all the women either glared at him or cried, "I could not help but pity them, though I know they were strong secesh" (p. 6). He wrote his second letter, dated 14 November 1863, while ensconced in new, brick, quarters in a former store near the shipyard, ferry, and rail road terminus. Their duties at that time involved searching at night for blockade runners in any form. He noted that they still lived on their rations, because not all members of the company would agree to pay 50-75 cents extra per week so that they could live well. He described sharing boxes of food and other goods from home and counted his blessings when he compared his current situation to a year before, when he was living in flooded and muddy camps outside of Fredericksburg. He closed the letter with description of friendships he made with educators who supported and staffed the colored and evening schools, and his religious habits.

creator: Clark, William, 1770-1838. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50083307
title: William Clark Missouri Territory treasury receipts, 1810, 1815.
context_snippets: William Clark was an American explorer, soldier, Indian agent, and territorial governor. A native of Virginia, he grew up in territorial Kentucky before later settling in what became the state of Missouri. Clark was a planter and slaveholder. Along with Meriwether Lewis, Clark helped lead the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803 to 1806 across the Louisiana Purchase to the Pacific Ocean, and claimed the Pacific Northwest for the United States. Before the expedition, he served in a militia and the United States Army. Afterward, he served in a militia and as governor of the Missouri Territory.

creator: NULL
title: French obstetrics manuscripts, around 1750-1800.
context_snippets: Volume contains two separate handwritten pieces on obstetrics, bound together with spine title "Accouchements," including a 50-page record of correspondence between two men that contains detailed case histories, followed by a 682-page exposition that was comprised of lecture notes. The 50-pages manuscript contains a manuscript record of undated correspondence between a Monsieur Lucas and Monsieur de la Motte, almost certainly Guillaume Mauquest de la Motte. The record provides the details of a particularly exotic case of extra-uterine pregnancy and the accompanying difficulties, along with treatment and an attempt at surgical remedy. The balance of the volume comprised of the 682-page quarto manuscript written in three different hands with occasional marginal notes, "Med[icale] pratique-- Chirurgie Medic[cale]: Cahiers sur les Accouchements et les Maladies des Femmes en Couche." It is a series of instructional lectures that detail all kinds of obstetrical problems and their remedies or management. The text can be broadly defined as dealing with pregnancy and then with women and newborn children, with the emphasis (judging by subjects and amount of the text ) on the former. There are occasional references to the literature of the period, e.g., the specific citation to volume two written by Andre Levret (1703-1780) on p. 447; also occasional citations and references to the Royal Academy of Surgery, e.g., p. 454. The bulk of the text is given over to practical application, i.e., case studies with statements of diagnosis and remedies. These are detailed expositions. There are occasional recipes or formulas recorded for medicines. Attribution of these lectures is assisted by a manuscript notation, in a different and somewhat later hand, immediately beneath the title. There the unknown contemporary interlocutor records in French: "There is reason to believe that these fascicles [notes?] are those of M. P[obliterated] or at least that they were written under his dictation and that they are the results of his lectures. What is more the reader will risk nothing in arming himself with much patience in order to read them." Mr. P. is most likely Nicolas Puzos (1686-1753), who served briefly as a military surgeon and became the protege of Royal Physician and "Accoucheur" Julien Clement (1650-1729). Puzos quickly advanced. He was appointed to the Royal Academy of Surgery in 1741, was its director by 1745, and held appointments to the household of Louis XV. This manuscript appears to parallel the order of text in Puzos' posthumously published work on obstetrics [Traite des Accouchements, 1759], but the two are entirely different in content. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections.

creator: Evans, Edward B. (Edward Benjamin), 1846-1922. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2007002293
title: Edward B. Evans letters, 1914.
context_snippets: Edward Benjamin Evans (3 November 1846 - 21 March 1922), a British army officer who attained the rank of Major, was a distinguished philatelist, stamp collector, and philatelic journalist who resided at Longton Avenue, Sydenham, London. His philatelic specialization included Mauritius, the Confederate States of America, the Mulready envelopes, and the Indian feudatory states.

creator: Evans, Edward B. (Edward Benjamin), 1846-1922. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2007002293

creator: Farnsley, A. P. (Alexander Pericles), 1832-1896. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2005096495
title: Alexander P. Farnsley facsimile letters to Miss Bettie Thurman, 1856-1860, 1962 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 11 letters of courtship from Alexander Farnsley to Miss Bettie Thurman, where Farnsley sought to convince her of the sincerity of his love and to marry him. Also includes one undated letter from Thurman in reply, a exhibit description card for items not in the collection, as well as a re-printed (Louisville) Courier-Journal article on the couple's romance, written their great-granddaughter.

creator: Cause Marketing Forum, Inc.
title: Cause Marketing Forum. Halo Award Records, 2002-2012 and undated.
context_snippets: Professional organization founded in 2002 by David Hessekiel to promote business-nonprofit collaboration and corporate sponsorship of social service campaigns. Halo Awards were established in 2003 to celebrate notable cause marketing campaigns.

creator: Demby, William. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86140670
title: William Demby papers, 1986-2008.
context_snippets: Most notable in the William Demby Papers are his unfinished novel, "King Comus," and a lengthy interview transcript from 2008. The collection also contains miscellaneous correspondence from the 2000s, personal documents, and research.

creator: Demby, William. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86140670
title: William Demby papers, 1986-2008.
context_snippets: William Demby (1922-2013) was the author of "Beetlecreek," "The Catacombs," and "Love Story Black." Demby's education was interrupted by World War II, when he served in Italy. He resumed his studies and then returned to Italy to marry Lucia Drudi. He married civil rights attorney Barbara Ann Morris after the death of his first wife and split his time between Florence, Italy and Sag Harbor, NY.

creator: Burns, T. Thomas, collector.
title: T. Burns collection of racial stereotypes, 1880s-1983 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection includes advertisements, games, sheet music, serial illustrations, and other caricatures of African Americans predominately dating from the late 1800s through the mid-1900s. A significant portion of the illustrations were excerpted from news or literature magazines such as Harper's Weekly, Frank Leslie's Popular Magazine, and Puck magazine. The collection also includes advertisements from companies, including Aunt Jemima and Cream of Wheat, which appeared in women's magazines such as Modern Priscilla and Needlecraft. Many items depict African Americans in rural or Southern settings. Of note in the collection are a set of shackles, which have no known provenance or date, but which appear to have been intended for slaves (or could be a reproduction from a later time period). Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Wolfe, Leslie R. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n90703689
title: Leslie R. Wolfe papers, 1972-2014 and undated.
context_snippets: Leslie R. Wolfe spent her career advocating for women's equality through her public policy work in Washington, DC. Wolfe came to prominence as the director of the Women's Educational Equity Act Program (WEEAP), a government agency which fought against sex discrimination in eduation for women in the wake of Title IX. She next served as the director of the Center for Women Policy Studies (1987-2015), a feminist policy research institute. While there, Wolfe continuted to make significant contributions to the fight against gender discrimination in education by publishing a landmark study on gender and racial bias in the SAT test. She also made significant contributions to women's heath care policies through pioneering research and programming focused on women living with HIV/AIDS.

creator: Kennedy, Virginia.
title: Virginia Kennedy World War II letters, 1943-1945.
context_snippets: Collection is comprised primarily of letters mailed to "Ginger" Kennedy from two Army pen pals who were based in Europe between 1943-1945. Capt. Theo D. McGee, who wrote the majority of the letters, was a member of the 9th Finance Division and Pvt. Vladimir A. "Joe" Pitsko was a member of the 14th Armored Division. McGee was based in England and France and wrote about exploring London; the impact of D-Day; local conditions and comparisons between goods and services available in England versus France; his pastimes of writing letters, attending religious services, and croquet; how the army disposed of money recovered from corpses; his interactions with children; and how soldiers were accidentally killed while celebrating V-J Day. Pitsko was based in Bavaria and held other posts in France, and wrote of his light duties, his pastime of horseback riding, and his desire to travel extensively. He provided detailed descriptions of the German cities where he was posted, and included picture postcards. He also mailed Kennedy two collar tabs for a German Police uniform, which are included in the collection. Some partial and full pages have been excised or removed from the letters. Also includes a period playbill for a production of "Junior Miss" at the Saville Theater in London, probably mailed my McGee.

creator: Crowson, Alice, 1857-1916.
title: Alice Crowson letters, 1881-1887 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 28 letters received by Crowson from friends and Beeman family members, mainly cousins, in North Carolina, and an Uncle based in Texas. One of her closest friends, Eugenia Morrison, wrote spirited letters, and teased Alice about her marriage and having a child. Morrison also wrote of her own unwillingness to marry her own suitor and of over-excitement caused by her attendance at a Methodist revival. Courtship, marriage proposals, and the success of religious revivals were common topics, as were health matters, sewing and quilting, canning and preserving, the weather, the success of gardens and crops, and travel and visiting. Crowson's cousin, Clelia, described her suffering and treatments for asthma and her baby's treatment for and slow recovery from cholera. Other letters mentioned the skin inflammation, erysipelas. Crowson's uncle described his successful beekeeping in Texas, among other endeavors. A surprising number of letters mention the body weight of individuals, and one writer refers to Crowson's ongoing struggles with "the blues," possibly postpartum depression (11 Feb 1884). She received a letter from a friend who was attending the Southern Normal school in Lexington, N.C. Several of the final letters were written to offer condolences on her husband's death and her being forced to turn her rent her home.

creator: Tapp, William H., 1814-1892.
title: William Tapp receipts and postcard, 1846-1882 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection contains receipts for amounts paid by or owed to William H. Tapp, along with a few early receipts for Josiah Thompson. It is unclear how the two men were related. Includes receipts for slaughtering completed, a cobbler's work, blacksmithing, the delivery of a walnut coffin and case, and a payment Tapp made in kind, using bacon. Several items relate to the estate of his father, Richard R. Tapp, and to William's purchase of his father's farmland. Others relate to a plea in Tapp's favor in Orange Superior Court. In addition, there is an 1868 receipt for Tapp's "use of the Colored woman, Mary" and marking the $3 amount paid to her.

creator: Peeples, Cincinnatus, 1816-1877.
title: Cincinnatus Peeples papers, 1839-1892.
context_snippets: Collection comprises primarily legal documents and correspondence associated with Cincinnatus Peeples' work, and that of the Peeples & Howell law firm following his death. Items mainly deal with financial collections to be completed in Georgia as a result of legal action; one item involves pensions for Revolutionary War officers and their beneficiaries. Includes a few tickets for membership dues paid in various associations.

creator: Peeples, Cincinnatus, 1816-1877.
title: Cincinnatus Peeples papers, 1839-1892.
context_snippets: Cincinnatus Peeples was born in South Carolina in 1816 and died in 1877. He was admited to the bar in 1839 in Augusta, Georia. He was a respected attorney and partner in the Peeples & Howell law firm in Atlanta, Georgia. He also served as a state senator and became judge of the Atlanta Circuit. He married Eliza Jane Cabaniss (1830-1899) in 1850; the couple had several children.

creator: Richardson, John H., 1830-
title: John H. Richardson financial papers and personal letter, 1860-1874.
context_snippets: Collection comprises business records and a personal letter for John H. Richardson. There are orders placed in Wilmington for goods Richardson produced, a receipt for payment, and a letter disputing the quality of items shipped, all dated 1860. In addition, James H. Bryan wrote to Richardson and his wife to alert them to meet her when she arrived in Franklin in Dec. 1874. He also wrote at length regarding their opposition to the elopement plans of Florence, who was a member of their household (it is not clear whether she is a servant or their daughter), and Sam O'Neal, and their relief that friends and family were able to intervene in time. He added that Florence has been sent to Raleigh, then will travel to Franklin.

creator: Richardson, John H., 1830-
title: John H. Richardson financial papers and personal letter, 1860-1874.
context_snippets: John H. Richardson and his wife, Helen, were residents of Franklin (Macon Co.), N.C. Census records indicate he was a farmer.

creator: Tanner, Evans, 1796-
title: Evans Tanner business records and personal letters, 1830-1882.
context_snippets: Evans Tanner was a postmaster and merchant of Tanner's Store in Mecklenburg County, Va. Part of his business involved trade in tobacco; it is unclear whether he was a planter himself.

creator: Tanner, Evans, 1796-
title: Evans Tanner business records and personal letters, 1830-1882.
context_snippets: Evans Tanner was a postmaster and merchant of Tanner's Store in Mecklenburg County, Va. Part of his business involved trade in tobacco; it is unclear whether he was a planter himself.

creator: Winston, Robert W. (Robert Watson), 1860-1944. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n91055735
title: Robert W. Winston speech to Raleigh Kiwanis Club, 1941 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises Robert W. Winston's undated, annotated, typescript (18-page) speech regarding the development of Raleigh since the end of the Civil War. Also includes a typescript copy of the speech, created in 1941. Winston treated the topic "industrially and sociologically, but not historically." Using sometimes colorful language, he provided anecdotes regarding several notable citizens, as well as Raleigh's move to be known for more than just its penitentiary, insane asylum, and cemetery during the early part of the twentieth century.

creator: Hill, Robert A., 1943- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82094350 creator.
title: Robert A. Hill collection, 1890-2014.
context_snippets: The major emphasis of the Hill Collection is The Marcus Garvey and Universal Negro Improvement Association Papers, a series of publications that Hill edited for over thirty years that compile more than 30,000 documents highlighting the influence and accomplishments of Garvey and the UNIA. The process of compiling the twelve volumes is reflected in Hill's collection of research materials from manuscripts, photocopies of microfilm and original sources, newspaper clippings, annotated printed materials, photographs, scholar's correspondence, FBI records, and annotated drafts from U.S. and international archives, universities, and libraries. Hill's research interests and collected materials document a wide range of topics. Prominent subjects include biographical information, writings, and activities of Marcus Garvey, his family, and his acquaintances, including wives Amy Ashwood Garvey and Amy Jacques Garvey and secretary Elinor White; the administration, political activities, and writings of the Universal Negro Improvement Association; biographical information regarding other African American political leaders, including W.E.B. Du Bois, Cyril V. Briggs, Bob Marley, William Pickens, Robert Athlyi Rogers, George Schuyler, and Alfred C. Sam; documentation surrounding Caribbean independence movements and subsequent interference by the U.S. government and corporations (including the United Fruit Company); the Rastafari movement; black nationalist groups and black separatist churches such as the African Methodist Episcopal Church, the African Orthodox Church, the Afro Athlican Constructive Church; Freedom of Information Act requests and other documentation collected by Hill regarding FBI and government surveillance of African American political activities during the mid-twentieth century; newspapers and literature circulated among African American communities, both by UNIA and other groups; and much more. The bulk of the research materials are reproductions. Original materials collected by Hill can be found in the Primary Sources (PS) series. The collection also contains Hill's personal papers, UCLA-related materials and correspondence, general research, presentations, and other writings. These documents include Hill's historical editions such as Marcus Garvey's The Black Man: A Monthly Magazine of Negro Thought and Opinion; Cyril V. Briggs' The Crusader; George S. Schuyler's Black Empire and Ethiopian Stories; and The FBI's RACON: Racial Conditions in the United States during World War II. The Jamaica Series contains research materials, subject files, transcripts, and FBI reports collected by Hill about the Rastafarianism and International Peacemakers Association movements in Jamaica between the 1950s and 2000s. A subset of this series is original photographs, a scrapbook, and other items produced by Reverend Claudius Henry and members of the International Peacemakers Association in Sandy Bay, Jamaica.

The Jamaica Series contains research materials, subject files, transcripts, and FBI reports collected by Hill about the Rastafarianism and International Peacemakers Association movements in Jamaica between the 1950s and 2000s. A subset of this series is original photographs, a scrapbook, and other items produced by Reverend Claudius Henry and members of the International Peacemakers Association in Sandy Bay, Jamaica.

creator: Hill, Robert A., 1943- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82094350 creator.
title: Robert A. Hill collection, 1890-2014.
context_snippets: The major emphasis of the Hill Collection is The Marcus Garvey and Universal Negro Improvement Association Papers, a series of publications that Hill edited for over thirty years that compile more than 30,000 documents highlighting the influence and accomplishments of Garvey and the UNIA. The process of compiling the twelve volumes is reflected in Hill's collection of research materials from manuscripts, photocopies of microfilm and original sources, newspaper clippings, annotated printed materials, photographs, scholar's correspondence, FBI records, and annotated drafts from U.S. and international archives, universities, and libraries. Hill's research interests and collected materials document a wide range of topics. Prominent subjects include biographical information, writings, and activities of Marcus Garvey, his family, and his acquaintances, including wives Amy Ashwood Garvey and Amy Jacques Garvey and secretary Elinor White; the administration, political activities, and writings of the Universal Negro Improvement Association; biographical information regarding other African American political leaders, including W.E.B. Du Bois, Cyril V. Briggs, Bob Marley, William Pickens, Robert Athlyi Rogers, George Schuyler, and Alfred C. Sam; documentation surrounding Caribbean independence movements and subsequent interference by the U.S. government and corporations (including the United Fruit Company); the Rastafari movement; black nationalist groups and black separatist churches such as the African Methodist Episcopal Church, the African Orthodox Church, the Afro Athlican Constructive Church; Freedom of Information Act requests and other documentation collected by Hill regarding FBI and government surveillance of African American political activities during the mid-twentieth century; newspapers and literature circulated among African American communities, both by UNIA and other groups; and much more. The bulk of the research materials are reproductions. Original materials collected by Hill can be found in the Primary Sources (PS) series. The collection also contains Hill's personal papers, UCLA-related materials and correspondence, general research, presentations, and other writings. These documents include Hill's historical editions such as Marcus Garvey's The Black Man: A Monthly Magazine of Negro Thought and Opinion; Cyril V. Briggs' The Crusader; George S. Schuyler's Black Empire and Ethiopian Stories; and The FBI's RACON: Racial Conditions in the United States during World War II. The Jamaica Series contains research materials, subject files, transcripts, and FBI reports collected by Hill about the Rastafarianism and International Peacemakers Association movements in Jamaica between the 1950s and 2000s. A subset of this series is original photographs, a scrapbook, and other items produced by Reverend Claudius Henry and members of the International Peacemakers Association in Sandy Bay, Jamaica.

title: Robert A. Hill collection, 1890-2014.
context_snippets: Robert Abraham Henry Hill (1943- ) is Research Professor of History at the University of California, Los Angeles; editor of the Marcus Garvey and Universal Negro Improvement Papers, a multi-volume letterpress edition published by the University of California Press and Duke University Press.

creator: Righter & Sutton Lumber Co.
title: Righter & Sutton Lumber Co. collection agent's letters, 1851-1858.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 8 letters sent from Philadelphia by collection agents for the Righter & Sutton Lumber Co. All but one letter was composed by lumber commission merchant John B. Cook. Letters discuss successful collections, but also detail the state of the businesses contacted, the viability of the lumber trade, possible new accounts, and any legal actions taken.

creator: Tillery, John, 1810-
title: John Tillery papers, 1864-1870.
context_snippets: John Tillery was a prominent slaveholding farmer and resident of Halifax Co., N.C. Thomas H. Watson was a neighbor.

creator: Roberts, Nancy, -1847.
title: Nancy Roberts and Nancy Seago estate records, 1838-1848 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises primarily records for the estate of Nancy Roberts, who lived near Cedar Creek in Virginia and probably died in 1847. There is an estate inventory featuring household goods, clothing, crops, and livestock, along with a record for items sold and their bidders, as well as a reimbursement of distribution from Jeremiah Henry. Includes a separate, undated, estate inventory for Nancy Seago, who likely died around 1838 in Anson Co., N.C. The brief list includes livestock; furniture; crops; barn implements and carts; along with slaves Jinne (Jenny, age 50), Ralph (age 20), and Sarah (age 18); as well as outstanding loans and credits.

creator: Robinson, Heman Harwood, 1814-1872.
title: Heman Harwood Robinson papers, 1838-1882 and undated.
context_snippets: Heman Harwood Robinson was born in 1814 in Bennington, Vt., to Samuel Robinson and Sarah Harwood. He married Helen Jane Purdie (1818-1864) in 1836. The couple resided in Elizabethtown, N.C., where he was as a physician and slaveholder. His second marriage was to Mildred Ann Nixon. He had at least 6 children.

creator: Sayre, Daniel R. (Daniel Roff) 1807-1878.
title: Daniel R. Sayre papers, 1829-1904.
context_snippets: Daniel Roff Sayre was a farmer and slaveholder in Union (Union Co.), N.J. Cataloged from items.

creator: Kirby, Reynold Marvin, 1790-1842. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n94073784
title: Army receipt for clothing at Fort Macon, 1834 January 17.
context_snippets: Reynold Marvin Kirby was born March 10, 1790 in Litchfield, Connecticut, the son of Ephraim Kirby and Ruth Marvin Kirby. Ephraim Kirby was an officer in the Revolutionary War. Reynold Kirby was a major in the U. S. Army, 1st. U. S. Artillery. He was a veteran of the War of 1812 and the Seminole Wars. His last assignment was as Commandant of Fort Sullivan from 1839-1842. He died there on October 7, 1842 of pleurisy after a brief illness. He married Mary Barclay Kirby (1811-1891) in 1831 in Richmond, Va. When Kirby died, she moved back to Richmond with their five children: David Barclay, Reynold Marvin, twins Edmund and Margaret Barclay, and Joseph Lee.

creator: J.P. Reynolds & Co. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2001068140
title: J. P. Reynolds & Co. letters, 1875-1876.
context_snippets: In 1868 John P. Reynolds of Salem, Massachusetts, patented a system of displaying a veteran's service record as a work of art called an escutcheon. The general design of these escutcheons was a shield with portions designated to the veterans' ranks, positions, units, and the battles in which they participated. These lithographs and paintings ranged in price from $5 to as much as $125 or more. By 1875 Reynolds had taken on Walter C. Strickler as a partner, a relationship that ended after 1878. Strickler's role was traveling around the country selling escutcheons. In addition to contacting individual veterans, he also made presentations at local G.A.R. posts and set up a display at the 1876 Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia. In an effort to attract new business, the company displayed the escutcheons of several well-known leaders, including Generals U.S. Grant, William T. Sherman, and Philip Sheridan at the Philadelphia exposition. They also solicited written testimonials from other prominent veterans such as Ambrose Burnside, Rutherford B. Hayes, Joshua Chamberlain, and John F. Hartranft. It is unclear how long Reynolds & Co. continued to produce escutcheons, but by 1888, Strickler had formed a competing company (Army and Navy Escutcheon Company) and had been discharged by the board of directors for poor management. The new company was sold to F. H. Dyer of Detroit, Michigan.

creator: Reid, Isabella M. (Isabella Malvina), 1818-1893.
title: Isabella M. Reid papers, 1842-1897 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises Reid and Torrance family letters, a few commonplace books, statements of accounts, and business letters. Hugh Torrance wrote (1846) to Isabella about health matters, particularly his family's bouts with whooping cough and pleurisy, and the return on their cotton crop. Sallie Reid wrote her mother (1848) a general letter concerning family members and friends. In 1865, a Confederate soldier [G.? W. Pondu?] wrote his wife of his plans to rejoin the family, and begged that she remember their promises [of fidelity?] to each other; the two addendums to this letter are too faint to be read. Georgiana (n.d.) wrote her brother James McConnaughey regarding traveling by buggy and the local peach crop, and family news. There are also business letters to Charles Crane Reid in Mayesville, S.C., attempting collection of debts, his own letters requesting free labor to harvest an oat crop, and other attempts to gain the money to become solvent, including one letter to an attorney regarding mortgaging his property. There are family letters written to Charles Reid on the subject, and lecturing him to attend church and show sufficient gratitude. In addition, there are two commonplace books used by Charles Crane Reid for accounts, drafting letters, general notes, and handwriting practice. Also includes a Mayesville, S.C., school enrollment list for 1864.

creator: Moore, R. P. (Robert P.) 1818-1898.
title: R. P. Moore letters, 1859-1860.
context_snippets: Robert P. Moore was a resident of Rutledge (Grainger Co.), Tenn. He served as Clerk of the County Court for Grainger County and was also a farmer and slaveholder. Records indicate that Moore married at least two times, to Mary E. Jennings (1851) and Melvina C. Blackburn (1870); he had several children.

creator: Twyman, James W., 1818-1879.
title: James W. Twyman papers, 1841-1876.
context_snippets: Collection comprises mostly business and legal documents for James W. Twyman. There is a certificate (1841) commissioning him as a 1st lieutenant in the 82nd regiment, 1st brigade, 2nd division of the Virginia Militia. There are also various account statements for general merchants, as well as insurance policies for his household property and machinery (1851, 1855). In addition, there are letters regarding payments made to him and outlining commodity prices elsewhere. Legal documents include his summons for turning a neighbor's home into a garden, and various agreements made in 1866 with tenants for provision of field labor, mill work, mill production, and blacksmithing. It is not clear if these agreements were made with his former slaves.

creator: Twyman, James W., 1818-1879.
title: James W. Twyman papers, 1841-1876.
context_snippets: James W. Twyman was a farmer and slaveholder in Madison County, Va. He died of consumption in 1879.

creator: Saxon, Lyd P. (Lyddall Parke), 1803-1868.
title: Lyd P. Saxon papers, 1854-1867 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 3 letters L. P. Saxon wrote to his Uncle Joshua regarding settlement of his mother's estate and payment of a debt he owes Joshua, as well as describing how he dealt with his wife's death and conditions in Alabama in 1867. There is also an undated letter [to Saxon?] from his father concerning homeopathic treatments for use in the heat. It is not clear how the other items in the collection are related to Saxon. These include 5 letters directed to Col. J. H. Irby from Charleston, S.C., mercantile house W. C. [William C.] Dukes & Sons, regarding cotton prices and payments made to Irby's account. In addition, there are 17 partial letters written by A. Livingston between 1856-1857 and copied by an unidentified writer with a focus on a debt Livingston owed.

creator: Saxon, Lyd P. (Lyddall Parke), 1803-1868.
title: Lyd P. Saxon papers, 1854-1867 and undated.
context_snippets: Lyd P. Saxon (also known as L. P. Saxon) was born in Laurens District, S.C. in 1803. He received his education at West Point, and later engaged in farming. He was at one time colonel of the State militia. He married Mary Eliza Crenshaw (1815-1848) in 1831; the couple had four children. The family relocated to Wetumpka (Elmore Co.), Ala., where Saxon farmed and was a slaveholder. Saxon served as Alabama State Treasurer from 1865-1868.

creator: Ferrell, Timothy K. (Timothy King) 1813-1856.
title: Timothy K. Ferrell letters, 1839-1844.
context_snippets: Collection comprises 28 letters written to Timothy K. Ferrell, primarily written by his sister, Mary, and her husband, Henry King. There are only two letters from his sister, Ellen Louisa, and one from G. H. Ferrell. Topics in Henry King's letters focus purely on business and legal matters, his own and Timothy's, including land and commodity prices, the scarcity of money, and banking hardships. They contain extensive advice regarding Timothy's management of the crops, farm, and animals, as well as how to build his house and barn. King also transferred business affairs to Timothy for completion, primarily so that Timothy would have cash on hand to build his farm. King mentioned traveling to Washington, D.C., to check the government's records of his land holdings. Topics in his sisters' letters initially focus on the death of their mother and it's impact on the family, especially their Father; in later letters they outline marriages celebrated and children born, describe the health of those closest to them and any accidents suffered, mention the businesses of friends and how well they are doing, and occasionally discuss politics, particularly the 1840 presidential race. Includes two family letters written to Mary King from William N. Packhard, regarding the health of a family member.

creator: Cables, James H. (James Harvey), 1842-1924.
title: James Harvey Cables papers, 1792-1934 and undated.
context_snippets: How the majority of the documents in the collection are related to James H. Cables is unclear. Collection primarily consists of legal documents for various North Carolina counties, including land deeds and indentures, summonses, and receipts. In addition, there are 8 letters to Cables and his family members, dated 1889-1934 and undated; an inaugural address by S. R. Hope before the Eumenean Society; a 1922-1923 report of the Ella C. Davidson Auxiliary in York, S.C.; an 1884 article on John C. Calhoun by C. L. Bratton; a Bratton family document relating to a monument for Col. William Bratton in the Revolutionary War; and three pages of printed poems. Contains a 1793 land survey for property held by John Holmes in Anson County, N.C.; an 1805 deed for William Parker regarding land in Rowan County, N.C.; an 1818 indenture for sale of land in Anson County to Roland Wilkerson by William Curlee; a deed for another land sale in 1819 by Wilkerson to Berry Austin; an 1823 deed for sale of land by Berry Austin in Anson County; an 1835 deed for Toddy Tolson in Anson County, along with another Tolson indenture dated 1827; a Frederick Carroll receipt dated 1827; an 1828 Iredell County summons for Harris Rouse; an 1843 Samson county summons for Nathan Williams and his 1842 promissory note; John L. Clifton receipts for 1845 and Bill for Injunction for 1849; a partial copy of Elizabeth Powell's dower dated 1852; and various receipts for Clifton family members dated 1867-1902.

creator: Tate, Alice (Alice Goodloe Lindsay), -1888.
title: Alice Tate letters and covers, 1872-1883 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises letters written to Alice Tate by family members, particularly her mother, cousins, and husband George, as well as friends and acquaintances. Ellen's mother writes about her household staff, and filling in for them as needed; provides updates regarding family members, including their health; outlines caring for Alice's sister, Lottie, and her newborn; enumerates dressmaking and other sewing activities; advises Alice on caring for her health, home, and garden; briefly describes and interprets a dream she has about caring for several of Alice's babies; instructs Alice on how to arrange her hair in the latest fashion; and provides relationship advice to enable Alice to stay happy with George long term. George writes how much he misses his wife and son and mentions the demands of his work; in another letter he discusses getting her a cook and nurse to enable her to feel better. Alice's cousin, Eugene, writes of his travels, maintaining family relationships, and his shock at there being no Bible available during a trip in Florida and the fact that a visiting Northern family doesn't travel with one. Another cousin writes that the local synod meeting has finished and that they witnesses the usual "running of the preachers." Kate Ripply, a family friend, wrote two letters updating Alice on her family's travel to New Jersey, then settling in Mexico. There are sympathy letters written to Alice following the deaths of Lottie Lindsay and George K. Tate, as well as one business letter probably directed to George's brother. Includes four covers.

creator: Rayfield, Lovitt, 1793-1862.
title: Lovitt Rayfield papers, 1828-1843 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises letters written to Lovitt Rayfield, primarily by John R. Rayfield, who attempted to convince his father to relocate to Alabama, then Mississippi. John repeatedly stressed the excellent economic conditions in Alabama, and also described weather conditions and crop prices as favorable to success. He announced he was growing fat as a result of his success, and that he planned to marry Elizabeth Johnson, who owned ten slaves. The pair married in 1838, and John wrote that Elizabeth miscarried in 1839, then announced the birth of a girl in 1840. John grieved over the deaths of his brother and sister, Travis and Caledonia, but argued unsuccessfully against Lovitt's remarriage. There are a few additional letters to Lovitt regarding debt payment or collection, and one requesting his assistance in building a house. In addition, there is an 1843 letter from Lovitt's cousin, Willis Rayfield, regarding Lovitt's inquiry regarding his possible relocation to Georgia. Includes an undated letter from Jane (Lovitt's second wife?) to her mother, regarding sewing, remedies, cider making, the death of one of her children and her loving feelings for others, and an accidental fire in their home. Collection contains a few pages of verse written by John R. Rayfield.

creator: Taliaferro, Elizabeth L., 1786-
title: Elizabeth L. Taliaferro papers, 1835-1855.
context_snippets: Collection comprises primarily business records for Elizabeth Taliaferro, although there are also a few personal letters and a contemporary sheet containing a brief genealogical information for her. Includes accounts, receipts, and letters regarding payments, these contain details regarding household accounts, taxes paid, rents; Taliaferro's mourning and other dressmaking items; doctor's visits and medicine; as well as payments received for oat, wheat, and corn crops and their shipping costs; in addition to equipment repair. There is an indenture dower agreement signed before her marriage to Taliaferro and her 1854 agreement to employ an overseer. Includes information for other family members, including James, George, and Thomas Taliaferro, Benjamin Hackney, and a few other Hackney family members. References to any African Americans serving on the property are not clear.

creator: Taliaferro, Elizabeth L., 1786-
title: Elizabeth L. Taliaferro papers, 1835-1855.
context_snippets: Elizabeth L. Taliaferro was an owner of Roaring Springs plantation in Gloucester, Va. She was born Elizabeth Hackney, and married Francis Thornton (1748-1822) in 1807. In 1824 she married James Baytop Taliaferro (1775-1841) of King and Queen Co., Va.

creator: Terrell, George M., 1818-
title: George M. Terrell family papers, 1836-1904 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises primarily Charlottesville business documents generated by the family's activities, including receipts, promissory notes, household and bank accounts, along with tax records for land and horses, a land deed, and orders placed with George M. Terrell or his sons for oat and wheat crops, corn meal, and cord wood. Federal census records do not indicate that the family owned slaves, but there is an indenture to hire a possible slave, Mrs. Martha Garth's man, Joseph, in 1853. There are a few business letters, and one bill outlines extensive dental work carried out for family members in 1848. There are a few records for Joel Terrell, mostly relating to land taxes, and the bulk of the material from 1860 onward applies to Terrell's son's, William and George, including newspaper subscriptions and orders for school books. There is also a copy of the "Prospects of the Charlottesville Institute for 1874-75;" the Institute was a boys' preparatory school for the University of Virginia.

creator: McCurdy (Family)
title: McCurdy family papers, 1852-1889 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises primarily family and personal letters sent to and by members of the McCurdy family, several of which were love letters or were written regarding the continuation or cessation of relationships with the opposite sex. There is also a letter to Elizabeth, dated 1878, informing her that her father is doing well under his treatment at the Insane Asylum of North Carolina. Also present is a set of letters written by S. L. Jeffers and her husband, Frank, to her parents, but their relationship to the McCurdy's is not clear. In addition, includes business letters directed to Jacob M. McCurdy regarding land pensions and purchases, accounts, taxes, although the majority deal with the transfer of Archibald McCurdy's Revolutionary War pension to Elizabeth. Other items include an 8-pg manuscript song book, probably for guitar; an undated handwritten program for an instrumental music performance; several sets of travel instruction for areas around Salem, N.C.; and an undated copy of "Milns's Geographical Running Hand" copybook.

creator: McCurdy (Family)
title: McCurdy family papers, 1852-1889 and undated.
context_snippets: The McCurdy family was based in Concord (Cabarrus Co.), N.C. Archibald McCurdy (1752-1843) emigrated from Ireland, served in the Revoluntionary War and in the War of 1812 and rose to the rank of Captain. In 1826, he married his third wife, Elizabeth "Maggie" Goodman Greely (1791-1880). The children of that marriage included Archibald Goodman, Jacob Monroe, Sophia, and Caleb Shive. According to the 1840 Federal Census, the family was engaged in agriculture; they owned one slave, and employed one free person of color.

creator: Instituto Cubano de Amistad con los Pueblos. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no95037012
title: Cuban Institute for Friendship among the People letter, 1968 June 21.
context_snippets: The Instituto Cubano de Amistad con los Pueblos (Cuban Institute for Friendship among the People, ICAP), a non-government organization founded in 1960, was established in Cuba soon after the early successes of the Cuban revolution. The purpose of ICAP was to reach out to the international community and form ties of friendship between Cuba and citizens of other countries who were either sympathetic to, or open minded about, Cuba's post-revolutionary ambitions and concerned about possible counterrevolutionary invasion by the United States.

creator: Anthony, Susan B. (Susan Brownell), 1820-1906, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82096260 correspondent.
title: Susan B. Anthony collection, 1870-1900.
context_snippets: Collection comprises seven letters from Susan B. Anthony to various correspondents, one postcard written to her, a printed item, and a letter by S.J.S. Holden that mentions Anthony, Stanton, and the 1874 National Woman Suffrage Association (N.W.S.A.) convention. In June 1870, Anthony wrote two letters to Edwin A. Studwell, who became her business manager, regarding payment for lectures in which she participated with Elizabeth Cady Stanton; her need to sell her serial, The Revolution, and plans for its continued success; competition with suffragists in Boston; her life insurance policies; and her general need for ready funds. There is also a Dec. 1873 letter from Anthony to Judge Henry R. Selden requesting copy for his argument made on Anthony's behalf regarding the Rights of Women in the U.S. District Court of New York, to be published in time for the upcoming N.W.S.A. convention. The postscript to this letter was written upon a flyer for a mass meeting of the New York Woman's Suffrage Society. Collection includes a copy of the final, printed version of Selden's argument, "Rights of women under the late constitutional amendments." In 1894, Anthony wrote two letters to a suffragist concerning problems in Kansas; she wished to identify the Republican, Progressive, or other person responsible for "stirring things up," for the Republicans failed to include suffrage in their platform. On 1900 April 24, Anthony wrote to Rachel [Foster Avery?] regarding several publications in process, including forms for letters to the national conventions of the prohibition, Populist, Democratic, and Republican parties; a "memorial;" an appeal to the Ecumenical Council; along with other work to be shared by the suffrage leadership. A letter from Anthony 1900 July 22 was written to an unnamed suffragist who likely requested an autograph, "Yes indeed--you shall have my pen tracks--not only--but also my wish that you both believe in work for the protection of women in the crowning right of citizenship--the right to vote--and so help to hasten the day when ours shall be a true republic in practice as it now is in theory." Collection also includes a postcard written to Anthony from Mary L. Lathrop in Jackson, [Miss.?] in 1874 regarding Lathrop's inability to send more money following Anthony's successful speaking engagement there; the money went toward advertising for the event. Another letter, from S.J.S. Holden to Rachel [Foster Avery?], in 1874 describes attendance at the N.W.S.A. convention, the speeches of Anthony and Elizabeth Cay Stanton, and other pastimes in Washington, D.C. Several of the letters in the collection are written on N.W.S.A. or National-American Woman Suffrage Association letterhead; Anthony's 1894 letters are stamped with the ownership mark of the Daughters of the Pioneers of Washington library. Collection includes dealer transcriptions for two of Anthony's letters.

creator: Anthony, Susan B. (Susan Brownell), 1820-1906, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82096260 correspondent.
title: Susan B. Anthony collection, 1870-1900.
context_snippets: Susan B. Anthony was born February 15, 1820 in Adams, Massachusetts. She was brought up in a Quaker family with long activist traditions. Early in her life she developed a sense of justice and moral zeal. After teaching for fifteen years, she became active in temperance. Because she was a woman, she was not allowed to speak at temperance rallies. This experience, and her acquaintance with Elizabeth Cady Stanton, led her to join the women's rights movement in 1852. Soon after, she dedicated her life to woman suffrage. Ignoring opposition and abuse, Anthony traveled, lectured, and canvassed across the nation for the vote. She also campaigned for the abolition of slavery, the right for women to own their own property and retain their earnings, and she advocated for women's labor organizations. In 1900, Anthony persuaded the University of Rochester to admit women. Anthony, who never married, was aggressive and compassionate by nature. She had a keen mind and a great ability to inspire. She remained active until her death on March 13, 1906.

creator: Stowe, Harriet Beecher, 1811-1896. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79093331
title: Harriet Beecher Stowe papers, 1853 and undated.
context_snippets: Collection comprises an introduction and a letter written by Harriet Beecher Stowe, along with a carte de visite of her. There is an undated introduction she wrote for the second edition of Narrative of Sojourner Truth. Stowe's statement appears as an introduction in some copies of the 1853 edition. In the introduction, Stowe discusses the African-American abolitionist and women's rights activist, remarking on her mental energy and revelatory powers as a Christian, and attests to Truth's character. She then mentions that the sales of the work will "secure a home for [Truth in] her old age ..." There is an undated letter Stowe wrote from Northampton Depot on Aug. 10 to Mr. Ward, informing him that although she is disposed to support his request, she is under pressures that limit her use of the pen. The carte de visite features a textured surface, and was created by the Howell studio in New York.

creator: Stowe, Harriet Beecher, 1811-1896. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79093331
title: Harriet Beecher Stowe papers, 1853 and undated.
context_snippets: Harriet Elisabeth Beecher Stowe (1811 June 14-1896 July 1) was an American abolitionist and author. Her novel Uncle Tom's Cabin (1852) was a depiction of life for African Americans under slavery; it reached millions as a novel and play, and became influential in the United States and United Kingdom. It energized anti-slavery forces in the American North, while provoking widespread anger in the South. She wrote more than 20 books, including novels, three travel memoirs, and collections of articles and letters. She was influential for both her writings and her public stands on social issues of the day.
